PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable members for Warringah and Ryan making statements to the House forthwith as to the reasons for their resignation from the Ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion needs to be put in writing and seconded.
—I second the motion.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I understand the honourable member for Warringah is about to make a statement of his own volition.
—What about Moore?
—I think the indication from the Leader of the House is that the honourable gentleman should separate his motion. The Leader of the House, by indulgence, wishes to make a point.

—Mr Speaker, the Government does not intend to accept the motion but I just make the point to the House that I understand that any member has the capacity to rise on his own behalf to make a statement if he wishes to do so. I understand that at least one of the two gentlemen whose names are included in the motion has such intent.
—I will hear the Deputy Leader of the Opposition speak to his motion.

—I will be very brief. The public of Australia knows that two Ministers have resigned from the Fraser Ministry. It is important that this Parliament be informed as to the reasons for their resignations. We know that the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) wishes to make a statement. There could be no more important business before this Parliament today than the honourable member for Warringah clearly indicating to the Parliament his reasons for resignation. It would be expected, of course, that the Opposition would wish to make some comment about that matter. Therefore, we are anxious to know at the commencement of the sitting of Parliament today the reasons for the two honourable gentlemen resigning. If only one wants to make a statement, that is his privilege. We are moving for the suspension of Standing Orders to put the procedure of the Parliament in order so as to give top priority to the most important matter before the nation this day, namely, the reason for the resignations of the two Ministers.
—I propose to take an unprecedented course. Before proceeding with debate on the motion I propose to ask both honourable members whether they wish to ask for leave to make a statement.
—Mr Speaker, I propose to seek leave to make a very brief statement .
—I propose to seek leave to make a brief statement.
—On that basis, does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wish to proceed with the motion?
—I want it done at the outset, now. That is the difficulty we face.
—Before I call either of the honourable gentlemen I will return to the blue business sheet and call the Prime Minister to announce ministerial changes and arrangements.

—That is the reason for my motion. I moved my motion so that before we are told what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has done we will be given the reasons for the resignations. That is the point. I am aware of what is on the blue sheet but the reasons for the resignations are not noted on the blue sheet.

—The reasons can be given afterwards. I think it is very important in the interests of the House and the conduct of business that if a person ceases to be a Minister and another person takes his place it should be announced to this Parliament as a matter of first priority.

—I appreciate that. But, Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to the precedent set on 9 March 1971 when the honourable member for Wannon resigned from the Gorton Ministry. The first item of business that day was a motion to allow him to make a statement as to the reasons for his resignation. I am merely following what happened previously in this House.
—The honourable gentleman has made his point. I uphold my ruling that the Prime Minister should announce ministerial changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Governor- General has this day accepted the resignation of Mr MacKellar as Minister for Health and the resignation of Mr Moore as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) has been appointed Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has been appointed Minister for Health until such time as permanent appointments are made. The appointments are in addition to their present portfolios. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) will represent Senator Peter Baume in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) left Australia yesterday to travel to Wellington for ministerial discussions concerning closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand. The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) is acting as Minister for Trade and Resources until Mr Anthony returns. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) left Australia yesterday to attend a meeting of the South Pacific Regional Civil Aviation and Shipping Council in the Cook Islands. The Minister for Education is acting as Minister for Transport until Mr Hunt returns. The Minister for Education will represent the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in this place for that period also. I would like to have incorporated in Hansard, or tabled-whichever the House wishes-the statement I issued yesterday evening.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is entitled to table documents without seeking leave. He will require leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PRIME MINISTER Monday, April 19 1982 FOR MEDIA
Resignation of Ministers

With regret I have accepted the resignations of Mr MacKellar as Minister for Health and Mr Moore as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Both Ministers tendered their resignations in view of questions that have arisen about their actions in respect of customs procedures and having regard to their acceptance of responsibility for those actions.

Mr MacKellar assures me, and I accept, that in bringing a colour television set through Customs last October, he had no intention either to mislead Customs or to evade duty. He has quite properly accepted responsibility for the incorrect declaration that was completed in his name.

The outcome however was that duty was not paid at the time-although subsequently it will be paid-and the Minister therefore appears to be in a preferred position compared with other Australians-something that Ministerial instructions issued in 1976 sought specifically to avoid.

Mr Moore very properly followed-up the question of the incorrectly completed customs declaration form, but not to the extent of establishing whether the item brought in by Mr MacKellar was dutiable or not.
Mr Moore has assured me, and I accept, that his error in not following up this question was an error honestly made.

This Government has always upheld the fundamental principles of Ministerial responsibility, and that the appearance and reality of integrity are indispensable parts of our system of government. I have insisted, and our Party expects, that responsibility should be maintained. It is extremely regrettable that these instances have come into the path of otherwise outstanding performances by these two Ministers.
The penalties in public office are high. Both Ministers accept this and have accordingly volunteered their resignations.

It is my intention to recommend to His Excellency, the Governor-General, that the resignations be accepted. I shall recommend to His Excellency that, for the time being, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Brown, be sworn as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, be sworn as Minister for Health, until such time as permanent arrangements are made. The appointments will be in addition to their present portfolios.
This matter will of course be referred to in Parliament tomorrow. Relevant papers will be available to be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I table the documents from the official files which relate to the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in respect of Customs procedures. Accompanying these documents is a paper setting out in more legible form the handwritten annotations on the documents.
—Is the Leader of the House seeking only to table the documents?
—Yes, Mr Speaker.
—I ask the Leader of the House to move that the House take note of the papers.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Opposition will want to consider these documents. We have not had the opportunity to consider them at this point. I will come back to that matter. Some fairly obvious comments need to be placed on the record immediately. First, the circumstances we are considering today are the product of acts of great personal stupidity; they were morally wrong. It was intolerable that holders of high public office should have allowed themselves to engage in what was a rather unconvincing effort to mislead the public on this matter. What has transpired is the only proper course in all of the circumstances. What is extraordinary, of course, is that it took 24 hours for two members to attempt to put together a simple statement on what they claimed was a very simple and explicable matter. It took a long, tense and speculative weekend for the matter to roll along. Rather extraordinarily, it took a six-hour Cabinet meeting before a final decision was made which resulted in the two members terminating their services as Ministers. One could not have imagined, if the circumstances had not arisen, a situation in which two promising ministerial careers could be ruined over such a relatively trivial item as a $250 television set. One could not have imagined that the Government of the country would be in disarray, that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) again would be under such siege, and that the administration of the nation's affairs would be paralysed at a time of great economic and social crisis, probably the greatest since the Second World War-I repeat, all over a $ 250 television set. But whether the amount be $250, or $2,500,000, the principle is the same.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the question that we must ask ourselves is this: Does the matter stop there? It is a matter of regret for me that I do not believe that it can stop there. I believe that there are at least three serious principal matters which must be ventilated in this Parliament and which deserve more searching inquiry. The first concerns allegations of intimidation undertaken in an effort to prevent a Customs officer well down the line from properly discharging his duty. The second concerns implications of conspiracy. The third concerns the query: Did someone else in the Government know about these matters before they became public knowledge in the media late last week, or was someone within the Government, within the Ministry, in a position in which he should reasonably have known about such matters before the publicity occurred?

First, so that honourable members will understand the seriousness of the matters of alleged intimidation and apparent conspiracy, I quote the relevant sections of the Customs Act 1901. Section 232 states:
Whoever--
And it goes on to conclude:

by threats demands or promises attempts to influence any officer in the discharge of his duty, shall be guilty of an indictable offence, and shall be liable to imprisonment with or without hard labour for any term not exceeding five years.
Section 232A states:
Whoever--
And in paragraph (b) it goes on to state:

endeavours to intimidate any officer, or any person assisting an officer, in the execution of his duty, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable, upon summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding $500 or to imprisonment for any period not exceeding 2 years.
Section 236 states:

Whoever aids abets counsels or procures or by act or omission is in any way directly or indirectly concerned in the commission of any offence against this Act, shall be deemed to have committed such offence and shall be punishable accordingly.
Section 86 sub-section (1) of the Crimes Act 1914 states:
A person who conspires with another person-
(a) to commit an offence against a law of the Commonwealth;
(b) to prevent or defeat the execution or enforcement of a law of the Commonwealth;
(c) to effect a purpose that is unlawful under a law of the Commonwealth;
(d) to effect a lawful purpose by means that are unlawful under a law of the Commonwealth; or
(e) to defraud the Commonwealth or a public authority under the Commonwealth,
shall be guilty of an indictable offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for three years.

I repeat: The allegations of intimidation and the implications of conspiracy represent potentially very serious offences. Therefore, the circumstances of this matter cannot end today. Those allegations and that implication must be thoroughly tested in an independent way. The allegations of intimidation have been commonplace in the last several days in the newspapers. I quote but one source; there are others which report the same sort of thing. The Sydney Morning Herald of 19 April states:
''Some days after the incident the officer was taken to the Clarence Street headquarters of Customs, and interviewed by two senior officers of the department'', Mr Spanswick said.
Mr Spanswick is an official of the Customs Officers Association. Talking about the officer, he went on to say:

He was told bluntly to keep his mouth shut. He was told not to make any further inquiries and to make no written reports. He was told to accept that the matter had been settled at the ministerial level between the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, and the then unnamed minister, on the understanding that it was a black and white set, and that would have been exempt from duty.

The point about this is, first, that this is a very serious felony. It does carry a penalty of imprisonment of from two to five years, and the evidence quite clearly on the public record in the newspapers is that the former Minister for Health, the member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), was told on two occasions that the colour television set in his possession was dutiable. That was established at the work face, at the entry point. The evidence I shall give in a few minutes makes it clear that from the top end, the remote end, of the Bureau of Customs, an assertion was being forced back that it was a black and white television and not a colour television, and that accordingly no action should be taken. I will come to that in a moment. That relates to the implications of conspiracy.

What is significant in terms of what I am raising is that an officer was told to shut up. He was told to keep quiet, even in spite of the evidence that he had seen before his eyes that it was a colour television set; even in spite of the fact that he had told the then Minister that it was a dutiable item and that duty would have to be paid. He was told that people in Canberra, who had never seen the television set, had concluded that it was a black and white television set and that the matter was ended. That is clear intimidation. I want to raise more questions in relation to that matter in a few minutes. However, the issue of conspiracy arises. Having had the assertion that it was a black and white television set rejected by the Customs officer at the work face and having seen him backed by his colleagues who work at that level, someone at the Canberra end persisted in the assertion that it was a black and white television set.

I refer honourable members to today's Australian, in which this matter is fully explored in a report entitled 'Customs men say inquiry must go further'. On a later page a sub-heading states 'Matter should not be put to rest, say union officers'. The evidence on the record shows that the honourable member for Warringah, when he entered this country, was made aware that the television set, being a colour television set, was dutiable. The honourable member for Warringah wrote to the honourable member for Ryan, who was then the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, on 13 October. In that letter he proposed that he would pay any duty. There was no apparent reply from the honourable member for Ryan. It would be a remarkably incurious officer who, having received a letter from a colleague, or anyone, saying 'If I am due to pay duty on a particular item I have brought into the country I am prepared to do so', proceeded no further with inquiry on the matter and allowed it to rest there. I repeat that those at the bottom end of the system, at the front line, constantly said it was a colour television set but those at the top end fed back the assertion, in an intimidating fashion, that it was a black and white set and that the people at the bottom end had to shut up; they had to ignore their responsibilities under the law. Mr Kelly, the Collector of Customs for New South Wales, was caught in the vice in this matter. On the public record it is shown that he received advice from some source on behalf of the Government declaring that the television set was a black and white set and therefore no action should be taken , but on the other end he was being told quite bluntly by officers at the work face that it was a colour television and that they could not accept this sort of doublespeak because it was, bluntly, contradictory.

There are further questions because the matter does not pivot on the letter of 13 October, as we have been told. My office has received reliable information from more than one source. The information is to this effect: That Mr Kelly, the Collector of Customs in New South Wales, was advised on 5 October-the date of the entry to this country of the honourable member for Warringah, and the circumstances which led to this matter coming before the Parliament today-of the incident and that it was a colour television set. Our advice is that Mr Kelly then communicated with a Mr Vince Montgomery, who was then Deputy Secretary of the Bureau of Customs. He is now retired. The information received is that Mr Montgomery then contacted Mr Besley, the head of the Bureau of Customs, and that Mr Besley then contacted Mr Moore, as Minister in charge of Customs. It transpires, apparently, that Mr Besley was told that the set was a black and white set and that he was to treat it as such, and that information fed back down the line. That is the information or large portions of it, that my officers received from not one but three separate sources today. It fed down the line to Mr Kelly, who then told the people working under him that that was his advice and he had to proceed on that basis.

Now, there are questions if this is correct. We are not going to accept a mere assertion that it is not correct; we have had too much evidence in this Parliament of repudiation by the Prime Minister and by government Ministers of serious allegations, only to find with the expiration of time that there was substantial evidence to justify those allegations. If this information is correct-and it must be tested independently-why was the then Minister in charge of Customs in a position on 5 October to declare dogmatically that it was a black and white television set well before the question of its being a colour television set had arisen?

The question is: Did the Minister instruct Mr Besley to tell the Customs officers to proceed on this basis and to take any necessary action, either on that date or subsequently, to make sure that that was the story that stuck? Was the intercept officer, Mr Tony Mayhew, called into the Bureau of Customs and told not to make any report on this matter, to pretend that what he had seen he had never seen? Is it a fact that Mr Mayhew did persist in declaring that it was a colour television set? Was he told that he must not do that, that he must believe that it was a black and white television set? Was the failure to act based solely on the directive that came from a high level, either within the Government or within the Bureau of Customs, and in spite of the statements by the responsible intercept officers?

These are some facts which must be confronted. If the honourable member for Warringah says that he did not know that he had certain responsibilities about the payment of duty for bringing a colour television set into the community he would have to be deaf because he was told by the intercept officer on two occasions that the item was dutiable. If he did not believe that he owed any duty on the item why did he go to the trouble a little more than a week after the incident arose-when he arrived in this country-to write to the then Minister in charge of Customs advising that he was prepared to pay any duty? If the then Minister in charge of Customs did not know that it was a colour television set he would have to be blind and incurious, having received a letter on 13 May. In any case, how could he make a dogmatic decision, as he presumably did, before then, that it was a black and white set? Did the Minister in charge of Customs then prod Mr Besley, who was then head of the Bureau of Customs, in the course of action which subsequently unfolded? Did Mr Besley instruct his subordinates to shut up an honest officer, and any other officer who sought to give that officer support? If he did not, who did?

I ask for an extension of time to speak on this matter, because of its seriousness. There are some other matters in respect of which I want to raise the question of perhaps the Prime Minister's knowledge of this matter much earlier than late last week. In those circumstances, I ask for an extension of time. (Extension of time granted). On the basis of the law which applies in this matter, and which I have quoted, the allegations of interference in the proper conduct of the duty of an officer of the Bureau of Customs is a very serious offence. On the basis of published declarations on this matter coming from officers of the Bureau of Customs, it is clear that they believe that that offence has been committed. That cannot be allowed to rest today. It must be investigated further. On the basis of evidence which is available on the public record, the implication is obvious that there has been an effort at conspiracy to cover up in this matter. It is more than just a run-of-the-mill cover-up if there is such a matter. Under the law it becomes criminal conspiracy; it becomes a very serious offence. I repeat that the offences in this matter, if established, involve penalties of two years to five years imprisonment. That makes them major offences.

Flimsy falsification has been involved in this whole duplicitous exercise. Everyone on the cover-up end down here in Canberra-those who are near the Government, in the Government or working for the Government-has declared that the set was black and white to save the hide of the honourable member for Warringah. Everyone on the working end of the system says it was a colour television. Where and by whom did this concoction start? Who else is implicated? What is the nature of the conspiracy which was got under way?

There is only one other matter I want to raise, and that is the very serious question which I adverted to a few minutes ago. Again, my office has received information from a source which I would regard as reliable. That information is that either the Prime Minister or the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet received advice about this matter before it became public last week; before all of those events unfolded in the latter part of last week. Is this a fact? If it is a fact there is a very serious matter. Its implications are far reaching and therefore that is an issue that again we on this side of the House cannot allow to rest untested in this House today.

There is, in association with that, the rather curious behaviour this morning of Mr Jeff Townsend, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer. A little after 11 a.m. today Mr Townsend delivered the documents in relation to this matter which, as reported by him, would be tabled today. He delivered them to a Mr John Young who works in a senior position for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Immediately Mr Young, at about 11.50 a.m., brought into my office two bound volumes of the papers which were allegedly to be tabled today relating to the Moore-MacKellar affair. I will now quote from a note prepared by my principal private secretary, Mr Costello. Mr Costello said: 'I picked them up and Jeff Townsend, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer, rushed in, took them from my hand saying that there were some minor procedural errors in it and we would get them back in 10 minutes. I asked Townsend about an hour later where the papers were. He said they had to be changed and there were additional documents. They would not be made available to the Opposition before the House sat'. Why were the documents snatched from the hands of my staff member? If documents were to be added to the total, it would have been a simple matter to have delivered them. Were there documents which, in the view of the Government, retrospectively, should not have been included? If they should not have been included why, in the view of the Government, should they not have been included? Was it a matter of potentially the gravest embarrassment for the Government?

In all of these circumstances-I refer to the information conveyed to my office and the behaviour of Mr Townsend in snatching the documents and rushing off with them before anyone had a chance to peruse them-one starts to speculate on the extraordinary behaviour of the Cabinet sitting for something like six hours to make a decision on a matter which should have been clear cut in the Prime Minister's mind and should have been concluded within a thrice by him once the circumstances were clearly understood by him. So in all of these circumstances there are many serious questions which remain unanswered and there are many serious imputations which float about in a way which allows them constantly to stick to the Government in the most damaging manner.

In those circumstances this matter cannot rest here. It is a very harsh penalty for the two ministers to have what clearly and incontestably were very promising careers cut short by this incident. If the matter rested at that point, that in itself would have been a melancholy fact. But the circumstances which I have raised today are at least equally as melancholy. I repeat what they are. On the basis of the public record there appears to be evidence of an attempt to interfere with the proper conduct and discharge of the duties of a Customs officer. It appears that this was undertaken by direction. That is a very serious offence. Secondly, it appears that a conspiracy was embarked upon to convert what was clearly in the view of the work face Customs officer, and established in fact subsequently, a colour television set into a black and white television set. That too represents a very serious set of circumstances. Thirdly , there is the matter of information being conveyed to my office by a source which I must declare is one I would regard as reliable that the Prime Minister or the Prime Minister's Department was made aware of the circumstances of this incident, if not fully, in clear terms some time before this incident became public knowledge last week. Therefore, I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the House is of the opinion that a judicial inquiry be established to inquire into and report on:

(a) whether the proper procedures were followed within the Bureau of Customs and at Ministerial level to investigate the importation of the colour television set by the former Minister for Health in October 1981 and, if not, whether there was a cover-up;
(b) whether a junior officer was victimised for carrying out his duty, both at the point of Customs entry by the former Minister for Health and in the officer' s later complaint;

(c) what actions were taken by the head of the Department in respect of all matters relating to the former Minister for Health and whether these actions were taken with the knowledge and approval of the Government;

(d) more generally, whether the Bureau is effective in performing its functions and the steps that need to be taken to ensure that it is an effective organisation and carries out its applications under the Customs Act, and
(e) whether any other Minister was aware or should reasonably have been aware of these matters and failed to take appropriate action.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the honourable gentleman proposes the suspension of so much of the Standing Orders as would prevent him from moving the motion.
—It is an amendment.
—I apologise. I did not hear the honourable gentleman say that it was an amendment. The Leader of the Opposition has moved an amendment to the motion. Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. We are impelled to move for a judicial inquiry because of the very serious implications which are inherent in the allegations, some of which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has canvassed. I point particularly to the interrogation and the intimidation of a junior officer within the Bureau of Customs who, believing that he was doing his job honestly and courageously, was impugned, interrogated and intimidated by a departmental officer. I wish to paint the circumstances that led this officer to be involved in the case. The officer's name is Tony Mayhew. He has been employed in the Bureau for about 25 years. He has a meritorious record within the Bureau. He was the Customs marshal who first noticed that the then Minister for Health, the honourable member for Warringah ( Mr MacKellar), was carrying a television set. Mr Mayhew asked: 'Is that a television set?' The reply was: 'Yes'. He asked: 'Is it a colour television set? ' The answer was: 'Yes'. He said: 'You have not declared it'. According to Mr Mayhew, the answer was: 'I am a Minister of the Crown and I don't involve myself with the detail on the back of a declaration form'. Apparently the former Minister will dispute that assertion. Nevertheless, that is Mayhew's claim.

SPEECH.PARA: Mayhew then said to the then Minister: 'That set is dutiable. Go to that channel and report to that officer'-an officer named Woodley-'that you are carrying a colour television set and that it is dutiable'. The Minister went to the channel indicated. Officer Woodley started a preliminary examination. He got to ask only three questions-'Is this your luggage? Did you pack it yourself? Is there any other luggage following?'-when he was interrupted by his supervising officer, who inter alia conducted a conversation which the former Minister for Health has repeated on television. The officer said: 'Good morning, Mr MacKellar ; how are you?' The answer was: 'I am tired'. The officer said: 'Oh, come through', and Mr MacKellar went through. That is where his basic mistake was made. At that point he should have said: 'I will pay the duty before I go through'.

'O what a tangled web we weave, when first we practise to deceive'. That is a very relevant quote. The whole matter could have ended very simply there. The careers of two very promising young Ministers in this Government could have been saved right there at that point, but they were not because the then Minister walked through and took his television set home. Officer Mayhew, upon learning that Mr MacKellar had passed through the point without interrogation or investigation, complained to the supervising officer. The supervising officer said to officer Woodley: 'Why didn't you tell me it was a colour TV set?' He replied quite simply: 'Well, you didn't give me a chance, did you? You took him away and I didn't have a chance to look at it'. Officer Woodley diarised all these facts; they are in his diary. He was then questioned in South Australia. He was a South Australian officer on loan to New South Wales because of extra traffic at the time of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

He diarised all these facts. He has been interrogated in South Australia by officer Drury and the Internal Affairs Unit 3 of the Department. I am sure that that is on file. He also claims that the time was 7 a.m. when it happened. The plane landed at 6.15. Anyway, Mayhew was not satisfied with the way that the Minister had passed through the gate so he complained. As I have said, he reported it to Pattison. Mayhew has consistently complained to his union that the proper procedures were not followed-that the Minister was allowed to go through the gate, which was evidence of preferential treatment for a Minister, evidence that duty had not been paid and that a false declaration had been made. He has consistently reported that to his union. As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out, the union consistently referred that to the Department. As I understand it, Mayhew has been interrogated by the Department on three occasions -on 18 January, 16 March and 19 October 1981. As I understand it, on every one of those occasions, Mayhew has stood by his allegation that the set was a colour set. The Department has consistently denied that. The Department, right from the top, has said that it was a black and white television. On the last occasion Mayhew was told that he was to stop saying that it was a colour television set and to stop making written or verbal statements about it. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) had decided that it was a black and white set and that was the end of it; it had been solved at ministerial level and Mayhew was not to go on making his statements.

The Opposition views with great alarm that a responsible public servant, who was doing his job as he saw correctly on behalf of the Australian public, has been pilloried because he was honest enough to stick to his guns. Whether the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs knew this was happening is another proposition. I have no evidence to suggest that he did. But the fact is that the Department knew. The Internal Affairs Unit of the Department knew. It knew that Mayhew had been consistently interrogated and pilloried about the matter He was interrogated by Mr Alan Williams, the Assistant Collector, Port Services, in New South Wales, a man who was filling in for the Chief Inspector of Customs in New South Wales. As the Opposition we will watch consistently and very closely in the future officers Woodley and Mayhew-and officer Spanswick, who is the Federal Secretary of the Customs Officers Association and a preventive officer stationed in Sydney-to see what are their career prospects.

We had related in this House the odd spectacle of Mr Berthelsen of the Department of Defence who, having given evidence to a Senate inquiry, then suffered in his employment and was persecuted forever after. This will not happen to the three officers in the Bureau of Customs because we will make sure that it does not happen. We will make sure in the case of these people, who are honest and who are concerned, that their future prospects are not jeopardised and that their right to do their job responsibly is protected.

Mr Speaker, once the union became fed up with trying to win justice for Mr Mayhew it went to the Press. The Press took this matter up last week and since then we have seen the very odd spectacle, as related by the Leader of the Opposition, of the two Ministers being locked up, quite peculiarly, for 24 hours -trying to present a solution, in a statement that was acceptable to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), because the Prime Minister obviously did not want to sack any more Ministers. Nineteen have already gone and this makes 21. Obviously he was trying to find a way around it. In the long run there is no way around it because the facts are undeniable.

The former Minister for Health, whether by intent or by accident, has impugned the law in three cases. He has made a false declaration; he has evaded duty; and he failed to sign the declaration himself. There is obviously evidence of a forgery there. We are not content to let the matter rest there. Very important principles are involved, quite apart from the staff. There is the whole principle of the collection of customs duties. The whole system depends on voluntary exposition to the officers on a declaration form of what dutiable goods a person is carrying. There is a very important principle here and the whole basis of customs collection revolves around it. Obviously if people were not prepared to make voluntary statements or if their statements could not be accepted as truthful, customs collection would be thrown into awful jeopardy. Every bag would have to be inspected. The system revolves around honesty. If the actions of this former Minister in failing to fill in his declaration form correctly and then failing to pay the duty are accepted as being standard behaviour, obviously the whole system is thrown into real disarray.

Apart from all that, the ex-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, introduced a Bill into the House a fortnight ago to increase the penalties for the evasion of customs duties. In his introductory speech he mentioned the difficulties the Bureau of Customs has in collecting duties. I would like to quote from that correctly but I do not have it with me. It is on page 1371 of Hansard if anybody would like to read it. The ex-Minister pointed out quite lucidly and eloquently that the whole system of customs collection depends on the honesty of the importer or the person coming through the gate.

This is not a piddling matter. The Leader of the Opposition has pointed out all the areas of the Customs Act that have been breached and the high penalties involved. Let us not dismiss this as a trifling matter, an error of judgment because the Minister, as he was then, was tired and failed to fill in his declaration form. This is not acceptable. In the back of that aeroplane were perhaps 300 people without the luxury of first class travel, as we members enjoy . They were sitting in a configuration of eight seats with no room to sleep comfortably, yet every one of those would have been held responsible before the law to make sure the declaration was filled out correctly. So it is not a piddling matter.

May I refer to the Prime Minister now that these two very promising young ex- Ministers have been removed from their jobs in rather tragic circumstances. I say that with some sincerity. The Prime Minister must now accept responsibility for the maladministration of this department. Surely every honourable member must believe, as I believe, the very sacred duty that a Minister has to his ministerial oath, to the whole system of parliamentary democracy, to see that his department is running correctly. The fabric of democracy is very fragile. There are very few democracies left in this world. In the Inter-Parliamentary Union there are, I believe about, 130 member nations. In those nations there are about 30 Oppositions, which indicates 30 democracies. It is incumbent on this Government to pull up its socks and to indicate to the people of this nation, who supported it in three elections, how important it is that its members realise just how vital is the system of ministerial responsibility. It is in the Government's hands. It is the Prime Minister's responsibility to see that this Government develops some form of propriety.

I put it to the Prime Minister that he is sitting there on borrowed time. He has had 21 ministers sacked, resign or removed from office in six years. I will not recite the list. It is a very sad one. We all know who they are. Might I remind the Prime Minister that when Rex Connor resigned voluntarily in this Parliament he did so because he had made an error about a telex date. He had not bullied any public servant or broken any laws. He breached none of the statutes of this country. He voluntarily resigned on a matter of principle. This has never happened with this Government. Only two of the former Ministers have resigned voluntarily, with the exception of the late Eric Robinson and the Member for Kooyong. The rest have either been sacked or removed. Now the Prime Minister is faced with the problem of looking to the drones on the back bench to find two people and dress them up and make them look like administrators. It is not good enough. May I remind the Prime Minister that half the back bench do not want him. Half of that lot sitting there do not want him. That was clearly evident in the recent polling in the party room-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will return to the subject matter of the debate.
—I think this is very important.
—It may be important but it is not relevant to this matter.

—I put it to you that it is, Mr Speaker. The reason we are asking for a judicial inquiry into the activities of the Bureau of Customs is because of the lack of supervision and administration in that area, and it is very relevant to the whole malaise of this Government. That is the reason I am mentioning it. Half of the back bench does not want the Prime Minister; a third of his party do not want him.
—The honourable gentleman will cease that line.

—Well, let me return to this line, Mr Speaker. The evidence of the last week or so has shown us just what a shoddy Government this is. Ministers make what appear to be very superficial mistakes which have cost them very dearly and for which they have paid a very awesome price, but they are not the simple mistakes that the Ministers and the Government want to tell us they are. They are very serious mistakes and have very serious implications, including a lack of administration of a department and a lack of propriety by another Minister. Are things to be swept under the carpet as appears to have been done in this Department?

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition has pointed out to the House quite clearly that there has been a cover-up from the top of the Department to the work face. Apart from perhaps the New South Wales branch of the Bureau of Customs nobody has come out of this matter with any credit at all. I think there is some evidence to suggest that Mr Kelly up until the sixteenth of this month did not know it was a colour television set. There is some evidence to suggest the branch did not know . But certainly within the bureaucracy in Canberra and certainly within the internal affairs section of the Department there was a cover-up. It was known quite clearly from Mayhew's complaint on the date of Mr MacKellar's entry to Australia that this was a colour television. It has been on the record ever since. He has repeated it ad nauseam to no effect ever since only to be accused of being a liar and of making statements that are false. But we all know now that was not false. The public of Australia knows it is not false. It was quite evident in the letter that Mr Mackellar sent to Mr Moore on 13 October that it was not false. He knew it was a colour television set. Mr MacKellar was told by Mayhew: 'Go and pay your duty-that is dutiable'. He did not do so. Perhaps Mr Moore did not know, but somewhere in the Department there has been a massive cover-up, a cover-up of enormous proportions in physical terms but more in spiritual terms, because what has happened indicates the total moral bankruptcy of this Government which has been illustrated in the activities of one department. The people of Australia will not stand for it any longer. Why does the Government not go to the polls instead of its party room and let the people decide? Let the people of Australia decide whether the right honourable gentleman should be the Prime Minister.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Fourth Report of the Department of the House of Representatives, for the calendar year 1981. I commend the report to honourable members.

INTERJECT.PARA: The presentation of the report of the Department of the House of Representatives provides me with the opportunity to remind the House that there is a need-an urgent need-for the House to seek to improve its efficiency as a monitor of Government administration through reform of its procedures. I mention one or two significant points.

I regret, as revealed in the report just presented, that the use of legislation committees over the last year has been minimal. I understand, however, that it is intended to refer a number of Bills to legislation committees this week. Legislation committees provide members with greater opportunities to examine Bills in a bipartisan atmosphere and I urge the Government to make them a more regular feature of the legislative program.

I regret that my efforts to change the nature of the office of Speaker to that followed at Westminster have made little progress. There would appear to be a good deal of public support for the proposal, which has included support expressed in editorials in some leading newspapers. Those writers seem to appreciate the difficulties and disadvantages of the present system. I am pleased to note also a degree of public support and the support of some newspapers for the televising of the Parliament. The newspapers now see it, as I have always seen it, as a means of heightening interest in Federal politics. The community is undoubtedly concerned about many current issues and the televising of proceedings will help to bridge the gap between the community and its elected representatives in this House.

In relation to the question period, after years of discussion about the inadequacies and difficulties of the period, in response to the Leader of the Opposition's motion, we are to have a review of our practices. Members will be asked for their views. I hope that the review will produce a satisfactory result , not only from the Parliament's point of view but also for the wider listening audience.

Although I have expressed some disappointment about progress in the field of parliamentary reform, much has been attempted. I have had preared a schedule which shows action on various reform proposals over the last several years. As I believe it would be of interest to honourable members I shall have it included in Hansard and circulated during the next few days. I shall welcome comments upon it.
The schedule read as follows-
REFORM PROPOSALS AT 'MACRO' LEVEL-SPEAKERSHIP OF SIR BILLY SNEDDEN
Issue

Actions

Speakership-Westminster Convention
Adoption of conventions associated with speakership of U.K. Commons (withdrawal from party politics, etc.) seen as
(a) important in itself; and
(b) essential to increase authority of Chair and acceptance of decisions-with consequential improvement in standards in House
The Speaker has promoted the concept on many occasions, e.g. speech to National Press Club, 8.6.78
The Speaker subsequently circulated 2 papers on the matter,
In May 1979 on the convention, and
In October 1979 on ways the convention could be adopted
In May 1980 a ballot was conducted among Members on the establishment of an all party committee to investigate the matter
Proposals generated a number of comments-in press, e.g., editorials in Canberra Times, West Australian and within community wide-correspondence received
80 replies received (within time); 47 in favour of committee; 32 against; 1 informal.
The Speaker indicated he would seek nominations to committee; he wrote to Whips but matter was not finalised

The Leader of the Opposition argued that such reforms should be investigated as part of a more comprehensive review of Parliament's operation (Mr Hayden gave notice of a motion proposing a joint committee on the operation of Parliament 22 .5.80, notice was again given in the new Parliament. Not yet called on)
Proposals not yet resolved, Government has indicated it does not support them
Televising of Parliament

Televising of proceedings has been seen as bringing Parliament to the people and modifying the sole interpretive role of the media. Canadian experience, where televising commenced in 1977, in particular, has been observed keenly

The Joint Committee on Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings reported that it was desirable to televise the Parliament and made recommendations as to the manner in which this might be carried out. PP 61 (1974). In October 1979 the Clerk circulated a discussion paper, recommending televising of selected proceedings of House and proposing a Parliamentary Television Unit be established to produce coverage (and be responsible to a Parliamentary Committee to be appointed to oversight the matter). Speaker has often (e.g. to National Press Club and 1978 Presiding Officers' Conference) strongly advocated televising, being of the view that it would do more than any other single matter to assist in the restoration of Parliament to its proper standing in the Community
Neither the House nor the Senate debated the report or its recommendations, though part of 1974 Joint Sitting was televised
Issue unresolved, but planning for Parliament House incorporates facilities for televising as integral part of plans
Parliamentary Appropriation

Greater independence for Parliament in the management of its own affairs has been seen as essential. The situation of Parliament charged with oversight of the executive, but being subject to executive control of its own finances etc. is unacceptable

During 1978 the Speaker (and President) made representations to the Government proposing the establishment of a committee of the House (empowered to meet with a similar Senate committee) chaired by the Speaker to examine and confirm Parliamentary estimates prior to their inclusion in the Government's Budget documentation. It was envisaged the proposals would provide the basis for the subsequent development of a series of 'one line' appropriations for the separate Parliamentary Departments

Deferred by the Government in favour of an alternative proposal to have the Speaker submit the estimates to the Minister for Finance and any subsequent areas of contention being subsequently discussed at Ministerial level. During 1980 this was again deferred. A proposal to increase the flexibility of the Department's management of funds voted to it resulted in the Government's agreement to consolidate several items under a common head of expenditure, thus improving all Parliamentary Departments' ability to allocate resources to meet changing and developing needs

In a February 1979 Report the Standing Committee on Expenditure recommended that measures which would enable the House to influence the preparation of its own estimates of expenditure should be discussed in the debate on the committee's report. Pp 66 (1979)

The Government's response was that it had acknowledged the special character of parliamentary estimates and agreed to the amalgamation of some appropriation items for administrative expenses in the 1979-80 appropriation bills, thus permitting the Presiding Officers a degree of flexibility in the management of these funds. Proposals for the formulation and examination of Parliament's estimates for 1980-81, involving personal consultation between the Presiding Officers and Leaders of the 2 Houses, had been conveyed to and accepted by the Presiding officers (H.R. Deb (4.3.80) 581). Debate on the Government's response to the report was inconclusive

The Speaker proposed during 1980 that the appropriations for the House be further consolidated to provide for a 2 line appropriation to cover salary and O /T payments and other administrative expenses

The Government rejected this proposal on the basis that separate control could not then be exercised of overtime and any relaxation of control in the administrative expenses appropriations would not provide for reasonable disclosure of the Parliament's expenditure proposals
In the main Appropriation Bills for 1981-82 details as finalized in relation to the Parliament had been altered from what had been submitted but no reconciliation had been sought by Executive

In June 1981 a Senate Select Committee recommended that the appropriations for Parliament be included in a separate Parliamentary Appropriation Bill and that the Public Service Act be amended to vest in the Presiding Officers the power of appointment, promotion, creation, abolition and reclassification of offices and the determination of rates of pay and conditions of service

The Speaker referred to matter and to wider issues, when appearing before Estimates Committee A on 8 September 1981. The Committee agreed to resolutions that (a) in appropriation procedures for 1982-83 funds for Parliament should be contained in a separate single line Appropriation Bill, etc. and (b) it registered its disquiet at many of the proposed cuts in real terms

On 18 November 1981 the Senate passed a resolution endorsing the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, resolving that the Senate establish a Standing Committee to consider the Senate's appropriations and staffing and listing five other actions to be taken in relation thereto; resolution conveyed to House. On 25 March the Senate established a Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing

On 25 March 1982 the House noted the Senate message. The Leader of the House, in explaining the Government's position stated that Government needed to maintain control over the total amount of funds available for expenditure by the Parliament, there would be a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill, 3 Advances would be made to the Presiding Officers, control of staff would be given to the Presiding Officers and the Government did not intend that the House would establish a committee as the Senate proposed to do
Committees-major review of areas covered, operation, etc.

Since the late 1960's and early 1970's proposals have been advanced for a more effective committee system, reflecting disquiet that the Parliament, and House in particular, was not an effective monitor of the activities of the executive. These proposals have been re-iterated a number of times in more recent years

The Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee system was first established in 1974 and reported on 'A Proposed System of Committees for the Australian Parliament' (PP275 (1975)) and 'A New Parliamentary Committee System' (PP128 ( 1976)). These reports contained wide ranging proposals for overhaul of the committee system
Neither report has been formally debated by the House. The recommendation regarding legislation committees was later taken up by the House (see below)
The House has basically continued to re-appoint a number of investigative committees which together only cover limited areas of Government activity
Most significant overall development was appointment of House Standing Committee on Expenditure (first appointed April 1976)

The Clerk issued a discussion paper 'Development of a Committee System' recommending the establishment of a system of finance and government operations committees for the House, to cover major areas of Government activity (August 1979)
Reasonable press coverage

Legislation Committees In its May 1976 report the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System recommended, inter alia, that standing orders be amended to provide for the appointment of legislation committees to consider bills in detail after they have passed the second reading

After the recommendation was considered by the Government and Opposition, the Standing Orders Committee recommended sessional orders to provide for the operation of legislation committees on a trial basis. PP133 (1978)
In June 1978 the House adopted sessional orders for the establishment and operation of legislation committees

Sessional orders have been adopted for the current Parliament but legislation committees have been used sparingly (7 bills considered in 1978, 2 in 1979 and 4 in 1980). Nevertheless these have provided considerable opportunity for a thorough analysis of the bills in a more bi-partisan atmosphere while Chamber time has been saved

Estimates Committees There has been some dissatisfaction at the effectiveness of the House's financial procedures for scrutinising Government expenditure. In its 1976 report the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System stated the House had not fulfilled its role of financial scrutiny and saw widespread support for the House developing effective committees of financial scrutiny but less agreement on the type of committee(s) required. Support was later given by the Government Members' Parliamentary Reform Committee and others for the establishment of estimates committees
In June 1979 the Government presented for Members' consideration and comment draft sessional orders providing for the establishment of estimates committees

In September 1979 proposed sessional orders were submitted to the House which referred them to the Standing Orders Committee. The Committee recommended the adoption of the proposed orders with some modifications and these recommendations were agreed to by the House. In 1979 2 Estimates Committees operated, in 1980 4 operated. In each case, despite criticism on specific points a number of benefits were gained, e.g. time available, saving in time of House, opportunity for more thorough consideration of expenditure proposals and contact with officials
Sessional orders providing for the establishment and operation of 6 estimates committees have been adopted for the current Parliament. These operated in 1981
Days and hours of sitting

For some years there has been concern to modify sitting hours so that they were both more predictable (e.g. time of rising) and, if possible, involved fewer late nights. There have also been proposals to change the sitting day pattern

Automatic adjournment first introduced in 1970 when the then Mr Snedden was Leader of the House. During Snedden Speakership basic sitting hours have been 2. 15 Tuesday and Wednesday, 10.30 Thursday, with adjournment moved at 10.30 p.m.
In May-June 1978 an experiment was tried involving sitting for 2 weeks of 4 days followed by a 2 week break

In Budget sittings 1978, House reverted to former pattern. Some dissatisfaction expressed, particularly when workload and pattern of Parliamentary life was associated with premature death/illness of Members
In 1979 Mr Cohen revived discussion on reform, proposing earlier sittings on each day, and earlier rising. Dr Everingham also proposed major changes, including a 'week on'-'week off' pattern
Mr Speaker agreed on need for review. Mr Cohen pursued matter in 1980. Mr Speaker indicated no reasons why proposals should not be tried
In March 1981 Senator Martin proposed regular earlier starts and earlier adjournment
In May 1981 a ballot was conducted by Mr Speaker giving Members the opportunity to indicate if they wanted a change
80 out of 102 Members favoured a change
A subsequent ballot was conducted by Mr Speaker to ascertain the preferred option
The most popular alternative was for 12.30-7 p.m. Tuesdays and Wednesdays and 10 .30 a.m.-7 p.m. Thursdays
A preferential ballot was conducted on 10 June in Government Party room using different options
The result was for 1.45 p.m. starts Tuesday and Wednesdays and 10 a.m. on Thursdays, with 10.30 p.m. adjournment
These hours tried experimentally from 20 August by use of sessional order
On 11 March 1982 Senator Grimes gave a notice of motion that would drastically alter the days and hours of sitting for the Senate
On 25 March 1982 the Senate agreed to Senator Grimes amended motion altering the Senate hours of sitting. The new hours are as follows:
Tuesday-
Wednesday-
Thursday-
(No break for lunch)
Accommodation (excluding new Parliament House)

In April 1978 the Presiding Officers proposed to the Government that West Block and the Hotel Kurrajong be made available for parliamentary purposes in view of the desperate accommodation position in which the Parliament found itself

In November 1978 the Government announced that it had decided to proceed with the design and consideration of a permanent Parliament House and drew attention to the need, as a corollary of that decision, for maximum restraint in respect of additional expenditure on the present building

The Presiding Officers indicated to the Government that its response offered no adequate solution to the immediate needs of the Parliament let alone those likely to arise in the next eight years. In March 1980 the Presiding Officers renewed their request for the use of West Block

In September 1979 the Government informed the Presiding Officers that it intended to retain West Block for use by Government Departments and that it considered the Hotel Kurrajong the most suitable location to have parliamentary staff unable to be located in Parliament House

In September 1980 the Speaker made a statement on accommodation problems confronting Parliament and announced that he and the President proposed to establish Presiding Officers Committees to advise them on the matter

In November 1980 the Government acknowledged that the location of parliamentary staff at the parliamentary annex and Hotel Kurrajong was not convenient and offered the use of East Block to the Parliament, after the departure of the Department of Administrative Services to West Block

In June 1981 the Presiding Officers accepted the offer of East Block and requested the allocation of the Kurrajong in its entirety until 1988. Parliamentary staff are schedwled to move into East Block late in 1982
Administrative matters-
House of Representatives Department

In ensuring that Department be able to meet needs of House at optimum level a number of reorganisation proposals had been conidered, however it was decided to have outside expert consultants review the operational effectiveness of the Department
P.A. Consulting Services, with officers from this Department and the Public Service Board reviewed operation in 1977
A number of changes made, some forthwith, others progressively since report made
Joint Departments It was concluded that there could be value in a joint management review of the three 'service' Departments
Urwick International, as part of a team, undertook a joint review of the three Departments in 1980
Some recommendations have been implemented, others are still under consideration

Information systems Each Department within Parliament had been taking steps to equip itself to meet the increasing demands for information in the most efficient way, but potential benefits were seen in a co-ordinated approach

Logica Pty Ltd, with a team of officers from the Parliament and assistance from the Public Service Board, conducted a review in 1980. Members were encouraged to participate in this exercise. A report was presented outlining a long-term plan for meeting the Parliament's information needs
The Parliamentary Departments have adopted a number of the recommendations
A Steering Committee, covering the Parliamentary Departments, oversees progress in this area and makes recommendations to the Presiding Officers as necessary
Privilege-general (and see micro issue)

Privileges Committee repeated recommendation for major inquiry, in 1981 reports

Procedural development-
House of Representatives Practices

Over the years there has been some criticism regarding the House's reliance on Commons' procedure and practice as expressed in May and the need for an authoritative reference text on the practice and procedure of the House has been regularly expressed

In October 1975 Speaker Scholes raised the need for such a text with the Standing Orders Committee. The Committee agreed that the matter be proceeded with as a matter of urgency. In November 1976 the Standing Orders Committee of the 30th Parliament agreed in principle with the need for the work
Work commenced on the text almost immediately and the establishment of the Procedure Office in 1978 enabled greater attention to be given to the project
The completed text, House of Representatives Practice, was published in December 1981

Procedure Committee Some advantages have been seen in changing the present system of bringing about procedural change in that the Standing Orders Committee has been seen as being too unwieldy and not suited to take a positive and continuing role in parliamentary reform

In 1976 the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System recommended that the House establish a Committee on Procedure to maintain a continuing surveillance of practice and procedure with a view to making recommendations for their improvement or change and for the development of new procedures. The Committee also recommended that no office holders other than the Speaker and his deputy be eligible for appointment
Notices have been given under general business of motions to appoint such a committee

In August 1981 the House negatived a general business motion moved by Mr Scholes proposing the establishment of a committee to maintain a continuing surveillance of the practices and procedures of the House
The subject of the appointment of a committee on procedure is scheduled for discussion at the next meeting of the Standing Orders Committee

Later in May 1979 the Speaker raised the matter again in a letter to the Leader of the House
The Leader of the House undertook to respond to the suggestion in detail later

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTRICITY AUTHORITY: EMERGENCY SUPPLY GUIDELINES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Pursuant to section 35D (2) of the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Act 1962, I present the guidelines for the drafting of electricity supply emergency orders . These guidelines have been prepared in accordance with section 35D(1) of the Act which provides that the Minister may, by instrument in writing, make guidelines to be applied by the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority in making emergency orders pursuant to section 35C of the Act. The Authority may make emergency orders only when the Minister has declared that an electricity supply emergency exists in the Territory. The emergency orders must comply with the guidelines, which are required to be laid before each House of Parliament and are subject to disallowance within a period of five sitting days. The guidelines do not come into force until after the five sitting days and the Authority cannot make emergency orders until the guidelines are in force.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate on the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Act 1982, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and Senator Chipp indicated that there should be public input into the framing of the guidelines. Accordingly, the guidelines were referred to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly and at its meeting held on 14 April 1982 the Assembly agreed to them without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), which for some reason I did not get a copy of-
—Didn't get?

—That is right. The statement of the Minister indicates a problem of communication that this Parliament and the Australian Capital Territory have. I refer to the participation as a right and not as an act of grace of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory in the decision-making which affects their day to day living. All other sections of the Australian community have that right and are able to exercise it through their State parliaments and/ or territorial legislatures. Canberra does not have that right. In initital statements on the legislation I indicated that I believed the matter should be resolved and should be the subject of a recommendation by the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. Decisions which affect the day to day lives of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory, as opposed to those which have direct relevance to the national capital, should be determined by resolution of the House of Assembly. I believe it is essential that even at this late stage the Minister and the Government bring into being proposals for some transfers of powers to take place following the House of Assembly elections which are due later this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to another current problem in the Australian Capital Territory which has very much the same history but different consequences. I refer to the ordinance concerning Anzac Day. Last year, almost in the dead of night, an ordinance was prepared and gazetted without any real opportunity for anyone to examine it. It was an ordinance which did not embody the normal standards of law which a country such as Australia is entitled to expect. The ordinance was to be applicable to Anzac Day, but this Parliament was unable to deal with it before Anzac Day. On this occasion, in similar circumstances the Minister and his Department, having not acted on the matter during the past 12 months, are to present an ordinance which has not been agreed to by the representatives of the people of Canberra. Because of the timing of the presentation, chaos would result if this House or another place were to disallow the ordinance during the period which is allowed for such a course of action.

It is an undeniable fact that this Parliament does not want the responsibility- I am certain that Cabinet does not want such responsibility and should not have it-for the day to day civil administrative laws in Canberra. The sooner the residents of Canberra are given the opportunity to elect a body which they know will have certain powers the better. An election for the House of Assembly is due to take place in the next two months. I believe it is not unreasonable for the Government to move to the situation that was applicable to stage one of the two-stage transfer of powers to the Northern Territory. In that case the financial considerations came under the second stage. It is not unreasonable to expect the Government at this time to take decisions on the transfer of the administration of Canberra as it affects the Australian Capital Territory and its residents. There will always be matters in respect of the national capital which will have to be resolved between this Parliament and the residents of Canberra. I believe that we in this Parliament should not and cannot reasonably deal with the domestic matters which affect the lives of the people of Canberra. The sooner we recognise that and divest ourselves of those powers and responsiblities the better it will be for this Parliament and the more democratic will be the processes by which the people of Canberra are governed; they will be governed by themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the 193rd, 194th and 195th reports of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 193rd report refers to our investigation into certain aspects of the administration of the Departments of Defence, Transport and Foreign Affairs and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. Our inquiry arose out of unfavourable comment by the Auditor-General in his reports for 1979-80 and March 1981. In relation to the Department of Defence, the Committee concerned itself with the administration of HMAS Stirling, the naval base in Western Australia. We were generally satisfied with our findings. Likewise, in relation to the second harbour bridge construction for Tasmania, we looked at the Department of Transport's administrative activities and are satisfied that this agency acted properly in its use of the Commonwealth's financial commitment in this area. Our examination of delays by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority in presenting adequately framed financial statements for auditing purposes in respect of the years from 1976 to 1979 resulted in a number of important conclusions. We also comment upon the adequacy of that Authority's procedures for accounting for receipt and use of non- government moneys. The Committee finds quite unacceptable the delay by the Authority in presentation of financial reports. We consider that the financial reports of the Authority should be presented to the Minister within three months of the close of the financial year. Similarly, we are disturbed that the Authority continues to use a cash based accounting system in spite of continued requests by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance to adopt accrual accounting. Our firm recommendation is that this be resolved urgently.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding accounting for non-government moneys, The Committee recommends appropriate amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority Ordinance 1976 be drafted without delay to rectify this accounting anomaly. With respect to the Department of Foreign Affairs we examined comments in the Auditor -General's report for March 1981 relating to accounting at overseas posts. We made recommendations in this area which will have a bearing upon cases such as that of the embezzlement of money from the Australian Embassy in Washington, which was reported in January of this year. The Committee is continuing to examine this particular case.

The 194th report deals with the Committee's examination of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for 1980-81. Expenditure by departments from the Advance during that year was approximately $47.4m. In its annual inquiry into the Advance the Committee seeks to determine whether expenditure charged to the Advance could reasonably have been foreseen in time for its inclusion in the Additional Estimates. As part of this approach, the Committee examines departments on the efficiency of their administration. The Committee requires departments to submit explanations in respect of all items of expenditure from the advance. In 1980-81 we received 129 explanations in relation to these items, and requested supplementary written information from 12 departments for 31 of the items. As part of the inquiry the Committee examined in public hearings the Australian Federal Police in relation to its administrative expenses, the medical and dental services of the Department of Defence, the Department of Finance on natural disaster relief and restoration funding and the Department of Industry and Commerce on reserve capacity maintenance. The Committee's examinations revealed that in all cases expenditure from the advance was properly confined; that is, it met urgent and unforeseen requirements. However, we were concerned that some departments provided insufficient information in their initial submissions which forced us to make supplementary requests and caused further delay. The Committee expects to see a considerable improvement in the 1981-82 submissions.

This report also makes recommendations designed to improve the effectiveness of the programs which were examined. For example, the Committee's reommendations concerning the utilisation of defence hospitals by dependants of servicemen and the need for the development of more suitable undergraduate training schemes should improve the recruitment of Service medical personnel. Implementation of the recommendations concerning the administration of natural disaster relief and restoration funding involve the Commonwealth in adopting a more active role in approving relief measures. This should reduce the time taken for payments to be made. The Committee's examination of reserve capacity maintenance at Government factories indicated that the major issues were the length of time taken to resolve compensation cases and the incidence of apeal by the Commonwealth in such cases. The Committee will be considering this matter further in consultation with its legal advisers.

The 195th report details follow-up action taken on the Committee's recommendations and conclusions from our investigations of the financing and administration of property owned or leased overseas by the Commonwealth Government. The inquiry was prompted by the reorganisation of the Overseas Property Bureau, which was abolished in 1976 and its functions absorbed by the Department of Administrative Services. The Committee then broadened its inquiry to include organisations representing officers and their families serving overseas. The findings of the inquiry were tabled in 1978 as report 172. The response to the Committee, in the form of a Department of Finance minute prepared by an interdepartmental committee, was received in June 1980. After considering the Finance minute the committee decided that the response to certain recommendations was inadequate. Further information was sought at subsequent meetings in August and October of 1981.

The excessive time taken to resolve this Finance minute is not acceptable to my Committee. Two years elapsed from tabling of the report until receipt of a response. Then certain aspects of the response required further follow up. The original response to many sections of the report was generally obtuse and did not pay due regard to our requirements. The Committee believes timely, accurate and complete feedback is essential if the full effects of its reports are to be realised. The conclusions and recommendations of the 172nd report were designed to draw attention to instances of administrative inefficiency and procedural weaknesses and consequently to improve the quality of public administration.

In relation to the Finance minute on this report several matters are outstanding: The effect upon recovery for losses sustained through property damages and cleaning expenses of a joint management review of overseas accounting recommendations; and the results of a review of the setting of rent ceilings. The Committee expects to be advised on the outstanding matters contained in this report at six-monthly intervals from this tabling until ultimate resolution.

In speaking on these reports I wish also to draw the Parliament's attention to delays we have experienced in receiving Finance minutes on a number of our reports. The Department of Finance co-ordinates departmental responses to the Committee and sends us regular reports indicating progress in each Department. They are dependent upon the co-operation of those departments in compiling the necessary responses which comprise a Finance minute to the Parliament. Clearly the Department of Finance is beyond reproach in its supervisory function. But its job of late has been made most difficult by delays from various departments.

The response by the Department of Health to our 182nd report, on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, tabled in September 1980, is a case in point of unacceptable delay which continues to occur. The response to our discussion paper on internal audit has also been slow, as has been the case with other matters contained within the 186th report on the Advance to the Minister for Finance. In the case of our report on the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, the progress of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in responding to a major recommendation in that report can be described only as glacial.
