I may wish to make a separate statement about that in due course. The Committee wishes to put on record that it finds such delays quite unacceptable and that it expects, and will demand, better compliance from agencies in future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek to refer only to chapter three of the Report of the Auditor General No. 193, which relates to the accounting systems of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to the preface of the 193rd Report, where there is a disclaimer from my involvement in the recommendations of the report as related to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority because for much of the time of those negotiations I was the Chairman of that Authority. I think it is worth while pointing out to honourable members the reasons for the delay in the Australian Capital Territory school system presenting its reports based on an accrual basis of accounting.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, there has been considerable debate since October 1977 over the accounting basis on which the Australian Capital Territory schools system is to report. It has been the view of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that a cash basis of accounting is the most appropriate basis on which to submit accounts. But there has been considerable dispute with the Auditor- General, the Department of Finance and now the Public Accounts Committee on the value of the cash basis of accounting versus the accrual basis of accounting. It has been the view of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that the cash basis of accounting is much more appropriate. The reason for that view is that the Australian Capital Territory schools system though in fact a so-called independent schools system, functions very similarly to a territorial department . The Senate Standing Committee on finance and Government Operations, in its report on statutory authorities of the Commonwealth, which was tabled in another place, comments:

There are difficulties in recommending that all authorities should adopt accrual accounting. Some authorities are, to all intents and purposes, government departments which have always operated under a cash accounting system .
It is the view of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that in fact the Authority has the same sort of functions and characteristics of operation as State and Federal departments.

The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority does not receive funds for the full cost of educational services in relation to government schools in the Australian Capital Territory. Funds are also appropriated to the Department of Housing and Construction for repairs and maintenance, to the Department of Administrative Services for school cleaning, to the Department of the Capital Territory for grounds maintenance and to the National Capital Development Commission for minor new works. Therefore, the full measure of support from government funds would not be revealed by prescribing accrual accounting for the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and with the exception of the National Capital Development Commission these departments operate under the appropriation cash basis.

The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has developed its information system on a cash basis to meet its external reporting requirements in addition to its statutory reporting requirements under the Ordinance to meet the information demands from external sources. Examples are the Australian Education Council and the Commonwealth Schools Commission for comparative analysis of national per pupil education costs and other reports. It is worth noting that each of the State education systems operates on a cash basis and reports accordingly. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is in fact no different from a government department in that it does not depart from the important characteristics associated with a conventional government department. It is also interesting to note that the Australian Capital Territory has a health commission which operates as the territorial health department on a cash accounting basis. Similarly, the National Library prepares and furnishes financial statements on a cash basis. I find it interesting to note a statement in paragraph 13 of a Department of Finance memorandum of 27 May 1981 to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The memorandum states:

If the Authority were either subsumed by the Department of Education or if while the Authority was responsible for the administration of education the ownership of resources remains with the Department, cash-based statements could well be appropriate.

Yet, while the Authority in practice operates like a territorial department as distinct from a national department albeit subject to almost all of the same rules and conditions . . . appropriate to a conventional department we suddenly have to operate like a trading concern.

So that has been the main basis of argument. The Schools Authority has submitted views that its accounting system should be based on a cash system of accounting. Meanwhile, the Schools Authority has been carrying out negotiations with various departments and with the Crown Solicitor to try to get a legal position on the basis on which it should submit its accounts. A view was sought from the Deputy Crown Solicitor in August 1978. However, there was considerable delay in any report being forthcoming. But the legal opinion of 28 May 1981 came to the conclusion that as the Schools Authority Ordinance of 1976 stands it is practically impossible strictly to comply with the provisions relating to finance since it would be necessary to examine every transaction involving non- government money to determine whether it is a financial transaction of the Authority within the meaning of section 34 of the Ordinance.

Criticism is made in the report of the Public Accounts Committee of the administrative inefficiency and misunderstanding within both the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority of getting the legal opinion and determining the legal practices to be followed. The Committee rightly points out that it is unacceptable, and this practice was condemned accordingly.

However, while this debate was going on among the Schools Authority, the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General, the Schools Authority was attempting to present its own accounting reports based on a cash system of accounting. The Authority therefore was not intending to operate in an unaccountable fashion but was acting in good faith to present accounts on a cash basis. An annual report, including an interim statement of receipts and payments for the six months to 30 June 1977, was finished and presented to the Minister for Education in May 1979.

In December 1979 the Auditor-General's Office was contacted and advised by the Schools Authority that statements for the periods ended 30 June 1977, 1978 and 1979 would be submitted for audit. In August 1980 the reports of 30 June 1977 and 1978 were presented to the auditor. In September 1980 the statements to 30 June 1979 were presented to the auditor. In March 1981 the reports to 30 June 1980 were available to be presented to the auditor. However, they were not able to be submitted because from February 1981 the Authority found itself without an auditor following the retirement of the previous Auditor-General, Mr Steele Craik. The new Auditor-General, Mr Brigden, refused to take on the personal appointment as Auditor-General to the Schools Authority. There was then an attempt to amend the audit regulations to bring the Authority under the provisions of division 3 of section 11 of the Audit Act. This announcement was made in the Commonwealth Gazette of 3 December 1981. On 24 November 1981 the Minister for Finance was advised that cash based statements for 30 June 1980 were not approved. However on 17 February it was agreed that cash based accounting be accepted to June 1981 and Statements from 30 June 1980 were submitted on 3 March 1982 and reports for 30 June 1981 are now in preparation.

So members of this House can see that there has been a consistent effort on the part of the Schools Authority to present accounts. There has been no attempt at all not to be accountable to the community of the Australian Capital Territory and to the national Parliament. Rather, the understanding was that the most efficient way to present those accounts would be through a cash basis of accounting. It has been determined that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority must present all future accounts on the accrual basis of accounting. I would hope that sufficient staff and expertise would be made available to allow the Schools Authority to provide this basis of accounting in the manner that has been set out in the 193rd report of the Public Accounts Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I refer to chapter 4 of the 193rd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which deals with the accounting procedures and overseas posts of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Following the inspection of five posts in Africa the Auditor-General reported that there were unsatisfactory features at a number of the posts including: Accelerated payment at the end of the financial year to avoid the lapsing of funds under section 36 of the Audit Act; incorrect practices for the recording of commitments; and poorly maintained and controlled film libraries. The joint management review team report recommends that a uniform accounting system be introduced. This would involve setting up large accounting offices manned by Department of Finance officers in London, Washington and Canberra. All overseas missions would be responsible to one or other of these offices for all financial matters. This system would remove flexibility from individual posts.

SPEECH.PARA: The move should be towards imprest posts and away from accounting offices as there would be long delays in processing posts' accounts unless large numbers of staff were employed at the accounting offices. Payment by cheques drawn in, say, London would not necessarily be acceptable to embassy suppliers in, for example, Tanzania and cheques drawn in Washington certainly would not be acceptable in Latin America. All accounting work would be done by Department of Finance staff, which would encourage a move away from having competent accounting staff in the Department of Foreign Affairs. Training in accounting is essential in the Department of Foreign Affairs, especially for senior officers and chief accounting officers. Training is vital also for junior officers who handle accounts and who have no experience in managing staff who often are older and far more experienced than they are.

I turn to the matter of libraries, which is dealt with at page 37 of the report . It sets out the concern of the Auditor-General that film libraries, an integral part of the information function of the posts, are generally poorly maintained and controlled. Among the problems identified are obsolete and damaged films, poor and inadequate storage, and inaccurate and inadequate associated records. Obviously the prints are generally of poor quality and they wear quickly because of lack of skills by projectionists at the borrowing institutions. Not enough films have a sound track in the local language and the subjects of those films are in the area of either animals or sport, or are insufficiently interesting for local audiences. The entire information effort of this Government at overseas posts is most unsatisfactory. That came out clearly in the report of the Auditor-General. Examples of that are: No funds are available for publications for general distribution; very few publications are printed in the local language; and there is almost no co-ordination between the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Trade and Resources, which runs its own publication efforts, and the Australian Information Service. The Australian Information Service is inefficient and ineffective in this regard. It should be either upgraded to make a serious effort or abolished completely. Films and books which are provided at this stage are used infrequently and post libraries are inadequate.

In summary, the Foreign Affairs posts should be administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs. Trade posts also should be controlled by the Department of Foreign Affairs. Administrative officers should be trained in Australian Government accounting procedures and should be trained to handle special problems encountered overseas. They should be trained in staff management and should be taught the local language to a competent level-at least in the written form-so that accounts can be checked. Posts should be allowed flexibility. The move is away from imprest posts to accounting posts controlled by the Department of Finance. As a result, accounting posts will have more highly classified staff and will need to travel frequently to resolve problems. Better quality local staff members need to be employed and they need to be closely supervised. Chief accounting officers need training in financial management. At this stage few, if any, of the present heads of missions are competent in this field. The film libraries are poor. They are old and most of them are unsuitable. The Government 's information effort needs a complete overhaul.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussions of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussions of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The alarming deterioration of the economy due to the Fraser Government's economic policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last week or so the media has trumpeted the message that the economy is in an appalling state, that we are headed for a severe deepening of recession-if not depression-and that government policy has to change. I am sure that honourable members have noticed this media reportage, but I quickly remind the House of the kinds of headlines we have seen. In the last week we have seen headlines like this:

SPEECH.PARA: Recession: It's here and serious.
Resources boom euphoria fades.
Unemployment surges back as a political issue.
Housing downturn set to continue.
Business talks of gloom.
Interest rates to rise again.
$2700m wiped off projects.
That referred to resource development. Another headline read:
ANZ overdraft rate hits 17.25pc.
Nation goes into the red-Interest rates soar as credit squeeze bites.
Two statements of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) were also reported. The headlines read:
Howard: I'll come clean on the economy.
Hard times ahead but keep smiling says Howard.

The Treasurer might think this is a time to be smiling and a time for honesty. Indeed, we welcome that. We would like him to come into the house and tell us exactly how he sees the state of the economy. I hope he intends to take part in this debate and to do exactly that: To come clean with the House, to tell us what sort of mess he has got this country into and how far it is likely to go into recession before he sees an end to this process, which clearly is one of enormous severity indeed.

Apart from those kinds of reactions by the Treasurer which I have mentioned the Government's reaction has been to acknowledge that there are problems but to condemn the media for being alarmist and for talking down the economy. In fact, it is anything but alarmist reporting. The position is indeed very serious-we as an opposition have been warning for months that this is the case-and will become much worse unless current policies are changed. Talking down the economy was not something which seemed to concern the Treasurer or his colleagues when their parties were in opposition. They seemed to think that to talk about the adverse state of the economy was the best possible thing to do at the time. I also ask the Treasurer what he wants the media and the Opposition to do. Does he want us to say that everything is good when quite clearly everything is going down the chute?

The fact is that the headlines were right and they were backed by substantive analysis. A quick look at the economy demonstrates clearly the failure of the Government's budgetary policy and the slide into deep recession. Let us look at a few major indicators. I turn firstly to employment. The Budget forecast at the beginning of this financial year was for a growth of 2 per cent in the level of employment this financial year. Over the last 12 months the level of employment has grown 1.2 per cent. In fact, since September last year, in seasonally adjusted terms, there has been no growth at all. I turn now to unemployment. The Budget forecast was for a slight rise in actual numbers and a decline as a percentage of the work force in the course of this financial year. In fact, in seasonally adjusted terms, the level of unemployment has increased since June last year. It is now 50 per cent above the level of last year and the rate of 6. 7 per cent for March is almost 50 per cent above-half as much again-the level it was when Labor went out of office in 1975.

In respect of inflation, the Budget forecast was for a rise of 10 3/4 per cent. It is currently 11.3 per cent; in other words, another half per cent higher, and likely to remain so for the rest of this year. Real business investment has been the major engine of growth in the last couple of years-not because of any actions by the present Government but because of the fortuituous event of the second oil shock, which made our energy resources so much more desirable for exploitation and generated the big increase in investment. Real business investment increased by 21 per cent in 1980-81. The forecast increase for this year is 10 per cent to 15 per cent, and it is likely to be in that range, but for next year the indications are that we shall be lucky if the real increase is more than 5 per cent, and it may well be less than that-and this in the area in which growth has been mainly generated.

In respect of consumer expenditure, the other growth area, the Budget forecast was that it would rise by more than 3.2 per cent, but recent indications from retail sales figures and motor vehicle registrations, which have both slumped, are that there is likely to be a much smaller increase in consumer expenditure. Indeed, retailers throughout the country are saying that the position is appalling. They are questioning the Government's figures on retail sales and saying that the position is much worse than the official figures tend to be indicating. The Budget forecast was for expenditure on new housing to decline slightly, but it will substantially fall because of the severe fall in commencements in the December quarter and, since then, the even more alarming drop in housing approvals.

The balance of payments current account deficit has increased. It is much worse than was expected in the Budget, where some increase was talked about. The balance of trade deficit, as at March, was nine times greater than it was at the same time last year. The balance of payments current account deficit is likely to be about $9,000m, as compared with a little over $6,000m last year. Real gross domestic product growth was forecast to be in the range of 3 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent. Because of all the factors that I have been discussing it is highly unlikely to reach those levels. We can expect rather more reduced levels of growth than were in the Budget forecast.

Finally, with respect to the Budget outcome, the government forecast a Budget deficit of only $146m. In fact, as we have seen-although the Treasurer is reluctant to put a figure on it-there are all sorts of leaks indicating that the Budget deficit blowout is of the order of $1,000m, or even more, which indicates that the Government will fall far short of its deficit objective. So the economic and budgetary outcome this year will clearly be well below what the Government expected, and the outlook for next year is much worse because of the collapse of the bases of previous growth-that is, the rundown in business investment, the considerable fall in the rate of growth in consumer expenditure, and the decline in export growth.

What are the reasons for this deterioration? In the time available, one can only quickly indicate those. Let me, first, acknowledge that the world recession has a part in this. We do not deny, as the then Opposition did in 1974 and 1975, that world economic factors have an influence on what happens in Australia, and we accept the fact that the world recession must affect Australia adversely. We acknowledge that that is happening right now. The economies of most major countries are growing only slightly, if at all, and some, such as that of the United States, are actually declining. Total unemployment in the member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is now 28 million, and there is no sign of a recovery yet. The impact on Australia, on both the volume and the value of exports, which creates severe problems in the export industries and through the deteriorating balance of payments, affects the economy generally. But the world recession has in fact much to do with the fact that conservative governments throughout the world, particularly in major countries, most especially the United States, have been applying policies which are not dissimilar to those of this Government. They are basically monetarist policies of one sort or another, and those policies have been causing contraction in those countries and, therefore, greatly accentuating the world recession which was initiated by the second oil shock.

This fact that other countries are pursuing Fraser Government-type policies of monetarism is a terribly important factor in explaining why we have an intensified world recession. For the Government to say 'You cannot blame us for what is happening in the Australian economy because of the world recession', is both a grossly simplified and an absurd proposition to start with-although we acknowledge that it has some effect-but it must be borne in mind also that the reason why we have this world recession is that other governments have been following monetarist policies similar to those of this Government and therefore bringing about and intensifying the world recession, which may have taken a much lesser form without these kinds of policies.

The neo-conservative policies, as they are described-the policies of the Fraser Government, the Thatcher Government, the Reagan Government, the Muldoon Government, and so on-all have a similiar basis. They are based on the monetarist theory which has become popular over the last 10 years, and has become very unpopular over the last few years. That monetarist policy conforms well to conservative ideology-that is, to small government, deregulation, market determined outcomes, inequitable income transfers, lack of concern about unemployment, and so on. Those are the hallmarks of monetarism and conservative ideology. This policy, stripped of all its jargon, amounts to a policy of fighting inflation by increasing unemployment. The Government tries to stop inflation by increasing unemployment. If it requires more unemployment to stop inflation, that is what we get. Therefore, we have growing recession as almost a continuing feature of such policies, as we have seen ever since this Government took office.

The way in which it is done is by introducing contractionary budgetary and monetary policies. We have them both at present-contractionary budgetary policies and contractionary monetary policies which are forcing interest rates up to record levels. The Government provides no stimulus to the economy. Indeed, it reduces activity in its attempts to get inflation down. It then hopes that a non-inflationary recovery will occur. The impact on people of this kind of policy is very severe. Because of slow growth, it means that there is slow employment growth, or increasing unemployment, and an adverse effect on living standards through increased taxes, increased interest rates and reduced government expenditure.

These are the hallmarks of the impact of these kinds of policies not only in Australia, where they have been applied, but also in the other countries to which I have referred. Everywhere it has been the same in its general impact- although the detail varies from country to country. The failure to reduce inflation is also a marked feature of these kinds of policies. Despite the fact that they create deepening recession and higher and higher unemployment, they fail to stop inflation. Such policies have been extremely ineffective in stopping inflation. For instance, in Australia, in the last 12 months of the Labor Government inflation was running at 12 per cent. Now, with unemployment half as much again as a percentage of the work force, we have a much deeper recession and inflation at 11 1/2 per cent-in other words, hardly any improvement at all on the inflation front despite a much deeper recession. In the United Kingdom the same thing applies. There was inflation of 10 per cent when the Thatcher Government came to office. Despite a great increase in unemployment, inflation is now at 12 per cent. So these policies not only involve much deeper unemployment but they fail to fight inflation, which was their original intention.

These policies need more and more unemployment to reduce inflation. We had 3 per cent unemployment in Australia in 1961, and zero inflation following that. Now we have 6 1/2 per cent unemployment and 11 1/2 per cent inflation. That is the kind of problem which these kinds of policies produce. One needs more and more unemployment to keep inflation at any given level. That means that to get inflation down to the one per cent or 2 per cent now, how much unemployment would we need? Would we need 10 per cent, 12 per cent or 15 per cent? No one really nows-but it would be a hell of a lot more than the present level of 6 1/2 per cent, officially, and it makes these kinds of policies an absurdity. They fail to reduce inflation. It also means that this policy can never provide the basis of economic recovery; every time we get any sort of recovery, this Government will come in with policies to contract the economy because inflation will tend to blow out again. That is what is happening right now. We had a mini- recovery in 1980-81 and in 1981-82 for a little while, but now the Government says: 'We must stop all that because inflation is getting bigger again'. So the Government comes up with policies that create more recession and more inflation.

These kinds of policies must stop. They must stop in this country and in other countries as well. I am sure that, with the effluxion of not a great deal of time, all the Government's pursuing these kinds of policies will be rolled, because the people of those countries and of this country will not tolerate the continuance of such outlandish policies, policies which are so crude and which involve the bludgeoning down of inflation by umemployment and having to use the bigger and bigger bludgeon of unemployment to keep inflation only at levels which are tolerable but still high. Those policies will not be tolerated by the people in future, in this country or any other.

What we need, in this country and others, and what we will get, are policies which are advocated by the Labor Party in this country and by social democratic parties elsewhere-that is, policies which reject the concept of using unemployment as the basis of inflation control, and which say that what we must have are more direct measures to control inflation. In particular, we must have prices and incomes policies to control inflation and a rejection of the crudity of the monetarism which has blighted this country and the rest of the world for the last several years. They are the kinds of policies we need. Prices and incomes policies have been pursued by some countries. Despite all the difficulties of the last decade or so some countries, such as Austria, Sweden and a few other countries in Western Europe, through the use of prices and incomes policies, have been able to keep unemployment at very low levels and inflation generally at lower levels than have applied in the countries pursuing monetarist policies. So on both accounts-unemployment and inflation, and rates of economic growth-they have performed much better than countries which have relied on the monetarist approach.

I am sure that increasingly people around the world will see that those are the policies to pursue. Those are the policies that the Opposition will be propounding. Opposition members support fully the idea of discarding unemployment as the means of inflation control but we reassert what we have always said-that inflation control is important but that it must be done by other means. Those other means are prices and incomes policies. If we have effective prices and incomes policies we can have stimulatory policies which will enable a non-inflationary recovery to occur. We cannot get a non- inflationary recovery with monetarist policies because every time recovery occurs, inflation blows out and has to be stopped by the introduction of more contractionary policies. We are then pushed further into the recessionary vortex into which we are rapidly being pushed at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In introducing this matter of public importance the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has revived that old chestnut of the Australian Labor Party; that is, the link between inflation and unemployment. The only mistake that the honourable member for Gellibrand made was that he got the linkage the wrong way round. The Government has never denied that inflation and unemployment have to be looked at together, but it has constantly asserted that there is no such thing as a trade-off between inflation and unemployment . Just as we strenuously deny-we have done so in the past, we do it now and we will deny it in the future-that this Government has ever used unemployment as a method of purchasing reductions in inflation, we assert with equal strength that more inflation simply will lead to more unemployment. We are not alone in asserting that because, as the honourable member for Gellibrand well knows, that was a proposition which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden ) embraced when he was Treasurer for a short time, during the Labor Government. He embraced it in almost these words: We no longer live in a simple world where we can do this and that, because more inflation leads to more unemployment. It is no accident that the unemployment situation in Australia has been better during times of lower inflation. For the honourable member for Gellibrand to suggest that in some way we are deliberately using the bludgeon, as he calls it, of unemployment to bring down the rate of inflation is to misrepresent totally the Government's position and it is a charge which I and the Government totally reject.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gellibrand has indulged the approach of many other people at present of talking down the economy. He is entitled to do that. He is the economic spokesman for the Opposition and it suits the political purpose of the Opposition to paint the gloomiest possible picture of the Australian economy at present. Of course he will go his hardest to do that. I have not at any time over the last few months, when it has become apparent that economic circumstances in Australia would not be as good as we thought they might be at the time we brought down the Budget, run away from that proposition, nor has the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and nor has or will any member of the Government. As I indicated last week, now more than ever the public has to be taken into the Government's confidence, has to be informed and has to be fully advised as to our assessment of the state of the economy. We have to recognise that circumstances are less rosy than they were at the time of the Budget. They are less rosy not only than the Government thought but also than the Opposition thought at that time. If the honourable member for Gellibrand is honest with himself he will recall complaining in this House last year about how much money was coming into Australia. He said we would have to do something to stop it, that we would have to turn it around and send it out again or introduce capital controls to stop it coming in. In other words, he was complaining about how attractive this country was as a place for people to invest. We should not let the honourable member for Gellibrand run away with the proposition that only we on this side of the House were talking about strong economic conditions in the middle of last year. He knows darned well that he shared similar views.

I ask the House and those who are interested-I accept that the bulk of the members of the Labor Party are as interested in the state of the Australian economy as we are-to keep a sense of balance and a sense of proportion about the real state of the economy. Of course growth will not be strong. For the information of the honourable member for Gellibrand, my latest advice is that non-farm gross domestic product will grow by about 2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent instead of over 3 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—'Disgraceful', the honourable member for Burke said. That is absolutely marvellous! It happens to be still about a per cent or a per cent and a half above the average of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, so if our performance is disgraceful I would like to know his description of some of those marvellous social democracies of western Europe that his colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand has said are the models that all of us should follow. The fact is that economic growth, even at that lower level, in Australia this financial year will be way above the average of the OECD. We should not let anybody run away with any other impression. Of course economic growth will be less and business investment will be less. But let us get a sense of proportion about that. In the December quarter of 1981-the quarter before last-new fixed capital expenditure was estimated to be 35.6 per cent higher than in the December quarter of 1980. That is some downturn, some recession! It is 35.6 per cent higher than it was in December 1980. It is well within the Budget forecast of a 10 to 15 per cent increase in real terms. Although investment is levelling out, it is still running at about three times the real level of three years ago; that is, 1977-78. I repeat: It is still three times what it was in 1977-78. Of course everybody knows that, despite the revisions, expenditure on mineral exploration is way ahead of what it was in the early 1970s.

SPEECH.PARA: I do ask that in properly assessing and revising expectations about the current and future performance of the Australian economy we preserve a sense of balance. We recognise first and foremost that we live in a world of interdependent economies. No government can hope to insulate this country, or any other country , from the effects of world-wide economic downturn and recession. We will all be affected by it. We are not impotent in the face of what happens abroad but we are affected by it. What we do here with our domestic economic policies has an effect on the degree of damage to this country of economic downturn abroad. We cannot stop the damage but we can reduce it or we can aggravate it. The central question we have to ask ourselves is: What is the right policy? What policies will reduce damage from abroad and, alternatively, what policies will aggravate damage from abroad? We have to ask ourselves what the causes of economic downturn and economic stagnation abroad are and we have to ask ourselves whether the policies that we are following at present are the appropriate ones.

The Labor Party would have us believe that, overnight, interest rates can be brought down. The honourable member for Gellibrand and the Leader of the Opposition say that we have to control, or regulate, all these interest rates and that is how the problem will be solved. I would like the honourable member for Gellibrand to explain to the Australian people what would have happened if interest rates in Australia had been artificially held down over the last few months. What would have happened to our external account, in the face of the present level of interest rates in the United States? Does he seriously believe that any corporate treasurer worth his salt would not have followed those high interest rates abroad? Does he believe that anything other than very serious difficulty would have befallen Australia's balance of payments if we had tried to maintain an interest rate structure that was markedly out of line with what has been operating abroad, or is operating abroad at present? Yet that is the practical consequence of the alternative economic policy advocated by the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on.

—The honourable member for Gellibrand says 'come on' but I remind him and through him the Leader of the Opposition that month after month they have gone around Australia saying that the policies of this Government have deliberately forced interest rates up. They have gone around saying that if we had a Labor government interest rates in Australia could be much lower but they do not tell us how they could be kept down without the consequences that I have described. Are they seriously arguing that, with a prime interest rate in the United States of 17 per cent or more, it is possible for any government to ensure that prime interest rates in Australia will be 3 per cent, 4 per cent or 5 per cent less than they are in the United States? That is the practical effect of what the honourable member for Gellibrand and the Leader of the Opposition are suggesting. They cannot have it both ways. They cannot represent to the Australian people that if they were in government interest rates would be lower, yet deny, as the honourable member for Gellibrand is now doing, the practical consequences of applying their policies. They know well-as indeed a Labor government in Australia has found out over the last couple of weeks-that the realities of office and of the marketplace cannot be ignored. Mr Cathie, the Minister for Housing in the honourable member for Gellibrand's own State of Victoria, made a remarkable discovery the other day. He said: 'We have to let the building societies put up their interest rates because if they do not get the money in first they cannot lend it out.' Of course, Mr Cathie has made the blindingly obvious discovery that, in an environment of high interest rates, if lending institutions are to be able to lend money they have to be able to borrow it from the investing public in the first place. That is a proposition that the Australian Government has argued for some time. It is one that it suits the political convenience of the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Gellibrand to ignore, but it cannot be ignored by those who have the responsibility to make decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the next few months the task of economic management in Australia will probably be more difficult than it has been at any time over the past few years. What this country has to do, above everything else, is strive to regain the international economic competitiveness that it had a couple of years ago but which, because of adverse developments on the wages and prices fronts, it has started to lose. It is a responsibility that everybody, in all sections of the community, will have to share. The fact is, of course, that a couple of years ago the level of inflation in this country was below the average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. As the honourable member for Gellibrand will know, the truth is that now it is above that average. What we have to do above everything else is work to apply policies that will bring the level of inflation back to a competitive position vis-a-vis that of our trading partners. In doing so, we must apply policies that have an anti-inflationary bite, not apply the sort of high deficit, loose monetary and fiscal policies that have been advocated, in the name of providing a mild stimulus, by the honourable member for Gellibrand. When members of the Labor Party talk about adopting a mildly expansionary Budget approach, when they talk about providing a mild stimulus, what they are really talking about is going back to their habit of running very large deficits. I might say that, in the view of most economic commentators, that state of affairs has been the cause of the high interest rates in the United States. I find it absolutely fascinating that the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Gellibrand should be saying that what is wrong with the present Government is that its budgetary policies are too closely aligned with those of the American administration when, in regard to economic emphasis, we depart from that administration in thinking that its Budget deficit is too high. That is the very policy approach that, if given the opportunity, the honourable member for Gellibrand and his colleagues would implement. They would run a high deficit. They believe in high deficits yet high deficits, more than anything else, have produced the interest rate situation that prevails in the United States. Any analysis of the interest rate structure of that country and its impact upon Australia would bring home to all of us the importance of the level of the United States deficit.

What has disturbed the Government over the past few months-it ought to be a concern of everybody in this House-is the extent to which our competitiveness has been eroded by adverse developments on the inflation and wages fronts. It is no accident that those countries, such as Japan, West Germany and the United States, that are more competitive are those that have succeeded in holding wage increases at or below their level of inflation. In Japan last year the rate of inflation to February was 3.1 per cent. Unit labour costs rose by 3 per cent. In West Germany the rate of inflation was 5.8 per cent. Wage increases were at about the same level. In the United States the consumer price index in the year to February rose about 7.7 per cent and average earnings rose about 5.6 per cent to 6 per cent. A very clear picture emerges that those countries have been more successful in holding their wage levels and, as a consequence, their competitiveness has improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Questions concerning the economic policies that are being adopted in Australia have long since ceased to be questions which impinge only on the immediate situation. Increasingly they are becoming serious questions about the whole nature and direction of economic growth in this country. One could almost be forgiven for believing that the chief advisers to the Government are deliberately setting about sabotaging any possible national recovery, and the future of Australia generally. If they had determined to do that it would be most unlikely that they would have chosen significantly different policies. I think that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) really would be well advised to seek independent advice.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation at present in Australia is that right across the nation industry groups, companies, research organisations and academics are calling for a change of direction in the Government's present economic policies. Yet those calls-of increasing volume-are falling on deaf ears. It appears that the Treasurer and the Secretary to the Treasury are closeted in a situation in which they do not hear those increasing expressions of concern. At one time those concerns were being expressed by increasing numbers of unemployed. At one time they were being expressed by young couples who were being forced out of their homes. The Treasurer, honourable members will remember, referred to them as 'young families trading down'-selling expensive homes and buying cheaper ones. Young families were being forced out of their homes. Farmers were finding it increasingly difficult to meet their interest rate commitments. Families were concerned about the future of their children. Of course, the Australian Labor Party has been consistent in its expressions of concern and consistent in the alternatives that it has been proposing.

I am not suggesting that the Treasurer should listen to the Labor Party. I am not suggesting, because I do not believe he would, that he listen to the cries from the unemployed, from the families or all of the three million people in Australia who are living below the poverty line. But I seriously suggest to the Treasurer that he listen to some independent advice from those interests in the Australian community which inceasingly ask the Government to change its direction, to follow the changes that are being made by Treasuries in other parts of the world. I have already referred, on another occasion, to the changes that have taken place in Britain. For the first time, unemployment there has started to drop because Britain has now repudiated the monetarist approach that it has been taking. It is not good enough for the Treasurer to come into this House, or to go out into the community, and continue to repeat things which are simply not correct. He said that the honourable member for Gellibrand was incorrect in his assertion about the Government's historically record high level of interest rates in comparison with other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are not.

—The Treasurer suggested that interest rates in Australia were lower than the rates in comparable countries. If he did not say that, I am sorry ; if I have misunderstood him so have 15 million other people in Australia. The reality is, as the Treasurer knows or should know, that at present real interest rates in Australia, that is, nominal interest rates less the level of inflation, are the highest in the world.
—No, they are not. Do you know what the rate of inflation in the United States is?

—The Treasurer shakes his head. The level of real interest rates in Australia is the highest in the world. Let me give the House some of the interest rates which is fact apply at present and particularly in comparison with situation in the United States. On 15 April interest rates in the United States on 90-day commercial bills were 14.2 per cent. In Australia on 19 April the interest rates were 22.3 per cent. On 180-day commercial bills the interest rates in the United States were 13.7 per cent and in Australia they were 21.3 per cent. The latest interest rate in the United States on 90-day treasury notes or bills is 12.8 per cent and in Australia the yield is indicating an interest rate of 20 per cent. Overnight funds-the Treasurer referred to them-were earning interest rates of 25 per cent in Australia; I repeat, 25 per cent on overnight funds! We know that the rates on 60-day and 90-day bank bills have been hovering around the 20 per cent mark. In comparison with the rate in the United States our interest rate is significantly higher.
—That is more than you can make on smuggling television sets.

—Indeed, and that creates a pretty good margin, as the honourable member for Robertson has indicated. I have indicated on previous occasions that the strategy that this Government was adopting was such that the target for economic growth in Australia during this current year could not and would not be achieved. I said that right from the start, from the time the Budget itself was adopted. The figures that the Treasurer gave at that time should have given him no cause for surprise to learn that the growth rate target of 3 per cent to 3.5 per cent would not be achieved. He has now indicated that for this current year it will be between 2 per cent and 2 1/2 per cent. I have indicated that for the following financical year it will be less than 1.5 per cent. The Treasurer knows as well as I do that if we just wanted to hold the unemployment level at the present rate we would need to achieve a growth rate in excess of 3.5 per cent. He knows that we are not going to achieve it. Unemployment in Australia, as I have said on previous occasions, will grow towards 10 per cent. In 1961 the then government almost lost office as a result of unemployment in Australia approaching 3 per cent. It is now 7 per cent and approaching 10 per cent. It is my hope that the Australian people will have sufficient conscience, sufficient concern and sufficient compassion for their fellows to react in the same way but to a greater extent than they did in 1961.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer indicated that many of our economic problems were overseas induced. We on the Opposition side are prepared to accept the proposition that the international economic situation is not as good as it could be. But it simply is not correct to say, and we are not going to allow it to be said, that Australia is incapable of marshalling its own affairs and determining its own direction to the extent that we have to be dragged along by developments overseas because that is not what has been happening anyway. In respect of those adverse developments overseas, we have been finding ourselves to be way out in front. I would like to draw attention to a statement made seven years ago by the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). What a remarkable transformation there has been in the attitude of this Government. We are not going to let this Government get away with it. This is what the Prime Minister, seven years ago, said:
I do not believe that men and women are governed by inexorable events beyond their control.

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, that it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership, when, if they were men of real stature, they would be saying, 'we can overcome.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said seven years ago by the present Prime Minister; and what do we hear him saying now? He is saying that Australia cannot get itself out of the mire because we are being dragged along by events overseas. The present high level of interest rates is caused deliberately by this Government, and the Treasurer knows it. He knows that the money supply policy in Australia is such as to create an extremely tight domestic liquidity position. Higher interest rates have been deliberately engineered by this Government. It is part of the Government's policy to attract the funds from overseas that it needs to get itself out of the balance of payments problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer and the Treasury are like boys playing around with little machines. They are pulling levers, they are stretching wires and they are sticking springs into the system just to see which way it jumps. They are trying to mesh these things together. It is becoming increasingly difficult for them. I do not believe the Government or the Treasurer's advisers at present sufficiently realise exactly what has been happening. In March 1982 unemployment was 460,000. Since March 1981 it has grown from 409,000 which represents an increase of almost 5,000 additional unemployed every month. Since this Government has been in office unemployment has grown by 1,000 every month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the case presented this afternoon by the Opposition I cannot help but be profoundly depressed because what the Opposition supporters have presented is nothing more than a subterfuge for an economic policy. It is very easy for members like the last speaker, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), to stand up and cite figures. If he wants to refer to unemployment may I refer him to the figures which existed when the last Labor Government of this Commonwealth was in office. At that time the level of unemployment in Australia reached a record which had not been compared since the Great Depression.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supporters must imagine that the people of Australia are stupid enough to accept yet again a re-run of the gloom and doom that came to Australia during the period 1972 to 1975. The memories of the Australian people are not so short that they are prepared to accept a re-run of a policy which has been demonstrated to be fundamentally imperfect.

Opposition supporters come into this House and talk up gloom and depression and then they wonder why they have become prophets of their own results. The simple reality is that in any country, confidence is a fragile thing. No responsible party when speaking to the Australian people should continue to attack a government whose economic policies under present circumstances represent the only route that it can take, unless they can offer a prescription which will work. They know that thesis will not.

Let us examine the details of the so-called Labor alternative policy. Labor says: 'We are going to solve all our problems. We are going to cut unemployment. We are going to be able to reduce interest rates.' All this will be done through the glorious seed from the tree of deficit financing. Let us be quite frank about this. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) speaking in Brisbane at an economics conference in June 1978-and I have not heard him change his tune on this particular record-simply said: 'If Labor does not gain office this year, by 1983, when we could next hope to gain office, we would face a mammoth task of rebuilding the public sector and maybe an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.'

We have heard nothing today about high taxes. We have heard nothing from any of the spokesmen on the Opposition side which suggests that they, through their glorious polices, will be able to give the Australian people everything for free and not come back and demand higher taxation. But it is on the record. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand, has made the position quite clear: His policy is for higher taxes in Australia. At least he is honest on this point. If we want to give more goods and services to the Australian people and have a bigger public sector somebody has to be prepared to pay for it . We cannot simply go on the principle of deficit financing indefinitely. Just as an individual cannot go to his bank manager year after year and ask for more money, to have a larger demand on the services of the bank, the same applies to a nation such as Australia. We have to reach the stage where we can live within our means. Much of the problem that we face today came about because during the period of the Whitlam Administration Australia did not live within its means. The deficit in Australia during that period reached a record level. Year by year since then the situation has slowly improved to where we are now in a position to say to the Australian people that the hard years of the past were worth while .

This country is one of the few in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which is at least able to live on the basis of its own capacity to produce. But we are told by the Opposition that we have to have a situation where the demands of the labour force are to be met at all costs. We recall what happened during those difficult years when increases in wages across the board were over 20 per cent in one year. Yet we were told that somehow or other there is no connection between high inflation and wage demands. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) told us this afternoon, the reality is that Australia's capacity to develop its society in a modern world fundamentally depends on our capacity to trade. If we cannot maintain a comparative cost advantage in those areas where we have a capacity to compete with the rest of the world we have no future as a nation. I cannot say that more strongly to the people of Australia. They will remember this. They will recall that fact. But unfortunately the erstwhile alternative government opposite seeks to imagine that it can live and that the people of Australia can live in some clouded cuckoo land indefinitely ignoring that simple reality.

Wage inflation is one of the prime causes of the realities of the economic situation that we now face. Average weekly earnings for all male employees rose by 5.8 per cent between the September and December quarters of 1981. They are the most recent statistics available. That reflects an obviously very large rise in earnings and brings the recorded annual rate of increase to 14.5 per cent. The important point about that figure is that it is well above the rate of inflation. As the Treasurer so rightly pointed out, if one compares the record of the Australian economy with our major trading partners such as West Germany or Japan one will see that both of those countries have been able to hold down their basic level of inflation because the demands within their economies for higher wages have also been restrained. That is not what we have seen in Australia.

While we live with the realities of a limited legal power base in the Federal sector, the fact of the matter is that the Australian work force, to a large degree egged on by members of the Opposition-expecting people to believe that they can get twice this year what they received last year regardless of who has to pay for it-has now reached the fundamental situation where today's wage rises will be somebody else's job tomorrow. If we are trying to build a country based on something a little more fundamental than the simple concept of 'I'm all right , Jack', let us get back to that simple Australian virtue of mateship. This nation was built on the belief that if we pull together as a people, if we hold our course and have a quite clear objective before us, this nation need fear nothing. While we proceed on the basis that we can divide the community and that workers and management can argue over every single possible source of friction there is no way that the opportunities facing Australians will be met.

Today we have been debating the Opposition's matter of public importance: 'The alarming deterioration of the economy due to the Fraser Government's economic policies'. As I said initially, the policies put forward by this Government are an adequate mix of fiscal and monetary policies directed at the realities of the situation. Today inflation still represents to this Government and to the people of Australia the greatest problem which we must overcome. Plenty of countries in the world-I refer to the comment of the honourable member for Hunter, the last Opposition speaker-have changed their policies. In all fairness to him, Great Britain was not one of them. The reason Great Britain has improved the basis of its unemployment situation is that after some three or four very difficult years of cutting away the fat and trying to restore an economically viable community on an industrial base which is able to compete, it is now in a position to seek an increase in productivity. It is the increase in productivity which is at the essence of economic growth. That is a lesson which the Opposition, when it sat on this side of the House, failed to learn. Quite obviously it is a lesson which the honourable member for Gellibrand and all his colleagues opposite continue to despise and ignore. If the economic success of countries such as West Germany and Japan is considered, it is clear that when the economy is based on high productivity a country is then in a better position to make the goods and services which are needed and the people require.

If we persist with a low relative level of productivity-let us make no mistake about it; during the 1970s the rate of productivity in Australia was by no international yardstick satisfactory-there is no possible way that this economy will develop. It will not do so until we get back to the fundamental requirements of restraining demands, particularly in terms of wages and salaries , in such a way that jobs can be created and more people can be employed. It does not need an economic genius to work out the reality that if an employer finds himself facing not only basic wage increases but also a possible on-cost increase of at least 25 per cent per unit of employment-that is what we are looking at now for employer-he must go for modern technology, change his market profile or sack or reduce his labour force. There is only one other alternative- he can go out of business. That is not what the Australian Government is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is now concluded.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anthony,Mr Armitage,Mr Beazley and Mr Bourchier.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other business expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lionel Bowen,Mr Cunningham,Mr Les Johnson and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHILD; DARLING; HURFORD; KERIN; THEOPHANOUS; WEST
PETITION.NAMEIDS: HF4; UD4; AV4; QH4; QJ4; XJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mrs Darling,Mr Hurford,Mr Kerin,Dr Theophanous and Mr West.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned young citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That there is an urgent need to take steps to terminate the inhumane, random slaughter of fur seals in Canada, in order to prevent their eventual extinction.
Your petitioners urge that action be taken to:
(a) inform the Government of Canada of our opposition to the annual slaughter of young fur seals as currently practised in that country;
(b) actively discourage any form of trading that involves goods or products derived (either wholly or partially) from the pelts of baby fur seals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, maritial status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference.

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons of the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of Commonwealth accommodation and goods and services and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Sinclair and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide fully paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Cass and Mr Cross.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation, and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power exist in Australia on particular grounds including inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction, in the provision of accommodation, and the provision of goods and services; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Tambling and Mr Uren.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawke,Mrs Kelly,Mr Morris and Mr O'Keefe.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Planning Association of Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing effectiveness of the Family Planning Association of Victoria.
In particular that:
Federal Government continue to provide funding to the Family Planning Association of Victoria for clinical services to meet the growing demands of the community.
Increased funding be provided to the Family Planning Association of Victoria's Training, Education and Research Unit for educational services to the community.
All funding be provided on a triennial basis to enable cost-effective long term planning.
The Federal Government grant the Family Planning Association of Victoria exemption from sales tax and allow donations to be tax deductible.

That we, the undersigned, support the expansion of family planning services to ensure that adequate contraceptive information is fully available to all sections of the community, with special consideration given to disadvantaged groups.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bourchier,Mr Fisher and Mr Scholes.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anthony and Mr West.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia do humbly pray that the Government will:

Do all within your power to influence the Canadian Prime Minister and Government to end the senseless annual slaughter of harp and hooded seals. We can see no reason for allowing this inhumane and unnecessary brutality to continue. The world's irreplaceable wildlife must be permitted to exist without exploitation from Man.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
Is it Necessary

A seal is an animal which deserves a chance to live. The annual kill is a brutal destruction of an innocent animal. We call on the Australian Government to oppose this unnecessary slaughter, and to let the Canadian Government know how the Australian people feel.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for children's services be spent in full for the purposes designated.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lionel Bowen and Mr O'Keefe.

PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Their support for and endorsement of the National Women's Advisory Council.
We call on the Government to continue to maintain the National Women's Advisory Council and increase Federal Government support for its activities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for cost of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non-residential area of Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aids for Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the PADP (Program of Aids for Disabled People) Scheme, while in theory an excellent initiative, is not at present funded to an adequate level to provide all the aids listed. This will result in a substantial shortfall which will restrict the ability of the States to fully implement the scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will increase the funding for the PADP Scheme to enable its total implementation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is a lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on Plant Variety Rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax payer and
6. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure:
(i) that information be made freely available to allow full and informed public discussion of the issues involved.
(ii) that the Government undertake to carry out an analysis of the costs and benefits involved to the various sectors of Agriculture and the Nation as a whole.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
