That in the light of the proposed alterations to the Sales Tax Regulations which will cause schools, P & C Associations, Government Departments, Councils, Sporting Associations etc., to pay the total amount for goods and then apply to the Australian Taxation Office for Sales Tax rebate instead of as at present providing a Sales Tax exempt form to wholesalers and retailers.

We believe such organisations will have to find extra funds to cover Sales Tax then be involved in excess bookkeeping and administration to retrieve the sales tax and finally wait on the return of these funds and that it will cause great difficulty for these groups.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Parliament will, reject these alterations to Sales Tax Regulations and maintain the present system where such organisations are exempted from paying sales tax by providing a sales tax exempt form.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia.
and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N .H.S and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Arukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty years lease they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests.

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1976 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Arukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hearing Aids: Import Duty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned individuals concerned with the welfare of the hearing impaired citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there are approximately one million people in Australia who suffer severe problems with their hearing.

That the greatest percentage of adults with hearing impairment are not eligible for N.A.L. aids. (1978 Australian Bureau of Statistics. 38.79 per cent of hearing impaired are aged between 45-64 years).
That the accepted useful life of a hearing aid is only 3-5 years.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House reject all recommendations that may subject hearing aids to any import duty (I.A.C. propose 15 per cent) and thus ensure hearing handicapped persons be not further disadvantaged.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marine Mammal By-products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale by-products, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammel by-products, including the Harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state and quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the Petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and (b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Governmnt to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States, there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the number of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purposes; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories; and
(c) that in the absence of uniform Legislation between States, the Commonwealth introduce Legislation to enable the enforcement of humane and responsible conduct for researchers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Railway Services in South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. We, the undersigned, humbly petition and strongly voice our dissatisfaction with proposals to withdraw services and or charge for services in respect to those north and north-western railway lines which serve railway employees, pastoral residents and others. This service is commonly known as the Tea and Sugar Train and we humbly pray that the existing provisions be examined with a view to sustaining services and costs as existed prior to your notification that changes would be made.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over the proposed flooding of the Franklin River valley in Tasmania if the river is used for further hydro- electric schemes.

Your petitioners, aware that the area is on the National Register, wish to emphasise that this should not be taken lightly. The unique character of the area as a temperate rain-forest, incorporates many individual features which are only beginning to become known. Not the least of these is the recent find of anthropological and other scientific relics in a previously undiscovered cave in the Franklin valley. This find alone intimates potential contribution to mankind 's knowledge which transcends progress that further hydro-electricity may promise when this very electricity can be generated by other means. Another priceless feature of the valley is its splendid Huon pine whose ages (some up to and over 2,000 years), quality and scarcity make it a species to be husbanded with care and respect, not drowned indiscriminately and uselessly as in another Tasmanian hydro-electric scheme.

Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament considers the issues involved in the destruction of the Wilderness areas to be of concern to all Australians and even other further afield, and that Parliament denies access to funds required by the Tasmanian government for building dams in the South Western Tasmanian Wilderness area and Franklin River in particular.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament Assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services programme is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important programme.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that moneys be made available to subsidize child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programmes and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all an that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.
2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasma,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 5 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal parliament.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Registration Fee for Periodicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, respectfully ask that the Australian Government request Australia Post to review the recently introduced annual registration fee for periodicals.

With many periodicals produced for distribution to members in small numbers only, this new impost, together with the recent increases in postage rates, considerably adds to the administrative costs of small clubs and organisers, whose activities are non profit, and are directly involved in community activities.
Accordingly, we earnestly request this review, with a view to small clubs and organisations, at least, being exempted from the requirements of annual registration.
We thank you in anticipation of your support.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ensure that the Government takes immediate action to restore the lost value of Family Allowances and to index them to cover future price rises.
Help single-income families by increasing the dependent spouse rebate to $1,392 .
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Bendigo respectfully showeth that in respect-
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) The one million household and business Liquified Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so that the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982-83 financial year.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the right honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Indi respectfully showeth that in respect-
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) the one million household and business Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982/3 financial year.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the right honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Casey respectfully showeth that in respect-
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) the one million household and business Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982/83 financial year.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the right honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Gippsland respectfully showeth that in respect-
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) the one million household and business Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982/3 financial year.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the right honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petititon of the undersigned electors of the Division of Barker respectfully showeth that in respect of-
(1) the current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) the one million household and business Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians connected to natural gas (primarily located in capital cities) and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982/83 financial year.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth-
that the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
the Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,
Queensland has suffered a 15% disadvantage over other states during the past ten years in road funding,
and the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth: that the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian Immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the inhumane slaughter of baby harp seals off the coasts of Newfoundland and in particular, the Gulf of St Lawrence and the Magdelen Islands.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to halt all imports of seal products.
2. That we can be assured that the murdering of harp seals be discontinued in all forms at the real and perilous threat of extinction of yet another artic animal species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government take heed of their petitioners' protest, and give seals the right to life.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the right honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the exportation of live animals for slaughter to overseas.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to ban the export of live animals for slaughter overseas.
2. That the export of live horses to Japan for slaughter for human consumption be banned on the grounds that it is cruel and unnecessary.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon M.P.

1. That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

2. That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent and that at the 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

3. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in Victoria who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: I, Dr Paul Robert Neuman, Leader and Lord of Knights of the Order of the White Cross International, a humanitarian knighthood for the Defence and Protection of Life, jointly with officers and members of the Order and with citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia by this our humble petition respectfully showeth:

That I, jointly with and on behalf of the undersigned petitioners voice our concern and objection about the proposed legislation of the so-called Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 and that I claim, according to the nature and principles of my organisation, to have a mandate to defend the silent Millions of Life-Forms, which are unable to defend themselves and are not represented otherwise in this Honourable House in order to protect their fate and future and also on behalf of the majority of people, who are not or very little informed about the consequences of this Bill and whose freedom and wellbeing is at stake, should this Bill become Law in Australia.

Since time immemorial, life has dominated Earth and has formed in the course of evolution a Web of Life, composed of animals and plants, which are depending on each other and are adjusted to each other within their Eco-system. Man, as part of nature and being bound to the laws of nature, must suffer the consequences if this nature is brought out of balance. The new life-forms, this Bill will allow to enter Australia, are tailor-made creations of genetic engineers, aliens and monsters to our eco-systems, but fit to open an entirely new marketing opportunity for food and chemicals. Scientific achievement or not, the Gene- manipulators play a wicked Lego-game for international finance and the chemical industry. I hold, that the natural species in Australia or elsewhere in the world have not even the slightest chance to compete with the invaders from man's laboratories, since the new creations are invested with the power of money, using man's abilities, man's laws and man's chemicals to clear the way for gene- manipulated commercial mono-cultures, designed and controlled by those who hold the Patent Rights over these plants.

It requires no imagination to realize that all power for dominance over people is contained by those who control the food. Indeed, control over all beings bound to eat and over farmers and horticulturists as to what to grow, how to grow and with which kind of chemical to treat. It also means control over licenced breeders of the new varieties, who may be directed to refuse supply to certain growers as the patent owners may feel fit. Beneficiary of the entire exercise is the chemical industry, which is eagerly buying up already such patents, thus the toxic pollution level in the environment must rapidly rise as a result of such policy. In the final analysis, I am convinced, that people in fear of famine due to possible repercussions, will to a great extent surrender their freedom and dignity to the will of those, who are in control of food. It has been voiced in various circles of Science and Philosophy that the potential of genetic-engineering and cloning can be more devastating than the Nuclear-Bomb and I believe, a unification of gene-manipulation, cloning, computer-technology and international finance together can form a power able to result in a sort of Domesday for the world as we know it. It may be the beginning of a ''Brave New World'' similar to that, described in Huxley's novel, but whether mankind can survive it's own creations or vanish together with nature, remains a question mark.

When the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives deal with this Bill, they may also consider the religious aspects of the matter. Australians, being so close to nature, have naturally a strong attachment to the Creator. It is not unlikely that spiritual divisions may be enhanced amongst people over this ethical atrocity, indeed, the scientific take-over of Creation is in a sense a dethronement of God as a control over all beings.

I am awaiting in anticipation the protest of the World-Leaders of Religion to come to the defence of the Divine-Creation, since they do so very often on the subjects of procreation and abortion and I pray, the very same Leaders will not 'side with the powerful' as they usually do. After all the Foundation of Judeo- Christian Faith is at stake.

I am sure, the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House do share the pride of all Australians over the unique beauty of this continent and the natural composition of it's diverse life-forms. Surely no-one of sound mind would wish to see this marvel of the Pacific Region being harmed and finely transformed into gene-manipulated mono-cultures, and yet this very Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 is the door-opener for such a future. We believe, the driving forces behind this Bill did get away with far too much already in Australia. I refer here to the chemical pollution and the concerted efforts of that industry to increase the sale of toxic chemicals to the agricultural community. Many housewives nowadays fear the method of high pressure salesmen: ''Foot in the door and no retreat.'' Australia is well advised to keep her doors tightly closed to the salesmen of new life-forms.

We cannot undo the scientific 'success' of cloning and gene-engineering, but the people of Australia can refuse to legalize their own dependence upon the mercy of Multi-National-Corporations. Such corporations generally do not break the Law openly, but rather lobby for the introduction of new laws, tailored to fit their future intentions. The present Bill, we believe, is a typical example of this kind and will give full cover of the Law to any foreign body or person as outlined in Division 2 Section 12 of the Bill and Division 1 Section 10 states unmistakably that virtually every plant of commercial interest falls under the Bill.

The promoters of gene-engineering may praise Interferon as a Wonderdrug, capable of eliminating cancer. We hold that from the very same corner of the industry once DDT was praised to be the Wonder-chemical, capable of eliminating the insect-pest, but yet the insects have not suffered real losses in the long run, while the environment of the planet is cursed with a dreadful chemical, which causes constant harm to nature now and in times to come and we believe, since the increase of cancer incidents appear in correlation with the increase of chemicals, it may be wise to reduce these chemicals rather than adding more to it, including substances derived from gene-manipulated matter.
I conclude, jointly with the undersigned petitioners that:
(1) The Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 bears destructive consequences for the environment of Australia.
(2) Due to protective chemicals, required for this kind of plants, the toxic level in the environment must increase.
(3) The independence of people and the free trade is endangered.
(4) The Peace of Faith is likely to be disrupted.
(5) The beneficiaries of the Bill will primarily be Foreign Corporations.
Should this Bill become Law.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia reject the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 entirely and in all parts.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for proposed expenditure announced.
Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, together with its companion Bill, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1982-83, seeks interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1982 to 30 November 1982, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation Bill for Parliament, forming part of the Budget for 1982-83, will have been enacted. Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $4,827m for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $464m, or about 10 per cent, greater than the amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1981-82. The Bill includes $125m for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, which is the same amount as has been included in Appropriation Acts (No. 1) for the past several years. I wish to emphasise that the Supply Bills do not anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the 1982-83 Budget context. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for proposed expenditure announced.
Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill seeks interim appropriations totalling $797m for expenditure on capital works and services, payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory and certain other services for the period 1 July to 30 November 1982. This is $134m, or about 20 per cent, greater than the amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 2) 1981-82. The funding through annual appropriations of certain expenditure which was formerly authorised by special appropriations is a major element of the increased provisions. This Bill includes $100m for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, the same amount as has been provided in the Appropriation Act (No. 2) in each of the last several years. As I emphasised when introducing Supply Bill (No. 1) 1981-82, the provisions in this Bill do not anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the 1982-83 Budget context. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Mr Hunt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with interest recently a report on the front page of the Australian newspaper of 18 March entitled 'Backbench fights cutbacks to State road funds program'. It stated that at the Government caucus meeting the previous day, the National Country Party rose en masse to attack the road funding proposals of its Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). The article specifically mentioned the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). The National Country Party members were joined by several Liberals-the honourable member for Eden Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean)-who complained of inadequate Federal road funding. Their blood-curdling cries certainly had a major impact on the Minister-so much so that this Bill increases road grants for the next three years by the amounts of only 7 per cent , 6 per cent and 6 per cent respectively, as was announced last year! This is despite the Government's full knowledge that road construction and maintenance costs are rising by more than 15 per cent each year. Yet again, for the seventh successive year, real Commonwealth road grants to the States will be cut in 1982 -83, 1983-84 and 1984-85 unless this Minister and this inept scandal-ridden Government are thrown from office, a fate that they so justly deserve. The only impression the National Country Party back benchers made on the Minister was that he cut his second reading speech to a third of the length of last year's effort. It illustrates the meagre commitment that the Minister for Transport has to roads except, of course, if they happen to be in his own electorate. Later in the debate I shall offer the members of the National Country Party and the Liberal Party an opportunity to bring their principles out of the Government caucus room, to voice them in this chamber, and to back them with their vote for my amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, Parliament had the doubtful privilege of hearing the honourable members for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron), Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and Lyne (Mr Cowan) beseeching the Minister to consider increased funding for country roads. They were bought off with his vague assurances that their views would be noted. That assuredly was the only action he took because under the financial provisions of this Bill every State in Australia will be worse off. I hope those honourable members will not be duped so easily again, especially by the Minister's latest tactic that scope for additional funds will be discussed in context of the next Budget.

Last November the Minister finally admitted that Commonwealth road grants were not keeping pace with increases in road construction costs. He said the Government would address the problem of declining real road grants on the release of the Bureau of Transport Economics report on a road construction price index in early 1982. That report, was tabled by the Minister several weeks ago. His response to the problem was again to defer its consideration until next August. The Minister's reference in his second reading speech to altered State relativities constitutes a superficial attempt to encourage dissension among the States in the battle for declining federal road funds.

The main purpose of this Bill is to provide financial assistance to the States and Northern Territory for road construction and maintenance purposes. The Opposition does not oppose it. The schedules attached to the Bill detail allocations of $734m in 1982-83; $778m in 1983-84 and $825m in 1984-85. These amounts represent, respectively, increases of 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 6 per cent over the previous year's allocation. The Bill maintains the established relativities and conditions attaching to Commonwealth assistance set out in the existing legislation.

In his second reading speech the Minister reluctantly confirmed the Australian Labor Party's repeated claims of recent years that Commonwealth road grants have not kept pace with road construction cost inflation. The new road construction price index report tabled by the Minister recently objectively reveals the sharp and irresponsible cutback in real federal road grants. It highlights the increases in fuel and bitumen prices as the two fastest rising components of the index. Both increases are the direct result of this Government's oil pricing and economic policies. The report using 1969-70 as a base of 100, shows that in the 11 years to 1980-81 the index for fuel had soared to 623.1 and that of bitumen to 512.4. By contrast the index for salaried labour rose to only 368.8 and of ' other labour' to 373.6. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an extract from the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cite two examples to demonstrate the appalling inaccuracy and inappropriateness of the two indices used by the Government as a basis for its increases in road grants. Using the old BTE index of road cost inflation and the notorious implicit price deflator of gross fixed capital expenditure on private non-dwelling construction, which does not even include bitumen prices, to compare the years 1974-75 and 1980-81 we find that total real federal road grants were cut by 4.6 per cent. However the new index exposes the true level of the cutback as 17 per cent. Secondly, in the 1979-80 Budget Speech the Government undertook at least to maintain road grants at the same level over the three years 1977-78 to 1979-80.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, even using the old inappropriate indices we find that in that period federal grants were reduced by 3.3 per cent. The new index reveals that the real cut back was 8 per cent, despite the promise made in the 1979-80 Budget Speech. It also exposes the massive 21 per cent cutback that has been made in real road grants to Victoria when comparing the years 1975-76 and 1980-81. More telling still is the cumulative total fall in road grants to Victoria compared with what they would have been if the Commonwealth had maintained the 1975-76 real levels for five years up to 1980-81. Expressed in constant 1980-81 prices, using the latest BTE index, the total cumulative fall is a brutal $112m over the five years. Other States have also had to contend with cutbacks in federal road funds . For instance the cutback in percentage terms in Queensland is 19 per cent. In money terms-comparing the years 1975-76 and 1980-81 the cutback is $95m. In South Australia the cutback is 28 per cent and in money terms it is $77m. In New South Wales in real terms the cutback is 15 per cent and in money terms it is $ 92m. So let us put an end to the claims of this Minister for Transport, his predecessor and those who sit opposite who seek to put the lie that the Government has maintained in real terms road grants to the States and Territories since 1975-76.

The Opposition has stressed many times that the amalgamation of the urban arterial and rural arterial roads categories into a single category of arterial roads would provide opportunities for inequitable distribution of road funds between urban and country areas. If formulae are agreed upon by each State and Territory for distribution of road funds then the former separate road categories should be restored to prevent repetition of the offensive National Country Party practice of 'pork barrelling' favoured regions with road funds, of buying votes in the country with road funds. The next Labor government will re- establish separate categories for urban arterial, urban local, rural arterial and rural local roads.

During the debate on the 1981 Roads Grants Bill, we warned that expansion of the definition of national developmental roads would result in 'pork barrelling' of favoured areas by the Minister for Transport. Sure enough, there is now prima facie evidence to show that the Minister's declaration of sections of the East- West road between Bourke and Narrabri in his own electorate as a national developmental road was not based on the usual criteria. He has applied $1.5m or 30 per cent of the 1981-82 New South Wales allocation for national developmental roads to the East-West road against the wishes of the present New South Wales Government and contrary to expert advice. This is an initial allocation with the estimate of total cost being, I understand, $25m. The present New South Wales Government has repeatedly stated that this road was not part of its 1981-82 developmental road proposals and that funds expended on it will divert funds from preferred developmental roads, all roads that are associated with the coal trade. The New South Wales Government has further claimed that its preferred developmental roads are used by several hundred vehicles per hour, compared with the less than 10 vehicles per hour that traffic the East-West road.

It should be noted that the recent report by a committee of senior representatives of Commonwealth and State road authorities on national highway deficiencies listed traffic volumes first on a list of priorities for works on national highways. An analysis of papers tabled by the Minister on 17 March 1982 in defence of his decision does not yield the conclusion, as he claimed, that the former Minister for Roads in New South Wales, the Hon. H. F. Jensen, decided on the East-West road as a national developmental road in 1978. Rather, analysis indicates that the Federal Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir, took the initiative in declaring the East-West road as a national developmental road. The prejudice the Minister holds towards metropolitan Australians surfaced in his arrogant Press statement of 30 October last in which he said this in reference to the East-West declaration:

. . . The N.S.W. Government has blatantly neglected this area (that is the Electorate of Gwydir) over the years to the advantage of Newcastle, Sydney and Wollongong. It is high time north western and western N.S.W. received a better deal.

I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the House that the 75 per cent of the New South Wales population who live in the metropolitan regions of Newcastle, Sydney and Wollongong know their areas have not been advantaged in the allocation of road funds. I can assure the House that the local government bodies of those regions also know they have not been advantaged in the allocation of road funds.

The Minister's claim was offensive, inaccurate and irresponsible. But his prejudice towards metropolitan Australians goes further. Presently he is attempting to reduce funding for urgently needed works on the Newcastle-Sydney expressway from the 52 per cent of the 1981-82 New South Wales national roads allocation as recommended by the New South Wales Government to 36 per cent of the allocation. If the Minister is successful in what he is trying to do, completion of the Newcastle-Sydney expressway will be delayed, opportunities for substantial cost savings in road construction will be lost and avoidable road casualties will occur. The hopelessly inadequate Wyong-Swansea section of the national highway is one of the heaviest trafficked roads in our nation. It has the worst record for road crashes and injuries of any road in Australia, yet this Minister and this Government are determined to delay its reconstruction for party political purposes.

The myth that the National Country Party cares for ordinary country people is a myth that has been perpetrated for too long. The absurdity is that the National Country Party is in reality a lobby group for the major mining corporations, many of which are foreign owned, and large corporate farmers. It masquerades as a fighter for the rights of ordinary country Australians. Country people deserve adequate transport services as a right just as they have a right to adequate education, health, welfare and cultural facilities. Under Labor's social audit concept, transport services will be valued by their full resource, environmental and social costs and benefits. This will replace the Government's narrow concept of valuing transport services simply by commercial costs and benefits.

The hypocrisy of the Government's approach to country transport services is revealed in the Minister's answer to a resident of South Australia who had protested at the planned closure of Australian National's vital 'tea and sugar' rail services to people living near the rail line from Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie. I quote from a reply that the Minister wrote to a resident. He said:

You may be aware that the Government's policy is that the Australian National Railways Commission should operate in a 'commercial' manner. In the circumstances, while I am sympathetic to the difficulties faced by people living in isolated localities, it would be inappropriate for me to direct the Commission to maintain an uneconomic service.

If the Minister's definition of commercial or uneconomic transport services were applied to all country transport services as it is being applied in respect of that service, few country transport services would remain in existence.

The crisis facing Australia's road network has been caused by the sharp reduction in real federal road grants by the Fraser Government. It has forced the growing burden of financial responsibility for roads onto the States and local government bodies. Both have limited access to the increased financial resources needed to meet that burden. Naturally there has been a resultant spate of increases in State motor vehicle and licence charges and of local government property rates to raise additional funds for road works. Their borrowings have skyrocketted but due to the Fraser Government's mismanagement of the economy, there is little scope for borrowing except at punitive rates of interest. The subsequent heavy repayments will eat into their future revenues, so restricting their ability to provide other essential services. Funds will have to be diverted from other priorities or necessary road construction and maintenance projects will have to be deferred.

In Adelaide last week the Senior Vice President of the South Australian Local Government Association, Councillor Des Ross, and the Association Secretary, Mr Jim Hullick, outlined to me and several of my colleagues the financial difficulties being caused for local government bodies in that State by this Government's cutbacks in road funding. They emphasised particularly the disadvantageous share of federal road funds being allocated to South Australia. Elsewhere in this country many councils are considering tearing up bitumen roads and replacing them with cheaper but less safe gravel roads. Federal revenue from fuel related taxes and levy has quadrupled since 1975. The estimated revenue for this financial year is $4,300m of which less than 17 per cent will be returned to road construction and road maintenance. Between 1975-76 and 1980-81 the Commonwealth's share of total road funding was reduced from 30 per cent to 22.2 per cent whereas in the same period the State's share rose from 27.6 per cent to 38 per cent.

State governments, in an effort to meet the costs associated with infrastructure for resource development, have had to divert funds away from freight services for country areas and small to medium size manufacturing industries as well as public passenger transport. The Australian Labor Party advocates a policy of allocating a fairer share of fuel-related revenues to road works and to the provision of alternatives to the private car in urban areas and long distance road transport. The nation's road network is disintegrating under the pressure of irresponsible cutbacks in real federal road grants and the total lack of a national transport policy under this discredited, divided, disoriented and scandal ridden Government. The paucity of federal road funds has forced States and local government bodies to divert an increasing share of available funds away from new road construction to road maintenance. As an example, in 1972-73 New South Wales spent 24 per cent of its total road expenditure on maintenance. By 1980-81, because of the cutbacks in real federal road grants, this share had risen to 34 per cent and for many local government bodies the maintenance share is even higher.

On top of its contemptuous disregard for the financial plight it has created for the States and local government, the Fraser Government bulldozed legislation through Parliament last May abolishing the long-standing discretionary power of State road authorities to decide which national road construction works they should build or put out to tender. This unwarranted legislation, a political pay off to the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, was opposed by all the States irrespective of their political persuasion. It constitutes a blatant featherbedding of wealthy private construction companies. There is absolutely no proof that private contractors build roads better or cheaper than State road authorities or local government bodies, a fact since admitted by the Minister. The Government acted without regard for the damaging and destabilising effect its decision would have on public road authorities, local government bodies and country towns. Already there is evidence to show that taxpayers' money is being wasted as a result of this Minister for Transport's blind determination to ensure that more national road construction works are carried out by private contractors in preference to public road authorities. Labor in government will restore to the States their former discretionary power over national road construction and end this Government's featherbedding of wealthy private construction firms.

It is instructive to attempt to understand the Government's rationale for its brutal cuts in real road funding because analysis shows there is no rational justification for its actions. The Government might claim that people do not want good roads and that use of roads is declining. Statistics show that road transport performs about 90 per cent of Australia's passenger task. In terms of passenger kilometres it carries about 75 per cent of freight tonnages. It is expected that for the next few years at least there will be a 4 per cent to 4.5 per cent annual increase in road travel. Again, the Government might try to claim that it is providing alternatives to road transport in order to conserve fuel and relieve congestion. Indeed, it has claimed that the crude oil levy is, in part, a fuel conservation measure. Yet, it has abolished specific purpose funding for urban public transport, the major alternative to the use of the private car.

The Government could also claim that road expenditure is not a good investment, given other priorities. Professor John Taplin, former Director of the Bureau of Transport Economics and former Deputy Secretary of the Department of Transport, now Professor of Transport Economics at the University of Tasmania, has shown by research and analysis that roads are in fact an excellent investment. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, an extract from Professor Taplin's paper. As with the earlier incorporation, previously a Minister agreed to its incorporation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE COST TO THE COMMUNITY OF NOT HAVING AN ADEQUATE ROAD SYSTEM
J. H. E. Taplin
Professor of Transport Economics
University of Tasmania
(Extracts from pages 1, 2, 7 and 8)

Answers to the question, what is the cost of not having an adequate road system , have been repeatedly given by the Bureau of Transport Economics and its predecessor in this field, the Commonwealth Bureau of Roads. The BTE report, An Assessment of the Australian Road System: 1979, shows that by holding road expenditure to 85 per cent of what it should be, as in the past, Australia would throw away benefits with a discounted present value of $1,785m (expressed in 1979-80 values). To obtain these benefits would cost $1,301m (again in present value terms) so that the net benefit lost would be $484m. Putting it another way , the community could have a 10 per cent return on the investment of $1,301m and have a surplus benefit of $484m as well.

Another important question is what are we losing at the margin? If a little more were spent, how great would the benefits be in relation to the cost? The BTE calculations indicate that if only 85 per cent of the warranted program is carried out then some more expenditure would yield benefits, discounted at 10 per cent, amounting to about 160 per cent of the added expenditure (i.e. a B/C ratio of 1.6). In some major classes of roads the yield would be much higher because the shortfall has been greater than 15 per cent.

These results provide a useful benchmark because many people know how unsatisfactory are these two highway connections to Canberra, particularly when there is heavy traffic-as there often is. They also tell us that, on their evidently severe criteria, there are many road projects which are twice as good and even three times as good as these two but which cannot be done because of insufficient funds.
