The first figure in Table 1 means that there would be about 2,000 fewer accidents annually. The BTE calculations imply that this reduction in accidents would include a saving of about 60 lives annually and almost 500 cases of injury . I have deduced from the sources given by the BTE that they were valuing a life at $103,000 in 1976-77 dollars, equivalent to about $135,000 in today's prices. Personally, I think the lengths society goes to in other fields to save life indicates a much higher community valuation of an individual life-perhaps $100, 000 more in today's values. If this is so then the discounted value of the reduced accidents is increased by almost 50 per cent from $137 million to $203 million.

The discounted value of $607 million for the reduction in vehicle operating costs would result mainly from more economical use of fuel and tires and lessened damage to vehicles. These benefits would be achieved through improved road surfaces, gradients and curves, as well as reduced congestion.

Of the two classes of time savings the discounted value of the commercial savings, $512 million, would greatly exceed the discounted value of the private savings of $188 million. The commercial savings are paticularly important. Because road transport is a highly competitive industry commercial savings would be passed on in lower freight rates and then through lower prices of goods to the community at large. I would add that the substantial part of the saving in vehicle operating costs accruing to commercial vehicles would also be passed on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The Government may assert that Australia's roads are safe enough, yet Professor Taplin has calculated that even if only 85 per cent of the Bureau of Transport Economics warranted road program were carried out, 60 lives would be saved and 500 cases of injury would be avoided each year. We have just witnessed the annual Easter blood bath on our roads in which 58 people lost their lives and almost 600 were seriously injured. It prompted the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 April 1982 to editorialise on the road carnage as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there can be no turning away from the costliest long-term obligation of all, the upgrading of roads.
It went on to state:
Roads are one area where the Commonwealth can play a positive role in what is, otherwise, primarily the States' responsibility.
The reference to 'otherwise . . . the States' responsibility' relates to police surveillance of breaches of traffic laws and to random breath testing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an advantage that is!

—Why does the honourable member's Government not bring in random breath testing in the Australian Capital Territory? It has control in the Australian Capital Territory. Why has the Government not done something about that?
—The Minister is going to.

—Honourable members opposite are very good 'gonnas'. The trouble with this Parliament is that the Government parties seem to be composed wholly and solely of 'gonnas'. They are always 'gonna' do something. They should just do it .
—If we are good gunners we can get you down.
—You would need to be good.
—The honourable member for Shortland will address the Chair.

—The question uppermost in the public mind is how many people have to die or be maimed in road crashes before this squandering, scandal-ridden Government comes to its senses and allocates a fairer share of road users' taxes to upgrading the road system and making the roads of this country safer for people to travel on, be they in the country or in urban or city areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Government may claim that increased road expenditure does not create employment. However, again, BTE research has shown that 64 per cent of direct and indirect expenditure on roads goes to the employment of labour. There is no sensible, rational or responsible reason for Federal cutbacks in real road grants. The basis of the Government's action with road grants is the same as it is for its entire economic policy-bastardised monetarism and a dangerous over- reliance on a few resource exports. This Government and honourable members opposite see road investment, however socially beneficial, as diverting funds from the resource sector. The vast financial and material demands of the resource sector, coupled with the Government's policy of slashing public sector spending to make room for resource sector development, is an alarming gamble with Australia's future. On numerous occasions we on this side of the House have warned of the dangers of placing an over-reliance on a few resource exports. Now , as media and industry reports are showing, the Fraser Government's economic strategy is cracking and its shaky foundations are crumbling. Moreover, the inequitable cutbacks in grants to the States combined with increased State responsibilities under the Government's disastrous new federalism policy and the need to finance resource development infrastructure are imposing immense pressures on the States to switch funds away from traditional areas of responsibility to mineral development infrastructure.

The Fraser Government has dislocated the public sector, the manufacturing industry, work forces and communities in order to make room for the resource sector to grow. It expected that this sector would rise like the Phoenix from the ashes of the manufacturing sector and carry the Prime Minister on to another election victory. This Government based its electoral viability on its resource export strategy and, now that that strategy is disintegrating, funds are being drained from housing, education, health, transport and the manufacturing sectors , as well as the social wage to prop it up. The deplorable state of many roads, the new employment that an increased rate of road expenditure would generate, the economic and energy savings to be derived from improved traffic conditions and the desperate need to reduce the senseless slaughter on our roads together constitute an indisputable case for a substantial supplementary allocation of Federal funds to be made to road construction and maintenance. Accordingly, I move:

That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give this Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that a substantial supplementary allocation of road grants should be made available to the States, the Northern Territory and local government without delay to-
(1) reduce the backlog of established roads needs;
(2) accelerate the rate of road construction and maintenance works;
(3) improve the efficiency of road transport services;
(4) reduce the incidence of road deaths and injuries; and
(5) assist local government bodies to meet road funding difficulties'.

In commending the amendment to the House I invite those honourable members opposite who have deplored this Government's priorities for Federal road funding and who are genuinely concerned at the state of our nation's road network to give the amendment their support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later hour this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak broadly about the road funding issue, I would like to comment on a few of the matters mentioned by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris). I think he has made it quite clear indeed that if the Australian Labor Party were in government tomorrow it would return to its policies of 1972 to 1975. He made it very clear that a Labor government would initiate legislation which would see a return to various categories of roads. If my memory serves me correctly-I am sure it does-funding for our rural local roads and our main and trunk roads was reduced drastically by the Labor Party when in government. In fact, we can all recall the time when 40 per cent of the petrol tax was allocated to the rural road system within Australia. I am not saying that the Labor Government was responsible for wiping that policy, but I recall that expenditure of $17m or $18m a year for rural local roads was reduced to $11m and $12m a year. I am afraid that my friend, the honourable member for Shortland, will not win many friends in country areas because local councils in particular and people generally have certainly not forgotten those days.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Shortland also referred to a statement he said he had seen from the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) relating to the result of calling for tenders for contracts relating to work on our national roads. I make the point that the Minister has made it clear that as yet it is too early to make any conclusive statements in relation to the result of our contract system for the national roads of Australia. The Minister has indicated that the policy is extremely effective. I think that this is the important factor that we have to take into account. I am sure that all honourable members on this side of the House believe that to give free enterprise an opportunity to tender for the construction and maintenance of national roads, arterial roads and, if necessary , council roads, will certainly reduce the cost of roads within Australia. I point out that legislation concerning Federal road aid to the States dates back to approximately 1922. Up to 1959 7d or 8d a gallon in petrol tax was allocated under legislation specifically for the construction and maintenance of roads. After the introduction of legislation in 1959 petrol tax generally became a Consolidated Revenue item. Since then an allocation has been made each year to the States.

The legislation before the House covers a three-year period. I recall the fact that originally the program was for a five-year period. That was done for a purpose-simply to allow the States and the councils to plan and to undertake their works accordingly. I do not think that there is anyone who would challenge the forward planning that was advocated within the program, simply because it was to the advantage of the Commonwealth, the States and the councils concerned. We should also recall that there were previously a number of categories of roads , and it is the responsibility of the States to decide, under their own legislation, as to where exactly they want to cast their categories. But under the Commonwealth funding, there are three. As we know, there are the national roads, which are the total responsibility of the Commonwealth; there are the arterial roads; and there are local roads.

The matter has been simplified to a very great degree, I shall suggest later that it should be simplified even more, because I believe that under our federal system, contrary to what was said by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris), we would get much more value for the dollar if the States and councils were able to accept a greater responsibility for determining spending on our roads. Under the legislation that came into effect a year ago, the Commonwealth gave to all the States a greater freedom in the spending of their money on their arterial and local roads, and the States appreciate this. I know that the Minister for Local Government in New South Wales welcomes this news as a good innovation for the States.

I think that we should keep in mind that there are two avenues by which the Commonwealth assists the road program within Australia. One is the legislation about which we are now speaking, and the other, which must not be forgotten, is the personal tax sharing arrangement. No one on the Opposition benches refers to this, of course, but these are funds made available by the Commonwealth, amounting to $350m a year, which are untied, and which are passed via the States to councils, and councils have the prerogative of determining how to spend the money-whether they balance it off against an increase in the rates or allocate it for roads. I know that nearly all the councils in my electorate of Lyne are allocating extra funding for roads. They will say that this is because of the extra assistance that they are receiving from the Commonwealth. Over a five-year period, over $1,000m has been given directly to roads, untied, as I have said, by the Commonwealth.

I support that if we were to say 'Right, let us keep that figure there and let us allocate all our extra funds directly to roads', this would be very well received by many councils throughout Australia. But I think that our program is fair, and I would be the first to agree with anyone, in the chamber or outside it, who says that we require more funds for roads. I am sure that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), following the advice of the Bureau of Transport Economics, would be one who would dearly love to come into the chamber and to be able to say 'Right, here are extra millions of dollars which will bring the amount that the Government can allocate up to the recommendations of the Bureau of Transport Economics.

But we must respect the fact-I am one who respects the fact-that unfortunately Australia is now going through a period of very acute economic problems and we must allocate the funds accordingly to our priorities, as determined by the Government and the Cabinet. It is our responsibility to come into this chamber and to say that we believe that roads in our electorates are one of the most important issues. I say that about my electorate. I am sure that the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), who had 50 or 60 council representatives at the House only a month ago, and who fights very hard for money for roads, is one who would solidly agree. My honourable friend the member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is always talking about the problems of the funding of Queensland's roads.

I think that we must accept that the people have made up their minds that passenger and freight transport over our roads is the thing and the coming thing . Our railway network generally is not sufficient and is not up to date enough to meet the general demands of the travelling public and freight movements generally throughout Australia. All country towns today look for decentralisation. They look to have the product manufactured in their town delivered on to the market floor on the following day. It is not always possible to do that with the railway system, but it is becoming possible to do it with our expertise in transporting freight over roads throughout the Commonwealth. Our roads will be used more and more for freight and passenger services. Many seaside areas throughout the country and many of our western towns are not served by a railway but are unable to secure State licence to operate a passenger service over the roads to the metropolitan areas. Outside of air and their own personal transport, there is virtually no other transport available for them.

I believe that we should go even further today because of the councils' concern and the deep concern in many of our rural city areas, and we should be looking at a more simplified system generally for the financing of roads. I advocate that the Government should now look at having only two categories of roads. We know that the Commonwealth has responsibility for national roads, but once we come to the roads that really matter within the local communities-the arterial roads and rural and urban local roads-perhaps the time has arrived when the Commonwealth should say to the States: 'Here is a bulk amount of funds. It is your responsibility to spend the moneys concerned and allocate your own priorities'. In a way, we are virtually doing this today, but we would have only the two categories of roads.

The importance of roads is so great that perhaps we should look at a proposal, which has been spoken about around the countryside, whereby a certain amount of petrol tax per litre is allocated directly for roads. If we took the $728m the legislation provides for this year and the increasing amounts that will follow through to 1984-85 and allocated it directly to the States on the basis of cents per litre in petrol tax, after taking out the 42 per cent for national roads, I do not believe that there would be any great objection from motorists. The motorist is the one who should be really responsible for the building and upkeep of roads.

I suggest that it is time to tie up forever the problems between the Commonwealth, the States and councils, and that a very clear line should be set. This is the opportunity, as I have said, for us to consider a tax on the basis of litres of petrol which can be returned to the States for expenditure on roads . Maybe-I do not know the constitutional powers in this respect-it is time for the States, with the Commonwealth being responsible for the national roads, to put on a tax and spend that money on the roads within their States. In other words, the States could determine the matter.

In New South Wales, the local government assistance fund in 1975-76 amounted to $12m. The previous government allocated that money directly to councils to spend as they wanted in their areas. The honourable member for Shortland should not speak about that, because that amount has been reduced. I believe that today it is only $9m. That is what the State of New South Wales thinks of the funding of roads. I believe I am correct in saying that none of the money collected from motorists within New South Wales goes directly back into road building within that state. This amounts to a considerable sum, involving registration fees, licence fees and fines imposed upon motorists. Virtually millions of dollars are not being returned to the roads in the States concerned. I know the States have their own priorities, but what priority does the Government of New South Wales give to roads? I know it has financial troubles. A State cannot invest its funds in projects that can be financed by private enterprise and expect not to run out of money. That is exactly what happened. I do not suppose it will be long before Mr Wran tries to come to Canberra. Certainly he will try to get here because he will want to get out of the mess he has made in New South Wales. This is evident now. He has ransacked the State so he will want to leave and come down here. He will see that the time is right before he comes. I have no doubt in the world that he will try to come if the opportunity presents itself.

As I said earlier, there is concern around the countryside about road funding. The Government appreciates the problem. The Minister for Transport appreciates the problem but unfortunately there is only a certain amount of money to spend, so priorities must be considered. As I said earlier, I believe there are ways to decide priorities which would clear up the details and let councils, States and the Commonwealth have a clearer view of the future situation so far as roads are concerned. Representatives of the shires and local government associations were in Canberra only a month ago. They talked to the representatives here about the problems that they have. They appreciate the economic situation but they want to know that they can plan. They want to know that extra funding is available because they believe, as I believe, that the general condition of the roads throughout Australia is slowly deteriorating in that the roads cannot keep up with the demands of present transport. The roads are not keeping up with the demands upon the Commonwealth, the States and the councils to provide the roads that this nation requires. If we look back over Australia's history we will all agree that in a continent as large as Australia, compared with European countries and even America, and bearing in mind our time here of less than a couple of hundred years, we have done very well indeed in the construction and maintenance of our roads.

Roads are productive. We have to realise this as it is important. It concerns me greatly that in all the budgets brought down by governments in Australia, proportionally less is spent on the productive issues of the nation, such as roads and water conservation, and on the matters that really will stand by Australia over the years to come. It is important that every penny that can be allocated to roads ought to be allocated, and ought to be spent efficiently. I outlined earlier what I mean by efficiently. The Minister said in the legislation of a year ago that the contract system is one way of overcoming inefficient spending. I know from the reaction within my electorate that this is being accepted particularly well not only by councils but also by the people at large. It is the people at large who travel on the roads. We can look at the roads up and down the coastline and at the roads leading west. The honourable member for Riverina, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), and other members of this chamber, are concerned about their local roads-the roads that take the school buses to school, that take people in to do business in the towns and take people's products to the market. The Pacific Highway up the coast is most inadequate. It cannot cater for the demands of freight and passenger transport generally. The arterial roads that leave the coast and go inland, to the hinterland, including the old main and trunk roads, are the ones that generally are still gravel roads. These roads should be in better condition; they should be bitumenised and available for fast transport.

Besides being reproductive, roads are utilities that are most important for Australia not only for defence but also in regard to the saving of lives. Over 3 ,500 people were killed and 90,000 people were injured on the roads throughout Australia last year. We have to look at these factors. A survey in Canada showed that 60 per cent more fuel is used on a road that is not in a reasonable condition that on a road with a bitumen surface. So there is a tremendous loss of fuel on Australian's roads today. Furthermore, the cost of production within our industries, particularly in regard to freight, can be brought down considerably if we have a better road system throughout the Commonwealth. Whilest I say todays that I support the legislation, I think we should all make it quite clear that we voice the opinion of many people around the countryside that there is a need for greater funding for roads generally throughout the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I agree with many of the remarks of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), I do take him to task. The honourable member was very vocal in condemning the previous Labor Government for its actions regarding road funding. The honourable member for Lyne was a Minister in the New South Wales Government which denied local government the 20 per cent savings in national roads funds which it had agreed to pass on. I ask him to think very seriously about why his Government, in which he was a Minister, did not hand on those funds. He condemns the roads in New South Wales and yet he was one of the causes for the roads in New South Wales being still bad.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the amendment, which I seconded, to the second reading of the Roads Grants Amendment Bill, I could not but notice on the front pages of the national Press in the week prior to the recess a photograph of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) riding tall in the saddle. I thought at first that he had discovered Marlboro country. Then I thought he had been reading Mungo MacCallum's column in the Age of Tuesday of that week which verbally depicted the Opposition riding off into the sunset, victorious after a parliamentary shoot-out, and which stated that he was forming a one-man posse to catch us before his deputies got him. My third thought was that Mr Russell Hinze or the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) had told him about the appalling condition of the nation's roads and he had opted for an alternative means of transport. I now believe that the correct assumption was that he had opted for another means of transport because a week later I noticed that the Minister for Transport was pictured in the Australian also trying a horse to avoid the bumpy roads.

Frankly, their remedy for the road situation does not surprise me because all of their Government's policies are characterised by horse and buggy thinking. The Prime Minister and his sidekick, the Minister for Transport, particularly are off the beaten track in their attitude to Federal Government road grants to the States, as was spelt out clearly by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris). One does not have to be Einstein to understand that it is elementary that if the Government increased road grants in real terms, based on a proper road construction cost index, it would: Most importantly, reduce the intolerably high toll of road deaths and maimings which would, in turn, reduce social security and health costs; provide employment; conserve valuable energy; promote tourism; lower transport costs; improve communications in isolated areas; improve the environment; lower air pollution; and, last but by no means least, increase our defence capabilities.

I appreciate that there is no bottomless well from which to draw endless buckets of funds. In fact, this Government's well has all but completely dried out due to careless mismanagement. However, as I have just indicated by the nine points I have made, an increase in real funds for roads indirectly would effect savings in other areas. The Minister for Transport must fight harder for funding and extol the virtues of roads as an investment in the future security and stability of the nation, not just an easy avenue in which to make cutbacks to balance the books.

Speaking of being off the beaten track, no State is suffering more from tight- fisted, Scrooge-like Government funding policies than is my home State of Queensland. I have no trouble in vouching for the deplorable condition of its roads, especially those in rural areas with which, Mr Deputy Speaker, you also would be very familiar. Queensland requires special attention. It requires more funding than do most other States and, indeed, a greater yearly increase in grants than is specified in this amending Bill.

The Bill indicates projected road grants for the next few years. Queensland is to receive proportional increases that will be almost identical to those received by the other States. But Queensland deserves more, and during the course of this debate I hope that I can persuade the Minister of that fact.

As all honourable members are aware, Queensland is growing rapidly-faster than is any other State or territory. In regard to interstate immigration, Queensland is the only State to show a significant increase. Whereas in the 1980-81 period, New South Wales and Victoria each showed a decrease in population of more than 12,000, and Western Australia a decrease of 570, Queensland showed an increase of 26,097. In regard to migration from overseas, Queensland's population increase was 10,000 more than that of its closest rival, New South Wales. Increased population leads to increased traffic, and road wear and tear, and therefore greater demand for new roads and maintenance of existing surfaces. Queensland is also disadvantaged by being Australia's most highly decentralised State. More than half of its population lives outside its south-east built-up area, which includes the north and south coasts, Ipswich and Brisbane. In New South Wales, 37.2 per cent of residents live outside the capital and in Western Australia the figure is 28.7 per cent. I suspect that many honourable members would have regarded Western Australia as our most decentralised State.

For the last financial year the Federal road grant to Queensland increased by 11.2 per cent, the increase for all other States. The Federal allocation for national highways increased by an overall average of 18.4 per cent. However, Queensland, which has more kilometres of national highway than has any other State, received 2 per cent less than the national average figure, as compared with the Liberal pork barrel State of Victoria, which exceeded the national average by almost 5 per cent. I wonder how that figure will vary now that the Liberals have finally been dethroned in that State. Other States need not feel that they are benefiting from Queensland's loss either. The report for 1979 of the Commonwealth Bureau of Transport Economics claimed that over the preceding five-year period Commonwealth grants to all States fell by 1.4 per cent a year in real terms. They have continued to fall at rates which have increased to six per cent this year.

The effects of the Government's Machiavellian funding policies towards what I regard as one of this nation's greatest investment hopes-our roads-are many and varied, but mostly detrimental. Of prime importance is the detrimental effect that the gradually diminishing road grants have had on the alarming road toll, of which, following our recent bloody Easter holiday weekend, all honourable member must surely be aware. Australians own 7 million cars. As a past member of the Parliamentary Road Safety Committee, it concerns me that increases in registration of motor vehicles are not matched by increased construction of roads. I quote from the Minister's news release of 13 April:

The road toll continues to be one of the biggest and most tragic social problems faced by Australians in the 1980s. The Minister added that in 1980 there were 22.4 road deaths for every 100,000 head of population.

For Queensland the figure is 25.9, or 3.5 more than the national average. Over the Easter period, 37 people died on the nation's roads. New South Wales, with 15 fatalities, had the most deaths. It was followed by Queensland, with 11. I ask honourable members to remember that the population of New South Wales is double that of Queensland, as is its number of vehicle registrations, but not its road toll.

Even before funeral arrangements could be made for the Easter road accident victims, Queensland's Main Roads and Police Minister and leading contender for the remake of the Incredible Hulk, Mr Russell Hinze, accused the Federal Government of responsibility for the road toll. In the Courier Mail of 12 April Mr Hinze is reported as having said that the poor state of some of Queensland's roads was a major contributing factor to the road toll and that the lack of Federal Government funding was responsible for the State's bad roads. Putting one and one together, Mr Hinze was blaming the road toll on the Federal Government. Although I agree with some of what Mr Hinze was saying, I cannot help feeling sorry for the Minister for Transport, whom Mr Hinze is trying to make a scapegoat in this matter.
In a Courier Mail article of 12 April dealing with the '595' campaign, the following appeared:
'Queensland can forget about reducing the road toll as long as the Federal Government persists with its dollars-before-lives policy of road funding' Mr Hinze said.
'The allocation of Commonwealth road funds to Queensland is a tragic joke. A realistic attitude could have halved the Queensland road toll in recent years.'
Mr Hinze predicted that Queensland would have the highest road toll of any State within two years.
What a disgraceful statement for any Minister to make. Rightly, he was condemned on the next day in an editorial in the Courier Mail, in these terms:
The attitude of the Main Roads and Police Minister, Mr Hinze, that Queensland's road death record is inevitable represents a defeatist approach to a problem which needs constructive thinking.

I would give ten out of ten marks to the Courier Mail editorial in that regard, but on 15 April, apparently the 'Incredible Hulk' turned green and in a mad rage got to someone at that newspaper, because it printed an incredible letter from the Minister which begins:
Your newspaper's record of publishing contradictory and at times ill-considered editorials has not been assisted by Tuesday's leader headed, 'No time for defeatism.'

I ask honourable members to remember that the Minister, in his earlier statement , had accused the Federal Government of being responsible for 50 per cent of the road deaths in Queensland. The Minister continued:
My Ministerial colleagues from other States . . . show that . . . road conditions are now one of the three main contributing factors of road accidents.

There was no mention of the other factors or of what really does cause road deaths. In the Telegraph of 15 April there appeared a very good story concerning Dr Strong, an eminent surgeon, who is surgical director of the Princess Alexandra Hospital and the newly appointed State Chairman of the Royal College of Surgeons' Road Trauma Committee. Dr Strong is reported as stating:
Queensland's road deaths occur mainly in country areas but that does not mean that poor roads are to blame.

The high country death count would well be a result of what happens after a crash, said Dr Strong. 'If you are going to have an accident don't have it in a country area', he said 'You may not be found for a while.'
Even if the crash is discovered, country hospitals are not geared for the massive injuries that often accompany a high speed road crash.

There we have the lie to Mr Hinze's statement. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 April reference is made to Life Insurance Federation of Australia figures and the following statement is made:

At least 50 per cent of all drivers and riders killed in NSW, Victoria and Queensland in 1980 had blood alcohol levels exceeding the .05 level. Of these, 50 per cent had levels exceeding .15 per cent.
More than 50 per cent of the drivers and riders who died after drinking were aged 24 or younger.

Surely those factors point out to politicians and State governments where they should direct corrective legislation. I repeat, obviously Mr Hinze was simply shifting the blame for the road toll away from the real issues-Queensland Government pork barrelling, the refusal to act on the alarming number of semi- trailer tragedies recently, and the glossing over of the controversial random breath testing argument as if it was not there. It is to Mr Hinze's benefit to be deprived of funds for roads so that he can throw up the lack of funds as a smokescreen to divert attention from his real failings as Minister responsible for main roads.

The Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, is also guilty of throwing up smokescreens and avoiding the real issues. In the national debate on random breath testing, the figures that Premier Joh has chosen to protest its introduction are strange indeed. He stated that Queensland police caught more drink drivers on average than Victorian police and therefore the Queensland system was more effective in catching drink drivers. However, when I look at the figures I can clearly see that Victoria's system of random breath testing is a greater deterrent than Queensland's system.

It is also strange that Joh and Russ ignore the figures such as those relating to the road toll. The average for the five years prior to Victoria's introduction of random breath testing was 908.6. It has since dropped to 784.75 which is a 26 per cent decrease. Queensland's toll has steadily risen over that same period. The national average of road deaths per 100,000 head of population was 22.4 in 1980. Victoria's figure was 19.9, having dropped from 23.7 and Queensland's figure was well above the average at 25.9. Without any statistical evidence Mr Bjelke-Petersen dismissed random breath testing as a possible form of assistance in lowering the road death toll by saying that it was an infringement of civil liberties. When has the Queensland Government ever been concerned about civil liberties! Just look at its record. I recall the state of emergency during the Springboks tour, the ban on street marches and now its Commonwealth Games legislation. No, Joh and Russ are diverting attention and passing the buck. If Mr Hinze were concerned with the road toll he would give up his Racing and Local Government portfolios to concentrate on Main Roads and Police. I would like to know whether the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), who is sitting at the table feels that his portfolio is so easy that he could handle a further three portfolios. Of course he cannot, and neither can Queensland's Minister for Main Roads, Mr Hinze. If he were really concerned he would hound this Federal Government and his colleagues for more funds. In that way he would show that he is interested in the main roads situation and that he is interested in reducing the road toll.

While Joh was strongly refusing to introduce random breath testing, even for a trial period, his wife Senator Flo had the marvellous suggestion of giving the money set aside to buy land for the Aborigines to road projects. Senator Flo said she would push hard for the Federal Government to direct funds from 'much less important areas' to road works in Queensland. I suggest to the honourable senator that if her husband were genuine and sincere about Queensland's roads and road accident fatalities his first step would be to prove his sincerity by setting aside the $2.3m he has allocated himself to buy a new jet to improve the roads not in a Labor electorate but in the electorate of Dawson. I think that would be a sound suggestion for the Premier to take in hand.

The sorry state of Queensland's political representation is another avenue in which Queensland is greatly disadvantaged. We might ask where would Labor hope to get the funds to allocate to roads. We would not think of roads as a burden, as does this Government. It also thinks of pensioners and those nasty unemployed people as similar burdens. We would think of roads as an investment. The return would come as savings in many areas. Those savings would come in the short and long term and be both monetary and environmental. Just consider one area of saving-the health costs of caring for the victims of road accidents. I would again like to quote from the Minister's Press release of 13 April in which he said:
The annual cost of deaths, injuries and property damage in road accidents has been set as high as $3,000 million.

I add that if one looks at the cost of an accident in cold monetary terms one would see that for every man aged between 20 years and 30 years who dies in a road smash the community loses $500,000 in lost earnings, tax revenue and commensurate returns for the cost of the person's education and upbringing. For those permanently disabled through an accident the loss may increase to $1m and dependants of traffic crash victims become charges on the public purse, something which the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) would no doubt hate to see.

Although 3,300 died in Australia on the roads last year and the majority of those were under 30 years of age, injuries reached a far higher figure-about 10 times as many. The Minister's figure of $3,000m starts to look very realistic indeed. That figure will increase annually as the road toll increases, more people are being saved from death by the latest life saving medical knowledge, yet the Government continues its stringent slashing of road funds.

Another detrimental result of the Government's road funding policy which concerns Australia as a nation and Queenslanders in particular is that this country does not have all-weather defence roads connecting vital areas with the north where we would surely be attacked if we were ever in such a danger. To paraphrase a distiguished colleague:
It took World War II to get a road from Adelaide to Darwin. It will probably take another world war to get it sealed.

Army officers have inspected the Flinders Highway between Townsville and Charters Towers and reported that they were appalled at the possibility of having to deploy large contingents of armed units along the road in a defence emergency. I have travelled widely on the roads in Queensland and the Northern Territory and I can say with some authority and without fear of contradiction that most of those roads in the wet season are continual bogs and in the dry they resemble the trenches of the Somme in France during World War I. In the event of a natural disaster in or an invasion of the north the possibility of rapidly moving troops and equipment along these roads is virtually nil. It is a national scandal that our northern areas are almost totally cut off from receiving substantial ground support from armed forces in times of desperate need.

The Labor Party has the policies to straighten out this country's road system. We are not concerned with making huge and sweeping cutbacks across the board, regardless of their merit, and at the same time ignoring tax fraud, medical practitioners' fraud and the like. The savings we will make from legislation in those areas will be put to work in other areas such as roads which we consider to be an investment in the future. At present the future does not look too bright, considering the Budget blowout, the worsening economic situation and the appallingly short-sighted Bills such as this amendment Bill which is simply a Government measure for retaining funds to balance the books at the end of the year.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bradfield) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement.
—is leave granted? There being no dissentient voice, leave is granted.
—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker you didn't--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Shortland has not made his position quite clear. The Chair posed the question whether leave was granted. He was in motion actually when he drew to notice that he may have demurred. The Chair rules that leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Honourable members will recall that on 11 March the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) sought to impugn the integrity and conduct of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) in relation to the investigations of the Nugan Hand group. I think at the end of that debate it was demonstrated that the allegations made by the Leader of the Opposition were false. Other allegations have arisen in Question Time and in various debates that have occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent weeks the Leader of the Opposition has taken the view that the terms of reference of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking were inadequate to allow investigation of all allegations of unlawful activities of the Nugan Hand group of companies. He indicated a strong preference to have a new royal commission established for this purpose.

As the House has been informed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and myself on many occasions, the Government envisaged upon the establishment of the Stewart Royal Commission the possibility of an extension of its terms of reference to cover other drug trafficking groups. It felt that this approach ought to be tested before any consideration was given to the possibility of a new royal commission. I wrote to Mr Justice Stewart informing him of developments and the House resolved to send the Hansard of the debate to the royal commissioner. Furthermore, the Commonwealth's law officers were asked by the Prime Minister to examine the documents which the Leader of the Opposition tabled in the House on 25 March and the allegations concerning Nugan Hand made in the House and the Senate as well as a letter to the Prime Minister from the Leader of the Opposition with a view to ascertaining whether the matters raised warranted an extension of the Stewart Royal Commission's terms of reference.
The law officers have formed the opinion that an extension of the terms of reference of the royal commission is warranted to cover allegations of:
(1) Nugan Hand's involvement in drug dealing, beyond any association with the Clark group;
(2) Nugan Hand's laundering of money, and association with organised crime;
(3) interference with earlier investigation of Nugan Hand.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of the law officers' report.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
NUGAN HAND
JOINT OPINION

We have been asked to examine the recent published material and allegations made concerning the activities of Nugan Hand to ascertain whether they warrant an extension of the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission.

We have examined copies of the documents tabled in the House of Representatives by the Honourable the Leader of the Opposition on 25 March 1982 (House of Representatives Hansard, 25 March 1982, page 1401) and read the allegations in that House and the Senate on that day concerning the activities of Nugan Hand. We have also examined the material and allegations (including the matter incorporated into Hansard) concerning the activities of Nugan Hand raised in the Representatives on 11, 16, 17, 18 and 24 March 1982 (House of Representatives Hansard, pages 890-927, 959-960, 976-988, 1033-1034, 1127-1131 and 1313-1314). We have read as well a copy of a letter dated 25 March 1982, relating to a re- examination of the Commission's terms of reference from the Hon. Bill Hayden to the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, C.H., M.P.
We think that the material and allegations in the tabled documents and the passages from Hansard above set out warrant an extension of the terms of reference.

In our opinion the terms should be so drafted as clearly to authorise, for example, an inquiry by the Commissioner into the allegations of Nugan Hand's general involvement in drug dealing as opposed to such dealing only when in association with Terrence John Clark; into the allegations of a general laundering of money wrongfully obtained or wrongfully concealed from the Australian authorities and into allegations of co-operation with organised crime .

None of the papers tabled support an allegation of trafficking in arms. There is nothing to suggest public disquiet on the question. We think that in the absence of some credible evidence to suggest it or a sense of positive public disquiet the terms should not be extended to include arms trafficking.

The transcript of the television interview of a former Narcotics Bureau agent contains statements that Michael Hand was understood to be either an 'ex-CIA operative or a current CIA operative' (House of Representatives Hansard, page 924) and that other people connected with the CIA were within the Nugan Hand organisation. The basis for this, as for similar suggestions in one of the tabled documents, nowhere appears. The imprecision of the statements and their hearsay basis hardly support an extension in this regard of the terms of reference.

Suggestions of Nugan Hand's involvement with foreign intelligence agencies have appeared from time to time in the Press. The sensational nature of the allegation is, no doubt, in part responsible. But apart from allegations in the tabled papers of Michael Hand's and Bernard Houghton's association (in the main spoken of in the past) with foreign intelligence services, there is no real evidence to support Nugan Hand's involvement. The additional reference to a retired U.S. Admiral (former head of an Intelligence Group with which Hand or Houghton or both had worked) as employed by Nugan Hand or a subsidiary does not carry the matter further. Nor do references to attendance at meetings called for commercial purposes of retired high ranking members of the U.S. Defence forces. Their engagement in commerce is hardly unusual.

While it is open to the Government to extend the terms to include Nugan Hand's alleged involvement or cooperation in its illegal activities with foreign intelligence agencies, on the present material we are unable to advise it to do so.

Mr Hayden's letter says ''it is essential the Commission enquire into allegations that Government officials and/or Ministers inhibited or attempted to inhibit investigations into all or some Nugan Hand activities''. Material which could suggest such action by a Government official, although not by Ministers, is contained in the papers tabled by Mr Hayden and allegations to that effect have been made in the Representatives and during a television interview, the transcript of which is incorporated in Hansard (H. of R.) of 11 March, 1982 at p . 924. The terms of reference, we think, should be extended to include this allegation.

Whether they should also extend to allegations concerning Ministers is more doubtful. The suggestion is that some Minister other than the then responsible Minister gave the direction to confine the investigation. The issues would therefore be, was any such direction given, and, if so, by which Minister from amongst all those in the Ministry? It is open to serious doubt whether general allegations of this gravity against, in effect, any, perhaps each, member of the Ministry should be submitted to a Royal Commissioner. Nonetheless, the terms should be widened, as we have said, to include whether a Government official improperly sought to confine the investigations. A term of reference raising the question whether any person improperly interfered with, or sought to confine, the investigation would allow inquiry into whether a Government official did so as well as permitting inquiry into a specific allegation against a specified Minister, past or present. Such a term is, we think, sufficient for the present circumstances.
P. DURACK
Attorney-General
M. H. Byers
15 April, 1982 Solicitor-General

TALK.START.PARA: —Having regard to the nature of the matters identified by the law officers as requiring further investigation and their relation to matters already under investigation by the Stewart Royal Commission, the Government does not think it appropriate that a new commission should be established. A further inquiry into these matters will be best handled by the Stewart Commission under extended terms of reference. Extension of the Royal Commission's terms of reference to cover Nugan Hand would be consistent with our announcement on establishing the Commission that the terms of reference might need to be supplemented to cover other drug trafficking groups. It is also consistent with the need for a wide and impartial inquiry into all aspects touching Nugan Hand, including those reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 March 1982 of evidence given to investigators that Nugan Hand supported and was used by persons and organisations across the political spectrum. There is a need for even-handedness in action to be taken by the Government in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made a decision, subject of course to the views of States which have granted concurrent commissions, that the terms of reference for the Stewart Commission should be extended as recommended by the law officers. The Prime Minister has written to the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland to seek their support in principle to the proposed extension of the terms of reference. The letter raised the need for agreement by at least New South Wales of a parallel extension of its commission to consider breaches of State law.

The Government has noted the law officers' conclusion that the need for a specific inquiry into any foreign intelligence agency links has not been established. There have been firm United States denials about Central Intelligence Agency involvement with Nugan Hand. The Government intends, however , that the extended terms of reference will be wide enough to allow the Commission to investigate Nugan Hand links with any organisation. The Commonwealth has always taken the view that all persons involved in criminal activities affecting Australia, regardless of whether they are members of any organisation, should be thoroughly investigated with the aim of establishing their involvement in drug trafficking or other crimes. In relation to the Royal Commission investigation, the Leader of the Opposition has on occasions raised the matter of the protection of witnesses. I assure the House that the Australian Federal Police will be made available to ensure any necessary protection of witnesses before the Royal Commission.

As I have indicated to the House, the Government has had repeated assurances from the United States Government that there was no connection between the CIA and Nugan Hand. On 26 March 1982 the Public Affairs Division of the CIA took the unusual step of issuing a statement responding to allegations about links between Nugan Hand and the CIA, and operations by the CIA against the Labor Government. It emphatically denied those allegations. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of a cable handed to the Government by the United States Embassy referring to the statement by the Public Affairs Division of the CIA.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Subject: Statement regarding allegations made in Australian Parliament re CIA involvement with Nugan Hand Bank

1. In response to queries from the Associated Press and the United Press International regarding recent questions raised in the Australian Parliament, the public affairs division of CIA issued the following statement on March 26, 1982.
Begin text:

The opposition Labor Party has produced documents alleging narcotics links between the collapsed Nugan-Hand Bank and the CIA. There are also resurgent charges that CIA engaged in operations against the Labor Government in Australia several years ago. Comment: The agency rarely comments on such allegations but in this case we emphatically deny these charges; the CIA has not engaged in operations against the Australian Government, has no ties with Nugan-Hand and does not involve itself in drug trafficking. End text.
2. Thus far there appears to have been no/no press reaction to this statement in the U.S. Haig
Unclassified State 89264

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a recommendation from Mr Justice Woodward in his further report into drug trafficking, and on the Commonwealth's initiative, the terms of reference for the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking were widened to enable it to investigate the evidence concerning Nugan Hand and persons associated with it. Volume 1 of the Joint Task Force report deals with the activities of Murray Stewart Riley, Harry Wainwright and some related drug matters. The draft Press release submitted by the Joint Task Force with Volume 1 and incorporated in Hansard by the Prime Minister on 18 March outlined the reasons why the volume should not be made public. As foreshadowed to the House, the Prime Minister did, however, make a copy of the report available to the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has now considered and accepted the recommendations in Volume 1. Specifically, the Government has endorsed the action proposed for the reference by the Joint Task Force of available evidence, information and relevant papers, concerning the activities of persons named, to the relevant Commonwealth and State Crown law or other authorities so that consideration can be given to the preferment of charges or other appropriate action-such reference is, I am advised, now well in hand; endorsed the proposed reference by the Joint Task Force of relevant information and papers-concerning drug importation routes , unregistered gaol visits, avoidance of the preventative screen by corruption, and sale and purchase of property-to the relevant Commonwealth and State authorities for appropriate action, and agreed that Volume 1 and, where necessary, supportive material be distributed by the Joint Task Force to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the AFP Bureau of Crime Intelligence.

A copy of Volume 1 has already been sent to the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. I should add that where relevant information and papers are passed to Commonwealth authorities for appropriate action, the Ministers responsible will be asked to monitor progress on necessary corrective action. The Chairman of the Joint Management Committee has been advised of the Commonwealth Government's full endorsement of the recommendations in Volume 1.

I am informed that the New South Wales Government has taken similar action in relation to matters falling within its areas of responsibility. The Joint Task Force has advised that Volume 2 of its report will deal with the Nugan Hand group of companies and their dealings with known and suspected drug trafficking groups.

The Royal Commission's extended terms of reference will ensure that it has ample scope to investigate and report on all matters of concern to Australia arising out of allegations made in relation to Nugan Hand. The Royal Commission will be assisted in its work by the decision recently announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that the Government has decided to amend the income tax law to allow it to be given information held by the Australian Taxation Office. The Prime Minister is writing to the Leader of the Opposition advising him of the Government's decision on extension of the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission. He is informing the Leader of the Opposition that, subject to agreement of the Stewart Royal Commission and the Joint Task Force, he or his Deputy Leader may peruse the relevant files of the former Narcotics Bureau. Those files, which are in the custody of the Royal Commission and the Task Force , hold originals of documents tabled in this House by the Leader of the Opposition on 25 March 1982.

Let there be no doubt in any mind that the Government is resolute in its intention that there should be the fullest possible investigation into the allegations of unlawful activities by the Nugan Hand organisation and persons associated with it in those activities. Moreover, let there be no doubt that the extended terms of reference will make it possible for the Stewart Royal Commission to examine exhaustively all matters of concern to Australia regarding Nugan Hand. As the House has already been informed by the Prime Minister and myself on a number of occasions, the Government has been open and frank in its handling of this matter and has referred all the files to either the Joint Task Force or the Stewart Royal Commission. I remind the House that the Prime Minister and I also appealed to the House and to all persons that if they have any information or documents relating to the activities of the Nugan Hand bank they should come forward to produce that information and documents to either the Joint Task Force or the Stewart Royal Commission. The Government repeats that appeal today. I present the following paper:
Investigations into Nugan Hand-Ministerial Statement, 20 April 1982.
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). It is a substantial improvement on the attitude of the Government in its response to the Nugan Hand matter when I raised it several weeks ago in the Parliament. On those several occasions not only was my concern repudiated and scorned; there was not a small amount of personal vilification involved in the Government's response. Today the Government has acknowl- edged that there was substantial cause for concern on my part and on the part of any person of proper sensitivity about society and his responsibility to society, especially one such as myself in public office. The regret is that the vilification and the attempted obstructionism and obscurantism of the Government of several weeks ago stood between the period when I first raised this matter and the enlightenment which the Government is now displaying. The Government has confessed that I was right and that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) was right too in demanding that there should be a royal commission of inquiry into Nugan Hand's operations and matters associated with that institution.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has some reservations about a few of the matters that I raised. I will come to those in a minute. The first point I make is that when I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) responding to his invitation to produce whatever evidence I had, and so on, I pointed out to the Prime Minister that the very strong preference of the Opposition was for a new royal commission to undertake this role. I said that the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking has now been operating for eight months but it is unrealistic to expect the Royal Commissioner to change course by asking him to conduct simultaneously what are in effect two major inquiries. I went on to point out how that would impose an unreasonable strain on that Royal Commission of Inquiry .

It is better to win some than to lose all the way. It would be better for everyone in the community if we had won all the propositions that we put forward , including the key one that there should be a quite separate royal commission of inquiry on this matter. My hunch is that the Nugan Hand inquiry will be buried in this Royal Commission of Inquiry for months and months-until well beyond the next election and maybe much longer. It is like a horseman trying to ride two horses that decide to go on diverging paths. These inquiries are substantially different in important respects. Having expressed that reservation I will go on to mention some matters in the statement by the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister has conceded that there should be an inquiry, which goes beyond the Clark group, into Nugan Hand's involvement in drug dealing. Of course there should be. There never should have been any quibble about that. One needed no law refinement, just ordinary common sense and literacy, to understand the terms of reference for the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry. They were too restrictive to allow the sort of inquiry we were proposing and which the Minister said could be undertaken by that Royal Commission when he responded to the concern of my Deputy and me in the Parliament.

The inquiry will also consider matters such as the laundering of money, Nugan Hand's association with organised crime and interference with earlier investigations of Nugan Hand. Apparently, it will not investigate allegations of association with the Central Intelligence Agency or of arms trafficking. The Minister, on behalf of the Government, has put up a rather fickle substantiation of that, saying that he has a law officers' opinion. As I read their opinion, the law officers considered only those matters which I raised in the Parliament. A whole huge volume of documentation and commentary, which cannot be ruled out of court, is available in this country on those two matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can look at it.

—Let me tell my story. The last time the Minister interrupted he got himself into trouble. That is why today he is backtracking. I quote from the report of the liquidators, Pegler Ellis and Co., in the case of Nugan Hand. At page 50 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that some former officers, directors and consultants to the Nugan Hand group had military backgrounds and links at a high level with American Intelligence Organisations.

From the way in which that is written, it seems to me that the verb 'had' was used as a verb of continuing tense, at the time of the liquidators' investigation. There can be no doubt that Nugan Hand was involved with the CIA and in arms dealing. The Sun-Herald of 15 February 1981 states:
The Nugan Hand Bank had a special arrangement with the CIA to handle its money, including illegal funds from drugs.
This startling new claim was made by a former executive of the Bank, Mr Neil Evans, a Brisbane tax consultant.
Mr Evans says smuggling operations involving the CIA were worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
One secret arms deal through the Bank with Saudi Arabia was worth more than $ 200 million.

There we have a former senior executive of the Bank declaring this publicly and the Government saying that there is no evidence of it because the law officers said so. Quite obviously, the law officers were instructed by the Government to consider only those matters which were raised in the Parliament. That is a substantial declaration and a matter that demands follow-up and thorough investigation. It is slipshod for the Minister to suggest otherwise. It deceives no one to suggest that the overwhelming evidence is that the Government does not feel that any case has been established for an investigation into that area.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express concern as well that the expanded terms of reference for the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking do not provide explicitly for investigation of those matters which have been raised as allegations associating the Central Intelligence Agency with Nugan Hand. They mainly relate to the intelligence association and also to gun running operations with which both the CIA and Nugan Hand have allegedly been associated. The Minister said this in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has always taken the view that all persons involved in criminal activities affecting Australia, regardless of whether they are members of any organisation, should be thoroughly investigated.

And so on. In that context the investigation of any organisation is associated with criminal activities. The Minister was generous enough, at the commencement of the suspension of the sitting for dinner, to point out to me that that, like some other comments he has made in this House on this matter, was misleading. In fact the terms of reference will be couched widely enough, but I suspect not specifically enough for my satisfaction, to include investigation of the CIA. I hope it will allow the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry to initiate investigations into those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will.

—The Minister says it will and I thank him for that assurance. I do not accept, as he does, the assurances of the CIA that it has never been involved with Nugan Hand. I quote further from the Minister's statement: There have been firm United States denials about CIA involvement with Nugan Hand. Quite frankly, on its record the only people who would accept that sort of guarantee from the CIA would be the sort of people who would believe Ronald Biggs when he said that he had never travelled by train. The CIA has a deplorable record. Let me give honourable members some quotations from a book I read a little while ago by John Stockwell, a former CIA officer. In his book 'In Search of Enemies: A CIA Story' he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I was assigned to a managerial position in the CIA's covert Angola program . Under the leadership of the CIA Director we lied to Congress and to the 40 Committees, which supervised the CIA's Angola Program.
. . . Our secrecy was designed to keep the American public and press from knowing what we were doing.

That is from page 10. On page 11 he deals with the pride displayed by Richard Helms, one of the CIA directors, on the occasion of his conviction of perjury for lying to a Senate committee. Who would believe the CIA on its record as an operative agency of the American Government? It has been deplorable and often out of control, and it can be rarely trusted. The CIA has been involved in gun running activity. Let me quote:
Joe Judge, US arms dealer has given an on the record interview stating that he was told by the CIA to use Nugan-Hand for gun running purposes. He alleges that Nugan-Hand was used in such a manner.
Among the papers left behind after Nugan's death-
We have a photocopy of this in my office-

in his own hand-writing from 1975 was: Military weapons Rhodesia, pay in gold, recoilless rifles, mortars 60/80M, M79 grenade launchers, Quad 50 calibre machine guns . . . ex-factory shipment, expecting phone call . . . Les Collings (Hong Kong Manager for Nugan Hand)-
That is my interpolation-
referred by Hand can send for inspections. Lee will take him . . .
There is another quotation:
There are a number of other reports of Nugan-Hand being involved in arms deals with Brazil, Thailand and other countries.

Wilson, who was Nugan-Hand's Middle East Manager and also associated with US Intelligence, is a major arms dealer. Wilson is currently wanted by the American authorities in connection with arms sales to Iraq.
Patry Loomis, as well as being a member of the CIA, is reported to have used Nugan-Hand to transfer huge sums of money for arms deals as well as payments for intelligence activities.

That is more than enough substantial evidence to justify an investigation of CIA activity in association with Nugan Hand. The people who have been associated are : Admiral Yates, William Colby, General Ed Black, Ed Wilson, Michael Hand, Walt McDonald, Bernie Houghton, Patry Loomis, Dale Holgreen and Guy Pauker. They are all US military or intelligence personnel of a very senior order. It seems to be an extraordinary coincidence that they all found in a short time that Nugan Hand was a favourite parking station for retired CIA and military officers of United States forces. One has substantial grounds for believing that the CIA operatives were not retired, if indeed CIA operatives ever retire. I mentioned before the dinner break Neil Evans, a former director of the Nugan Hand Bank, who declared that secret arms deals were conducted-I interpolate involving the CIA-by Nugan Hand. Of course, we had the declaration of the liquidator handling Nugan Hand's affairs to the effect that the CIA had in fact been involved in Nugan Hand.

Let us look at the role of our own security agency, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I quote from an article written by Brian Toohey and Marian Wilkinson which appeared in the National Times. The authors of the article have carried out some impressive investigative journalism in this very difficult area. It is extraordinarily difficult to penetrate this clam shell. They said this:
According to a green stamp in Immigration records, Houghton--
Parenthetically I point out his association with the CIA and Nugan Hand--
was Security Cleared by ASIO in 1969. A blue stamp in 1972 immigration papers show him as 'Listed ASIO', while he was 'vouched for' by the NSW head of ASIO in other 1972 papers.

Toohey and Wilkinson went on to say that in spite of all this Woodward, then in charge of ASIO, wrote that ASIO had nothing on Houghton. We do not cop that either, and we are far from satisfied at the way in which these investigations have been conducted to this point. We are appalled at the way the Government sought to obscure and deflect discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.

—The Minister says it is not right. But let me remind him of what he said about me and the matters I raised in this House in relation to the need for an expansion of the terms of reference for the Stewart Royal Commission of inquiry if it was going to handle this matter. I repeat my preference for a separate commission of inquiry for practical reasons. As a commentary not on the quality of what I had to say but on his own intelligence and application to his task, the Minister, on 16 March 1982, said: 'Has anyone ever heard anything so pathetic?' and 'I am afraid that he has demonstrated his ignorance yet again' rejecting the proposition I was putting forward and the evidence in support of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it unacceptable that there will be a total exemption, apparently if one takes the legal opinion, of any authority for the royal commission to investigate any alleged association of an unnamed Minister or Ministers. It will be appropriate for the royal commission of inquiry to investigate all unnamed senior or junior or in-between officials of the Public Service. They are in a different category. That is appropriate. But there should not be special immunity for any member of this Parliament let alone the Government if allegations have been made. It is in their interests that they have a clean record, that the slate be established as a clean one by an independent investigation. I repeat that it is a shame it took the Government so long to realise that the seriousness motivating the Opposition in this matter was well and truly justified. We have had an important moral victory on this matter with this large concession to date. But I repeat it is regrettable the Government cannot even conduct affairs in this area properly as it cannot in any other area .
