SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradfield Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In resuming the debate on the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982 I feel I should seize the opportunity to comment on some of the comparisons made by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris), the shadow Minister for Transport in the Opposition. He drew many comparisons which showed that road grants had progressed only by low percentages on an annual basis. But the comparisons he made were unfair because he failed to take into consideration the tremendous increase in general purpose revenue grants made by this Government, both to State governments and to local governments, particularly since 1975. Members of this Parliament will be well aware of the generosity of this Government-the tremendous increase in these general purpose revenue grants and the reason they are paid. General purpose revenue grants are paid to State and local governments so that they can be masters of their own expenditure. Under those conditions, it is unfair to compare purely specific purpose grants without taking into consideration the payment of general purpose revenue grants. From the speech by the honourable member for Shortland I cannot help but feel that once again we have gone back to the era of achievement being measured by how much is spent. That is hardly the birthplace of efficiency. That is exactly what the Labor Government did when it experienced its brief period in office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Roads Grants Amendment Bill that is before us is necessary to replace the present controlling legislation which provides for road expenditure to June 1982 . This Bill ensures further funding totalling $2,337m to provide road construction and maintenance funds up to and including the 1984-85 financial year. This Government originally announced a five-year funding program for roads in June 1980. This Bill allows for the completion of that program. I think it is both important and appropriate to reflect on recent developments in our road system. While many people will argue that available funds are inadequate-I can well understand this view-observations can easily be made that disclose that substantial improvements have been made to our road system over the last 20 to 25 years. I ask all honourable members in this House to reflect, in all fairness , on the last 20 to 25 years and to think of the improvements that have been made to the roads on which they regularly drive.

In a large country with a small population I think the achievement in relation to roads has been quite reasonable. I and many other honourable members drive from Sydney to Canberra quite regularly. Improvements have been made to that road. The expressways that have been constructed along some of the major roads up and down the east coast of my State of New South Wales reflect achievements in road construction. The fact that new bridges are being built and road development is still going on is an indication that progress is being made under difficult conditions. It has not been an easy task to construct roads in this large country-a country with a relatively small population-but this Federal Government has accepted its role to develop roads. It is the role of this Government to develop roads.

I should like to analyse the three tiers of responsibilities for roads. The three sources of funding are the Federal Government, State governments and local governments. It is the Federal Government's role to place emphasis on development and to ensure that roads go to areas with not very large populations . In the more densely populated areas the State governments, but more particularly local governments are able to meet the maintenance costs for their roads. They are better placed than the Federal Government to raise the necessary revenue locally. However, a local authority in the centre of Australia is not as well placed to raise such revenue. So the Federal Government has more of a responsibility to develop roads than to maintain roads.

Apart from the expanded and extended funding provided for in the Bill, conditions of funding remain basically the same as those expressed in the Roads Grants Bill 1981. I should like to refer to the recently reduced number of road categories-down to three-because they remain in this Bill. I should like also to refer to the fact that in 1981 this Government introduced into road building and road maintenance the procedure of open tendering. That has brought efficiency to the building of our roads, and that is a condition which will remain and continue to bring efficiency to our road building and road maintenance programs.

This Bill provides for $734m for the forthcoming financial year, 1982-83. As the honourable member for Shortland correctly said, that is an increase of about 7 per cent. The Bill provides for $778m for the 1983-84 financial year, which is an increase of 6 per cent, and for the following year $825m, which is, again, an increase of 6 per cent. I realise the concern at the apparent funding restraint embodied in this Bill, but I strongly suggest that judgments as to the degree of restraint can be made only in simultaneous consideration of general revenue grants made by this Government to the States and local government bodies to which I referred earlier.

I want to itemise the increase in general revenue grants to all States, because I want to show, through figures, how the Federal Government is being generous in what it is doing, and that in some cases State governments are not pulling their weight. Looking at this generous increase in general revenue grants-the revenue which goes to States, and is directly tied to personal income tax collections- one finds that all States in Australia in the last four years have had general revenue grants increased from $4,317m to a generous $6,690m, an increase of 53 per cent. I mention those figures because the inflation rate over those four years has not been 53 per cent, so in general purpose revenue grants there has been an increase in real terms.

Four years ago total grants from this Government to local government throughout Australia were $165m. It is estimated that in 1981-82, four years later, local government will receive $351m-an increase of 113 per cent. That is a most generous increase when compared with the rate of inflation, and it is certainly an increase in real terms. Those general revenue grants can be used at the discretion of the State or local government authority which receives them. If those bodies choose to do so, they can be used for road maintenance or road building. That was the basic purpose of our tax sharing arrangements when they were introduced in this Parliament in 1975. They were introduced so that those authorities, which have been elected by people, could bear the responsibility for the priorities that they give to their spending areas.

I turn to my own State of New South Wales, and itemise the general purpose revenue grants received by that State. They are contained on page 209 of Budget Paper No. 7. Anyone can see them. In 1977-78 New South Wales, through the tax sharing arrangements, in general purpose revenue grants, received $1,319,609. Yet in 1981-82-this year, four years later-that general purpose revenue sharing arrangement will net for New South Wales $2,535m. That is an increase of just on 100 per cent. The latest figures I can get on road expenditure in New South Wales are for the year 1979-80. We find that expenditure in that year, through the New South Wales Department of Main Roads, was $119.4m. In that same year expenditure on roads by local government totalled $153.5m. So in New South Wales in this particular year a total of $273m was spent on roads. In that year this Federal Government granted to the State for road expenditure just on $117m, which left roughly $100m for the State to finance out of its own sources.

Keeping that in mind, it might be worth while to look at just one statistic-how much New South Wales collected in that year from owners of motor vehicles in State taxes and motor vehicle registration fees. The State is short of about $ 100m over and above our grant yet it collected from owners of motor vehicles in 1979-80 $181.4m. So we have a situation-I have no doubt this happens in other States-where the Federal Government gets the blame for not providing funds for road grants and the State Government of New South Wales is short-changing the motorist by expending on roads not even the total amount of charges it imposes directly on owners of motor vehicles by way of taxes and registration fees on their vehicles. Yet when it cannot perform a task or go ahead with a program it does not tell the public that; it takes the easy way out and blames the Federal Government. It says to the people that it is sorry, but it does not have any money. It is just a farce.

When we talk about road grants it is important that we keep in mind the general purpose revenue grants that I spoke about. In the example I gave from my own State, not only is the New South Wales Government not using on roads any of the increased general purpose revenue grants that come out of tax sharing, which have been increased most generously, but also it is even short-changing the general public on what it receives directly from the motorist. That is the situation we have. Yet people argue that we are not providing sufficient funds for roads. No matter how much we spend on roads, because they are so essential to the country, nothing is sufficient. But, really, the arguments are very unfair. If other members of this Parliament analyse State financial figures further, they will find that the same thing is happening. The States are not pulling their weight and are not accepting their responsibility for the development of roads.

In the few minutes I have left, I would like to shift to the matter of road safety. There is no doubt-the community agrees-that the accidents on our roads are of tremendous cost to this community. Some two years ago, in common with the honourable member for Shortland and the Deputy Opposition Whip, I served on the Standing Committee on Road Safety of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of this Parliament.

—I stand corrected, of this Parliament. I saw statistics on the tremendous, terrible burden on this country that results from the damage to property and people caused by road accidents. Of course, one of the best ways of overcoming this situation is to build better roads. The Government is sympathetic to that concept but, if I may return to the point at which I started , the Government cannot do that alone. It cannot supply all of the funding necessary for such a massive program. State governments must help. Local governments must help. They have the population and resources to gain revenue, with which do these jobs, from those who are the users of the roads. The job of the Federal Government is to top up such funding and to ensure that roads are developed in the remote areas of Australia. As population moves out into those areas through the development of roads and communication there is created in years to come a local basis from which revenue can be obtained to maintain the roads.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Bill as one that is both sensible and adequate. I believe that that is the correct terminology to use in describing it. But we must always bring home to the people of Australia that governments at three levels are responsible for our roads. I refer to the Federal Government, to the various State governments and to the 800 or so local governing authorities. They must all pull their weight. They must stop shovelling the blame on to this Government because what it is doing for our roads, bearing in mind that it is spending the taxpayers' money, is quite adequate. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were asked what I thought was the single most important public works project initiated by the Whitlam Government I would say unhesitatingly the National Roads Act, which specified that a national highway would be built. From 1969 to 1975 I concentrated a large part of my parliamentary career upon highlighting the enormously high rate of death and injury on Australian roads. I constantly reiterated the need to build a national highway linking the major cities of Australia. In 1972, at my instigation, the Australian Labor Party held a road safety conference at Terrigal. Approximately 200 people from all over Australia were present. They heard Mr Whitlam announce that a Labor Government would introduce national highway legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the advent of the Whitlam Government, the practice had been for the Commonwealth to provide substantial amounts of money to the States over roughly five-year periods, under the Commonwealth aid roads legislation. The funds were allocated on a population basis, for the States to do with as they wished. Regrettably, that system led to the funds being used by the States in a pork barrel fashion to dish out benefits to marginal rural areas and thus win votes, rather than build a more efficient and safe road system. This pork barrelling led to a ludicrous situation in which, in rural back blocks, one found superb two-lane roads leading from one small country town to another while the main highways connecting major cities and towns of Australia, on which the greatest amount of traffic occurred, were often little better than goat tracks. I was at a loss to understand how this absurd situation was ever allowed to develop. I have nothing against rural communities having adequate roads but surely if governments are to spend billions of dollars on roads it is logical that their first priority should be with regard to those roads that carry the major share of traffic.

Let us not forget that while the national highways connecting Cairns, Brisbane, Newcastle, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth provided improved motoring and greater safety for city travellers, they also benefit the overwhelming majority of the rural communities which live along them.

The legislation which introduced the national highways sytem in 1974 provided that approximately 30 per cent of funds would be spent on developing a national highway. Because of the considerable engineering planning that was required for major highways the fruits of that legislation are only now becoming evident. I am fairly familiar with at least two sections of the national highway and I want to make special mention of those in this speech.

When I first became a member of this Parliament almost 13 years ago I used to travel from Gosford to Canberra. Apart from the fact that the trip took between 5 1/2 to 6 hours it was at best a dangerous and at worst a nightmarish journey, particularly from Sydney to Canberra. The rural sector of the trip commenced at Liverpool. For the next 150-odd miles it was for the most part a narrow, bumpy, tortuous goat track and one fought to stay on the road against extremely heavy traffic, much of which was semi-trailers. When it was raining one always felt thankful that one had survived the trip. When an accident occurred, as it did with monotonous regularity, the road was often jammed by traffic for a number of hours. The Hume Highway was nototious both for its nightmarish qualities for general driving and the horrific, often multiple, crashes that occurred at frequent intervals. If my recollection is correct, about 90 people were killed every year on the Hume Highway between Liverpool and Albury. I have travelled on the Hume Highway to Goulburn and on the Federal Highway to Canberra on dozens of occasions during the past 13 years. The improvement is dramatic until about 60 kilometres from Canberra. The opening of the 35-kilometre F5 south-western freeway section on 15 December 1980 made it a 40-minute to 45-minute trip from Liverpool to Mittagong and there is an almost uninterrupted four-lane divided expressway from Liverpool to not far from the village of Collector.

Between Sydney and Goulburn there is now, I understand, 198 kilometres of dual carriageway. The saving in time is dramatic. Where once it would have taken 5 1/ 2 hours to 6 hours to travel from Gosford to Canberra the trip can be done comfortably and safely in 4 1/4 hours to 4 1/2 hours. As yet I have been unable to obtain comparative accident figures but I would be surprised if there has not been a significant improvement. Overseas experience shows that when a new expressway, freeway or autobahn replaces a two-lane road there is a 70 per cent to 80 per cent drop in the road toll. Sometimes the figures are confusing because often a new highway will lead to increased speed and of course increased usage. Motorists are often directed to the new highway, resulting in a significant increase in traffic. So at first glance some of the figures, as I said before, may be a little confusing. It is important to note the comments made by the Minister when opening the Campbelltown to Yanderra freeway section. He said.

The cost of this project is in the vicinity of $80m. With the opening of this new section the distance between Liverpool and Mittagong will be reduced by more than 13 kilometres. It is estimated that there will be an overall reduction in excess of 30 minutes in travel time between the two centres-a saving of $13m a year to the community.

The Minister did not indicate whether the $13m saving included accident savings or just fuel and time conservation. However, assuming the $13m a year includes everything it means that the $80m that has been expended on the expressway will be recovered in six years. In economic terms alone, not to mention comfort, time saved and the safety aspect, we can justify very substantial increases in road expenditure. That is the point that I think the honourable member for Barton (Mr Bradfield) missed completely. It is acknowledged by the transport economists that good roads pay for themselves through the reduced consumption of petrol and less depreciation and wear and tear on vehicles.

Finally, let me point out that although the Hume Highway serves the millions of people who live in Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne, it provides the same benefits to all those country residents who live along the route between Sydney and Melbourne as well as many others, such as those who live in the Riverina and southern tablelands who now choose the Hume Highway to travel interstate or intrastate.

I now move to the area which I know best because it is the main route that runs through my electorate of Robertson. When I was first elected as a member of this House in 1969 I represented the area connecting Sydney and Newcastle from the Hawkesbury River to Lake Macquarie. Undeniably it is one of the most beautiful areas in Australia, as indicated by the fact that it is now one of the two major retirement areas in Australia. However, one of the prices which it has to pay for its beauty is the very rugged, almost mountainous, and heavily wooded country that covers at least the southernmost section of the Central Coast.

In the early 1960s the Labor Government of New South Wales announced that it would build a first class inter city expressway linking the cities of Sydney and Newcastle. A start was made in March 1963 and by the time the Labor Government was defeated in 1965 the Sydney and Newcastle expressway was well under way.

The section from the Hawkesbury River to Mount White opened in December 1965 and the section to Calga in 1966. The Hawkesbury to Berowra section was started at the end of 1966 and opened at the end of 1968. The cost was about $40m, which seems remarkably cheap in this day and age, but I remind honourable members that we are talking of prices of nearly 20 years ago. From then until the Askin Liberal Government left office in 1976 the only added work was the erection of a new bridge across the Hawkesbury River. It is to the Askin Government's eternal shame that it virtually abandoned the Sydney-Newcastle expressway, which covered the busiest and one of the most dangerous roads in Australia. The motive was clear. The Government distributed its public works expenditure where it felt it would win it the most votes and not where the funds would contribute to a more efficient and safer road system. It was and remains a scandal.

The advent of a Federal Labor government specifically allocating a proportion of the Commonwealth road grants to a national highway led the New South Wales Liberals to scream like banshees that the Whitlam Government was dictating to them how they could spend their money; their money, mind you! No account was taken of the fact that it was the Commonwealth that had to face the odium of raising the taxes. The cry of the States down through the ages has always been: 'You raise the money in taxes and we will get the credit for how it is spent'. I am not talking just about Labor or Liberal governments. All States love to get the money and to spend it. They love the Federal Parliament to raise the taxes and cop the odium for doing so. To its credit the Whitlam Government, and particularly its courageous Minister for Transport, Mr Charles Jones, held firm. Australia had a responsibility to build a proper national highway system in order to improve driving safety, save lives, benefit tourism, build our defence system and reduce costs to the driver, the consumer and the rural sector.

Starting in 1974, plans previously pigeon-holed were resurrected and a long slow process redesigning the balance of the Sydney-Newcastle expressway began. Finally, in 1977, a start was made on the Ourimbah to Doyalson section. I want to stress how important this section is. It includes a notorious stretch of winding road from Tuggerah to Kangy Angy where some of the worst accidents have occurred with monotonous regularity. Every few months-sometimes every few weeks- one hears that another serious head-on collision has occurred in that short three or four kilometre stretch. In December last year I asked the Department of Main Roads to take me out for a day to inspect the work that it had done and to explain to me the plans for the completion of the balance of the Sydney- Newcastle expressway. The actual roadwork on the Ourimbah-Doyalson stretch is 11 kilometres. That is nearly completed. As I recall there are some seven bridges of varying sizes to be built. It is anticipated that this stretch will be completed some time in 1984.

Work is well advanced in sections of the Ourimbah to Calga strip, particularly in the northern area near Ourimbah around Dog Trap Road. It is a magnificent feat of engineering. I suggest that honourable members who are interested in roads should go and look at what is being done there. This region is not flat open country such as one sees on the Federal Highway on the way to Canberra. It is extremely mountainous with deep gullies and hills that require huge quantities to fill. I was full of admiration for the engineers, workmen and private contractors all of whom are participating in this superb piece of road engineering that will ultimately lead to a magnificent four to six lane highway of approximately 100 kilometres in length, linking the cities of Sydney and New- castle, which is the busiest stretch of intercity highway in Australia.

Prior to the building of the first three sections of the Sydney-Newcastle expressway one had to allow 3 1/2 hours of tortuous, dangerous driving to travel from the Harbour Bridge to Hunter Street, Newcastle. I expect that when the expressway is finally completed the same trip will be done in around 1 1/2 hours and with very little risk of a serious accident. For most of the journey it would be impossible to be involved in the worst type of motor vehicle accident, the head-on collision. If plans go according to Hoyle, the expressway should be completed from Berowra to Doyalson, even to Toronto, by 1987-88. That will be a nice present for the Bicentennial to those who use this highway. I have no information about the proposal to extend the expressway south to Pearce's Corner at Wahroonga, although I understand the Federal Government has committed $60m towards this part of the project. Those who travel on their holidays or travel regularly to work on this road, will know what a nightmare the section to and from Sydney is at weekends, holidays and at peak periods.

That is the good news; now for the bad news. After the State Liberal Government did virtually nothing to advance the expressway during the 11 years it was in government in New South Wales, we now find that the Federal Government, under the stewardship of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), proposes to interfere in the funding provided for the New South Wales Government by directing a large portion of the funds allocated under the National Roads Act away from the Sydney -Newcastle section of the national highway to work on the Hume Highway. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Press release of the Minister of 27 November 1981.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TRANSPORT AUSTRALIANEWS RELEASE

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Statement by the Minister for Transport, Mr Ralph J. Hunt, MP)
The Minister for Transport, Mr Ralph Hunt, has moved to ensure a larger share of National Roads funds is spent on upgrading the Hume Highway between Sydney and the Victorian border.
''I made this decision after reviewing the National Highway construction work priorities outlined by New South Wales in its National Roads program recently submitted for my approval,'' he said.
''The New South Wales Government proposed to commit a disproportionate share of Commonwealth funds to construction of new National Highway works between Sydney and Newcastle.
''In the Commonwealth's view, this diversion of funds would result in an unacceptable slowing down of urgently-needed construction work on the Hume Highway.''

Mr Hunt said he was astonished to see a press report attributed to a senior DMR officer that works on the Hume Highway, in particular the Mittagong/Berrima bypasses, would be set back for an indefinite period-at least 10 years.
Mr Hunt emphasised that since 1974 the Commonwealth had repeatedly stressed its commitment to the continued upgrading of the Hume Highway from Sydney to Melbourne as a matter of high priority.
''Clearly the New South Wales Government no longer considers the Hume Highway is of any great importance'', he said.

''I have already indicated the Commonwealth's dissatisfaction with the proposed New South Wales National Highway program and made it clear that the Commonwealth will not permit such an imbalance in the use of Commonwealth funds by New South Wales.
''Accordingly I have asked the New South Wales Minister for Roads to revise the State program to reflect the Commonwealth's view.

''In the meantime, I have approved only that part of the National Roads program dealing with the Hume Highway and which will allow works already underway on other roads in New South Wales last year to continue.''

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr COHEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The first point I make about this Press release is that it indicates a complete reversal of the philosophy espoused by the Liberal-Country Party coalition when it was in opposition from 1972 to 1975. At that time it villified the Whitlam Government for what it described as gross interference in the States' right to run their own affairs. It was good enough to hurl that sort of abuse at the Whitlam Government in 1975, but in 1982 when it suits the Liberals and the National Country Party to court votes in Federal seats such as Macarthur and Hume it is prepared to direct the New South Wales Government when and how it should build its section of the national highway. The New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs and Minister for Roads, Mr Whelan, has made it clear that if he is forced to accept the demand of the Federal Minister for Transport that funding for the Sydney-Newcastle expressway be cut from 52 per cent to 36 per cent it will lead to vastly increased costs, dislocation of workers, disruption of planning and continued slaughter on the Wyong to Swansea section of the Pacific Highway which, as I said before, is one of the worst stretches of killer road in New South Wales.

INTERJECT.PARA: In conclusion, I make reference to the road toll and the annual hue and cry that erupts each year for something to be done about it. Many members will remember my long involvement in this issue as initiator, member and finally Chairman of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Road Safety, later the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety. In all the brouhaha that goes on in the media about the need to reduce the road toll, it seems to me that the experts-I use the words advisedly-are still not capable of an honest appraisal of what has happened in the past decade or so and of suggesting what approach should be adopted in the future. Two things can be learnt by a close examination of the numbers of Australians killed and injured on the road since 1970. The first is that there has been a reduction of both death and injury in actual terms. When one takes into account the increased number of motor vehicles and drivers the reduction is even more dramatic. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table prepared by the Legislative Research Service showing the number of persons killed and injured from 1970 to 1981.
