INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr COHEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I hope that honourable members will notice that in 1970 the total number of persons killed was 3,798, yet 11 years later the number killed was 3,322, a drop of 476. When one takes into account the very substantial increase in population of about two million, and the even greater increase in the number of vehicles on the road, the number of lives saved is vastly increased. Had Australia gone on killing people on the roads at the same rate as in 1970 the number of people being killed now would almost certainly have reached 6,000 per annum. Evidence of an improved position in real terms is illustrated by the figures in the column on the right which shows the number of people killed per 10,000 vehicles. In 1970 the number was eight. In 1980, the last figure available, it was four.

INTERJECT.PARA: If one were to examine further the figures indicating the types of persons killed according to how they travel one would see that in 1970 the numbers of people killed in different categories were as follows: Drivers and passengers, 2 ,693; pedestrians, 822; motor cyclists, 173; cyclists, 98; and others, 12. In 1981 the figures were as follows: Drivers and passengers, 2,130; pedestrians, 644; motor cyclists, 390; cyclists, 93; and others, 15. If one examines those figures one will notice that the number of drivers and passengers killed dropped by nearly 600, despite a massive increase in the number of people on the road and the number of miles driven. The big increase, of course, is in the number of motor cyclists killed. The number has gone up from 170 to 390.

I would like to spend a great deal more time on this matter. I am not trying to give the impression to this Parliament that we should be complacent about the road toll-of course not. Until those figures are reduced to a fraction of what they are now we should keep on trying. But I wish that those people who write about and comment on the road toll would at least get their facts right. There is no magic formula for reduction of the road toll. Anyone who has been involved with it for long periods will know that. A whole range of measures have to be assessed on a cost-benefit basis. Improved roads are clearly a major source of saving but, of course, a very costly source. We need improved roadside furniture and continued improvement in vehicle design.

The last figures I saw showed that 80 per cent of people wore seat belts but that the 20 per cent who did not were providing 80 per cent of those killed. In this country we have never looked at the matter of air bags. In some States we have not yet seriously got down to the problem of looking at how we could stop the drunks getting on the roads. Unfortunately my time is running out. I would have liked to spend more time on this problem because it has been of interest to me for many years. I just say that there is no magic formula. The problem cannot be solved by sensational headlines and clever editorials.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dean Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In beginning my contribution to tonight's debate I want to take up the concluding comments from the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) and thank him for his contribution because I think he made a quite important point. It is all too easy for commentators of one sort or another to say that the basic problem of the road toll and the road accident level is the condition of the roads. As the honourable member for Robertson said, of course the condition of the roads is a factor in the whole road toll and road accident level problem. But he did add other factors which I think are important and which ought to be emphasised. For instance, he talked about seat belt enforcement. Fortunately in Queensland it has been law for quite a number of years now that people should wear seat belts, but even there I am afraid that often the simple fact of the importance of wearing seat belts is not emphasised enough and is not enforced.

SPEECH.PARA: He talked about the possible investigation of the use of air bags. I know that early experiments with air bags in the United States of America, in fact, inconclusive but I know also that there have been scientific advances since those days. Yes, the matter ought to be looked at again. The honourable member did not name random breath testing in his concluding remarks. He may have earlier in his speech, but again it is an area that ought to be seriously looked at by all the States as well as the Commonwealth. It is not good enough for Queensland, for example, simply to say: 'Our way of doing it is good enough. It is efficient enough. We do not need to look at random breath testing'. The road toll over the last Easter weekend is enough to require any State government to think very seriously indeed about introducing random breath testing.

Of those points the honourable member for Robertson raised I would finally mention the whole problem of driver testing in Australia. I believe driver testing, preparation of using vehicles on the road, is simply inadequate in all States and the Commonwealth. I know that there is a resource problem in providing a better system of driver testing. But if we are to be serious about the road toll and the road accident level we have to be serious about driver testing. I hope that the Commonwealth and all the States will be prepared to take a fresh look at that problem and do something about it, not just talk about it. I fully endorse the comments of the honourable member for Robertson in saying that when looking at the road accident problem of Australia today we have to look not only at the condition of roads but also at all the factors which involve the driving of vehicles on roads. We have to be much more serious about all those factors than I think we are currently.

I support the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982. One has to support it if for no other reason, of course, than to make sure that the money is there to be spent. That is what this Bill will do; it will ensure that during 1982, 1983 and beyond moneys will be appropriated to continue the work on Australia's road systems. However, in supporting the Bill I point to three general areas in which, in my view, there are deficiencies and at which I hope the Government will take a fresh look to re-examine its priorities. The first point to which I will address myself flows from the 1979 report of the Bureau of Transport Economics. That report was entitled 'An Assessment of the Australian Road System' and it makes some interesting findings about deficiencies in the funding of road projects in Australia. Secondly, I will draw again from other reports concerning the problem of inflation. The overall level of inflation in Australia is probably running at about 9 per cent, but road construction cost inflation has been running at a far higher rate. We have not so far adequately provided for that. The third area that I wish to address myself to concerns the national highways system and, in particular, the Bruce Highway, Highway 1, in my State of Queensland.

Let me start with the 1979 report of the BTE, 'An Assessment of the Australian Road System'. Two important facts come from that report. The first is that in terms of economically efficient allocations for the period 1974-75 to 1978-79, compared with those allocations actually made, there was underexpenditure on all roads in Queensland. In other words, whether we are talking about Commonwealth funding or State funding-the provision of funds by all levels of government-the fact remains that in Queensland in that period there was underexpenditure on all roads. I hope that the Queensland Minister for Main Roads, who is very fond of ticking off the Federal Government for its deficiencies, will take note of that point and recognise that it is not just a Commonwealth failing.

The second point which flows from that assessment is that in carving up the available Commonwealth cake of funds the Commonwealth is still adhering to a formula which is some seven or eight years old. Taking into account developments in the nation, the more accelerated growth in Queensland, Queensland's own special features, which include its decentralised nature-it being, apart from Tasmania, the most decentralised State in the nation-we can see that that seven to eight-year-old formula is simply no longer doing justice to Queensland. That flows very strongly from that 1979 BTE report. Underexpenditure in Queensland, exacerbated by the use of that formula, deprives Queensland as against other eastern mainland States. I therefore say to the Government that while, of course , one must support this Roads Grants Amendment Bill for the sake of getting money to be spent on roads, one also has to say that one is disappointed that the formula has not been re-examined. One is forced to say that that formula-the way in which the national highway funds cake is divided-must in all equity be re -examined as a matter of urgency.

It is not easy to use actual figures to prove the point, but let me use one set of figures which, while it does not necessarily prove the point, at least illustrates that there is this misallocation in the division of the existing road funds. If we take the three mainland Eastern States we will see that Victoria-a very small State geographically-received this financial year for spending on its national highway system something like $77,000 a kilometre. New South Wales this financial year received something like $78,000 a kilometre for spending on the national highways. Queensland received only $15,000 a kilometre for spending on its national highway system. As I say, that does not necessarily prove the point because road usage needs in Victoria and New South Wales are obviously far greater than road usage needs on, say, the Landsborough highway of middle Queensland. But the figures at least illustrate that there is a misallocation. They illustrate that that seven-year-old or eight-year-old formula is no longer a fair way of distributing the national road funding cake throughout at least the Eastern States.

I move from there to talk about the problem of inflation as it affects road construction throughout the nation. A study was carried out recently entitled ' National Highway Deficiencies and Road Funding Strategies'. It has been considered by Commonwealth and State transport Ministers. This study has drawn two major conclusions. First of all, there is a need for funds to be made available for national highways to be increased significantly if deficiencies in the system are to be overcome within a reasonable period. Secondly, the report indicates that a 25 per cent increase in the present level of national road funds would need to be maintained up to the year 2000 to bring the national highway system up to a minimum standard. In other words those two major conclusions-they relate to the national highways system in Australia, not to all the other road categories we are aware of-point to the fact that our road funding is not keeping pace with inflation in terms of the costs of building roads.

Let me relate those two major points to a recently prepared Bureau of Transport Economics report entitled 'Road Construction Price Indices 1969-70 to 1980-81'. This report was tabled here on 16 March this year. It includes road construction price indices for each of the 11 years in that period, as well as annual percentage increases. It can be seen from that report that the road construction price index has increased by 208 per cent in the seven-year period 1974-75 to 1980-81. In the same period, Commonwealth road grants to the States and the Northern Territory have increased by only 172 per cent. In other words, in terms only of coping with the inflationary cost of building roads in that seven-year period we have fallen behind in providing funds, from that 208 per cent cost increase level to an actual 172 per cent provision of funds level. That is a serious problem.

Putting my remarks on a rather more simple footing, the Bill that we are currently considering seeks to provide in the 1982-83 financial year some 7 per cent increase in funds when compared with what was provided in 1981-82. The figures suggest that the road building cost increase over that same period is double that figure. We are simply not providing enough funds at the national government level-I have already made the point that the other levels of government have to accept responsibility as well-to cover even the inflation component of road building costs. I was pleased to notice that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) indicated in his second reading speech that the Government will be examining in the Budget context the scope to provide additional road funds so as at least to cope with the inflation problem. In my speech tonight I can only emphasise the need for the Government to do that and to make provision in this area.

I have no special magic wand to wave when it comes to finding extra money. Of course it is difficult to provide more money in one area as against any other area in a Commonwealth Budget. Of course all of us want to see taxes come down rather than go up. But the fact remains that we have a problem in providing adequately for the road system of this nation. Where we find that increases in funding are not keeping pace even with the cost of building roads, let alone with the cost of improving roads in real terms for the future, we have to think drastically about our priorities and we have to think drastically about the provision of funds for road construction.

My third major point, as I indicated at the outset, relates to the Bruce Highway in Queensland. Of all the national highways in this nation the Bruce Highway is one of the longest-it is not the longest but certainly it is one of the longest-and in many respects one of the most important. It is important not just in road usage terms. I have already admitted, for example, that the Hume Highway in New South Wales and Victoria would have a greater claim to being important in road usage terms. But the Bruce Highway is certainly important in terms of many other factors which include access for visitors who want to travel to different parts of Australia, particularly to north Queensland. Those factors also include decentralisation. Queensland is the most decentralised of the mainland States. The northern Queensland stretch of Australia is populated by people who live in a large number of developed towns and cities and who are involved in a lot of resource and other development in this nation. Also, northern Australia has a defence importance which is highlighted by the fact that Lavarack Barracks is located in Townsville, my own city. If we are to ensure, at least in peacetime, adequate mobility for defence training and capability we have to consider the need for an adequate highway system. So when we take all of these factors into account we have to conclude that the Bruce Highway in Queensland, and in northern Queensland in particular, is one of the most significant national highways in Australia.

Unfortunately, that highway is remarkably deficient. On Sunday of this week I had the experience of having to drive my vehicle though hip-high water in order to return to my home city of Townsville so that I could come to this place to contribute in this debate tonight. I did not like driving through that sort of water, but it had to be done. It is not good enough to say: 'Don't drive in the wet'. The fact remains that some people have to drive in such conditions. This does not occur only north of the Tully River stretch where I was faced with this problem on Sunday. There are many parts of the Bruce Highway in north Queensland where, when it rains, the roads are flooded. The roads are flooded at different times of the year. This is simply not good enough having regard to the factors I have already mentioned: decentralisation, defence, development and tourism. In addition, the Bruce Highway in north Queensland in many stretches is narrow, rough and old; it cries out for reconstruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Narrow bridges.
—Narrow bridges are a very great problem and there are many of them. There are about 37 single lane wooden bridges between Mackay and Tully. Part of that is in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government accepts 100 per cent responsibility for the funding of acceptable projects on the Bruce Highway and other national highway systems. However, a new and exciting development came about some six to eight weeks ago when in my company and in the company of Senator Collard and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the State Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, Mr Hinze and the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) travelled part of the Bruce Highway system. As a result of that the Ministers jointly announced a Commonwealth-State study of the Brisbane to Cairns national highway. That study, firstly, will formulate a plan for the necessary construction and associated funding to upgrade the highway to an acceptable standard in 10 years. Secondly, the State Minister, Mr Hinze, offered to seek an injection of State funds if the Commonwealth also provides additional funds for the highway. This is an exciting development. We are entitled to be cynical. We have heard enough in the past about the road being done up, but progress is too slow. At least now a definitive study will be undertaken. It is exciting that within a stated achievable period something better will be done for the Bruce Highway in north Queensland. If the study produces a report it will be worthy of support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very appropriate that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are sitting in the chair tonight while this debate is taking place. You , Mr Deputy Speaker, were the Minister for Transport in the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975 and were responsible for introducing new innovations in the funding of roads. Of course, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean) has been talking about one of those programs-the national roads program. I should also like to commend the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) for his contribtion to this debate. For many years he has been interested in road safety and has been highly involved in the Standing Committee on Road Safety. I thought that his contribution was quite good.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris ). I think the guts of the amendment need to be emphasised. In part, the amendment states:
(1) reduce the backlog of established roads needs;
(2) accelerate the rate of road construction and maintenance works;
(3) improve the efficiency of road transport services;
(4) reduce the incidence of road deaths and injuries, and
(5) assist local government bodies to meet road funding difficulties.

I feel that the honourable member for Herbert should support the amendment. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) also made a contribution to this debate tonight, and I feel that he should support the Opposition's amendment. Both of those honourable members represent country electorates. Their electorates are getting a raw deal similar to the raw deal that I feel the large country electorates are getting. I refer particularly to my electorate of Grey. Comments of the honourable member for Herbert in relation to the road program of the present Government were reported in a Townsville newspaper.

I feel that the amendment should have the support of all honourable members, especially National Country Party members who face these problems in some of the electorates around Australia. National Country Party members often complain about the raw deal their electorates are getting. For that reason I say that they should support the Opposition's amendment. I appreciate their feelings because I represent a large electorate. My electorate runs into problems just as do all large electorates which contain large undeveloped areas in which there is a need to provide roads. This places a great strain on the funds available to local government.

Quite recently I was able to attend a meeting of the Eyre Peninsula Local Government Association in South Australia, which represents a fairly large part of that State. There was also a meeting in another part of the electorate last week, which unfortunately, I was not able to attend but at which, I understand, the matter of roads was raised. At the Eyre Peninsula Local Government Association meeting the agenda item which received the most attention was, of course, that dealing with roads. I have 23 local government bodies in my electorate and they are all complaining about roads. That emphasises the problems that these bodies face. They are all in trouble over roads and they are looking for greater support from the Government.
The Minister said this in his second reading speech:

The amounts to be provided in the next three years involve annual increases of 7 per cent in 1982-83, 6 per cent in 1983-84 and 6 per cent in 1984-85. All States and the Northern Territory have been allocated corresponding annual increases in funding. As a result the 1981-82 funding relativities will be maintained through to 1984-85.

When we look at the percentage of the increase-7 per cent for the current year, 6 per cent for next year and 6 per cent for the year after-we see that the increases are dropping well behind requirements.

The South Australian allocation for 1981-82 is $56.302m. For 1982-83 it rises to $60.327m, for 1983-84 it rises to $63.943m and for 1984-85 it rises to $67. 807m. When we work out the relativities, we see that the figures stick closely to what the Minister said-that is, for South Australian increases of 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 6 per cent. All States are treated the same, with the result that many are crying out for greater assistance.

At a recent local government association meeting in Adelaide problems of local government were raised and certain indications were given. As we all know, quite recently the Bureau of Transport Economics issued a road construction price index. That index demonstrated a road construction price escalation of 15.3 per cent in 1981, following a 15.9 per cent increase in the previous year. South Australia is disadvantaged in its part of the road funding cake. For example-I do not want to appear too parochial-South Australia has 9.7 per cent of the vehicle population, 9.7 per cent of kilometres travelled, 12.2 per cent of the length of roads, 15.5 per cent of the land area and 9.3 per cent of the total population, yet it receives only 8.2 per cent of the Commonwealth road funds. As was pointed out at that meeting, the fact that the Australian National Railways Commission is at present in the process of closing down country railway services means a greater emphasis is being placed on roadways and greater strains are being placed on local governments and State governments in providing funds for those roads. The meeting went on to record:

More importantly, South Australian local government is now spending an increasingly higher proportion of its total revenue on roads. For example, in 1979-80 16.8 per cent of local government revenue was expended on roads. In 1981 -82 (the latest figures available) this proportion has risen to 21.2 per cent-a significant increase.
With a 15.3 per cent increase in the cost of road construction in the last year, if local government is in any way to maintain its road services it must put more and more of its money into that area.

Much has been said tonight in criticism of the Whitlam Government. The honourable member for Lyne was fairly strong in his criticism of what the Whitlam Government did in road works. As I have said, during the 1972-75 era of the Whitlam Government, the present occupant of the chair introduced legislation for the national roads program, something which has been of great benefit to the nation and the individual States. One other significant project introduced at that time was the Minor Traffic Engineering and Road Safety Improvements Program . It gave a lot of assistance to local government and state governments in overcoming some of those problems that they all strike, such as the necessity to provide traffic lights and channelling where they are required, as well as the carrying out of other minor traffic engineering projects. Unfortunately the present Government has done away with that program, with the result that the States have to fund all those works from their own resources.

Earlier in the evening it was said that we should use private contractors for our road works. I think anyone would say that the roads built in South Australia by the Highways Department are of extremely high quality. An officer of this House said to me once after having taken a trip to Perth, that driving over South Australian roads was a pleasure; they were beautiful roads and a credit to the people who built them. In most cases the credit can be taken by the South Australian Highways Department. This fad for making sure all this work goes to private contractors could be a fallacy. A number of road projects have been carried out in my electorate. I remember two. One was the sealing of the Flinders Highway from Port Lincoln to Ceduna. The work reached a certain stage and the contractor went bankrupt. The State was left more or less holding the baby. It did not have the finance to finish the job started by the private contractor, with the result that that road had to wait until finance was available. If my memory serves me right, two contractors building the section of road between Port Augusta and Whyalla went broke. We are not against the use of private contractors but we should be making more use of State government highway authorities and local government people, because they have the expertise in roads and are the most competent to carry out this work.

The honourable member for Lyne criticised the Whitlam Government but later said that local government authorities were now able to pick up the untied grants under the arrangements with the Federal Government. We must remember that for 23 years Liberal-Country Party governments gave absolutely nothing to local government. The Whitlam Government introduced Federal funds for local government . However the formula has since changed. People who condemn that Government should at least acknowledge that it recognised the financial problems of local government and commenced those grants to local government bodies. I hope that those people who criticise the government of those years take those factors into consideration.

Mention was made of the amounts that will be allocated over the next three years. It is expected that for 1982-83 the Government will pick up $4,300m in revenue from petrol taxes and levies, et cetera. Yet, it will allocate only $ 734m under this program. I am certainly not one who says that taxation picked up in a particular area should be spent in that area. If that were the case, we could say that the people who are taxed on tobacco could expect bigger and better public ashtrays. I feel that because of the need for road works the States and local government should expect a higher proportion of the money raised in petrol tax to go into our road works programs.

I understand that everyone has been asked to cut short their speeches so that more people can join in the debate. I wanted to say a few more things about national highways, but I conclude by again recommending the amendment to the House. I suggest that we look at what we can expect if we allocate more of our finances to roads. With better roads we reduce fuel consumption. We lower hospital and medical costs because, one would hope, there are fewer accidents. Some of the reasons for that conclusion were given by the honourable member for Robertson earlier. Also, better roads facilitate the movement of goods, et cetera, to market and promote tourism. They improve communications between all parts of the country, cut down the massive repair bills and lower insurance costs. Again, better roads lessen wear and tear on machinery and parts, whether owned privately or commercially, provide employment and conserve precious energy resources. I conclude on that point but again urge honourable members, particularly those who represent country electorates, to support the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with many other speakers in this debate, I acknowledge that the funds provided to the States for roads are insufficient and probably never will be sufficient. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) acknowledged that in his second reading speech. We all sincerely hope that we will see a higher priority accorded to road funding in the forthcoming Budget. There is no doubt that, apart from the use of our roads for general purposes, our defence roads system is in a state of disrepair. I need hardly mention the benefits that better roads bring to the general economy, to tourism and to recreation, or the very essential point that good roads keep people in the country, where much of Australia's income is produced and its rural and mining industries are to be found. Having acknowledged that point, I wish to direct the bulk of my remarks to the subject of road safety.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been very disturbing to see, in recent weeks particularly in my home State of Queensland, so many people come out to blame on the state of the roads the high accident rate that has been so much in the news. I regret to say that many of those who have been making such remarks and trying to score political points should know better and, in fact, do. I include in that number the Minister for Main Roads in Queensland. The state of the roads is one factor contributing to road accidents; there are many others. They can usually be grouped in twos or threes and are seldom to be found on their own. I have in mind speed, drink, the overloading of vehicles, vehicles that are not roadworthy and weather. But the two greatest problems, on any statistical basis that one might like to name or produce, are speed and the effect of drinking taken together.

It seems almost not worth mentioning, but a fact that is always overlooked when people are casting around for a place to lay the blame is that it is drivers who cause accidents. Sooner or later we have to take responsibility for our own actions. That comes back essentially to the driver who is in charge of the vehicle.

Having said that, it is heartening to reflect, as other speakers have done, that the figures concerning Australian road accidents are not all gloomy. In 1979-80 accidents involving casualties numbered some 70,000. If one establishes some sort of ratio between accidents and vehicles one notes that there are 7,500 ,000 vehicles, or almost one for every two people. Thus, the ratio was one accident for each 108 vehicles, but in 1974-75 it was one accident to 98 vehicles. When we consider that and other factors, the ratio is seen as coming down, which is a very heartening sign. For example, in 1960 some 2,468 persons, or 8.8 per 10,000 vehicles, were killed on our roads. In 1980, 20 years later, unfortunately 3,272 people were killed. But at that time the ratio of fatalities per ten thousand vehicles was 4.3, less than half the 1960 figure. So the ratio is down but I regret that it is still not as good as it is in other developed countries, for example the United Kingdom, the United States of America or Canada.

The big drop in those ratios started in 1970 and although it is impossible to prove conclusively there must be some correlation between the figures for 1970 and the fact that that year seat belts were generally introduced in this country . I mention seat belts because now all too often people throw up their hands and say: 'Well, there is nothing we can do about our road accident figures'. The fact is that there is something that we can do and something must be done. If we are going to throw up our hands and walk away from the problem, that is hardly the action of any responsible government, State or Federal.

In 1980, to illustrate the extent of the problem as it is with us now, some 90, 000 people were injured on our roads. There were 32,000 people admitted to hospital. There were 3,200 road fatalities. It is beyond me how anyone can walk away from those sorts of figures.

In the last 10 years nearly 40,000 Australians have died on the roads and an estimated one million have been injured. Having said that, what is the first thing we can do. I suggest that the first thing to be done is that those States which do not have random breath testing should seriously consider its introduction. I know it is controversial. There is a good deal of talk about civil liberties, the unpopularity of it in electoral terms and many statements have been made that it does not work. All the evidence that I have been able to collect indicates that in fact it does work and that it is a great deterrent. The principle of random breath testing is supported by the Federal Government, the Victorian Government and the South Australian and Northern Territory Governments and ironically by the Queensland National Party which is somewhat at odds with some of its own Ministers. I do urge those States that have not introduced random breath testing at least to try it. South Australia, I understand, has introduced it for a three-year trial period. The States should at least try it and see what is the end result. We cannot accept the toll as it is. Fifty per cent of all road fatalities involve alcohol. Approximately 30 per cent of all road injuries involve alcohol. Each year in Australia some 250 to 300 quadriplegics and paraplegics come off our roads because of road accidents. Hundreds of millions of dollars are spent on health costs and on pensions for people injured on our roads, not to mention of course the personal suffering that is caused. In Victoria in 1960 there were 1,061 deaths on the road. In 1980 there were 657. That is a decrease of 404 or 38 per cent. That is a most significant figure. It seems to me to be common sense to try random breath testing but it does not make any sense at all to reject it by saying that the evidence is not available.

As to other actions that could be taken, I would encourage governments to make closer checks on truck drivers logs to ensure that they do not drive for long periods without some sort of adequate rest because all the evidence shows that truck accidents are caused not only by speed by also mainly by fatigue. I would also urge a closer check to be made on some trucking companies which set impossible times for their drivers to meet. It is no wonder, when one looks at some of these times, that accidents occur which are caused by fatigue. I now turn to motor cycles. A motor cyclist in Australia is at something like seven times greater risk than the driver of a motor car. Tougher tests should be implemented for obtaining motor cycle licences. Motor cyclists should not be allowed to be in charge of very powerful machines on the roads until they have proved that they can drive. This simply means that the States should set aside pieces of land where people can learn to ride and be tested before they are given licences to ride on the roads.

The third suggestion I would make to try to cut down the road toll would be to increase the number of police highway patrols. It seems to me that police patrols must be one of the greatest deterrents to people who are driving unsafely on the roads. I would strongly support the States looking at the provision of special traffic police-highway patrols, if you like-on our highways . The presence of specialist patrols would free other police to attend to more important anti-crime duties. I am not denying the importance of adequate road funding-it is vital to this country, and I look forward to seeing a higher priority placed on it in the coming Budget-but tonight I am more concerned with road safety. Our casualty figures are declining in relative terms, but we cannot afford to neglect them. We should be trying to reduce the figures further. I utterly reject the suggestion that comes forward time and again that the condition of the roads is solely responsible for the casualty rate on our roads.

Briefly, I turn to another matter but it is related to this subject. I refer to the state of the roads in northern New South Wales and the roads which lead towards my electorate of McPherson. I urge the New South Wales Government to look at the problem which exists in this area. Northern New South Wales is experiencing a boom but it will strangle itself if the roads are not improved. The boom will fizzle out. Some 80 per cent of tourists to the Gold Coast arrive by road. A lot of them come from the south. I have no doubt that the New South Wales Government will say that insufficient Federal funds are provided. I point out that specific purpose grants for roads are made only to supplement general purpose grants which are given to the States. These general purpose grants can be used as the States wish. In the whole question of road funding this point is too often conveniently ignored by the States. I suggest to the Federal Government that it seriously consider the option of including road grants in general purpose grants, taking into account the mileage of roads in particular States, the area of the State, the population, et cetera, and abolishing the special purpose grants so that the States can spend money as they wish. It is time to consider this option. I believe it should be considered before the Budget is brought down this coming August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very interesting debate and a large number of people have taken part. I am sure that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), if he were here, would be pleased at the support that has been forthcoming. I am quite certain that we would be able to give him more support if a more satisfactory increase were being allocated. If funds were to be increased to such an extent that they were keeping pace with the needs of State and local government there would be no reason for us to propose the amendment which we have moved. Yet, as the Minister knows, the circumstances make it necessary for us to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Back in those halcyon days of the Labor Government, the Hayden Budget of 1975- 76 allocated 30 per cent of all road funds while the States and local government allocated 31 per cent and 28.9 per cent respectively. The situation now is that these percentages have changed and have changed dramatically. The Federal Government's allocation in 1980-81 was only 22.2 per cent. It appears then that it is the deliberate policy of the Fraser Government to reduce its responsibility for the nation's roads. The devolution of responsibility to the States and to local government is exceedingly reprehensible when we consider the implications. For instance, when roads continue to deteriorate someone has to pick up the tab. We know who that is. In all cases this must result in increased taxes and rate charges or a reduction in other services.

What is more reprehensible is the fact that, as the Commonwealth has reduced its commitment to roads as a significant priority, it has gained enormous revenue from its fuel pricing policies. I am sure that has been detailed elsewhere in this debate. In the same time the Federal road grants to the States , as a proportion of Commonwealth revenue from fuel taxes, has fallen from 53.9 per cent to an estimated 16.1 per cent in 1981-82. Since road construction costs have continued to rise at a rate far in excess of these reimbursement increases, the inevitable result is a rapidly accumulating backlog of essential road works due to a lack of sufficient funds. It is not generally realised that the gradual deterioration of Australian roads is reaching that stage where it will take gargantuan steps to arrest the decline and a mammoth program to improve them.

Owing to the neglect by the Federal Government and unfortunately that senile and incompetent state of the late unlamented Liberal Government in Victoria, the funds allocated to the Country Roads Board in the State have dropped by 22 per cent in real terms over the past decade. It is no wonder that the Victorian people decided to throw out the Thompson Government and replace it with a Labor government. There appears to be no co-ordinated plan but a sad history of ad hoc decision-making in response to the pressures of external interest groups. What resulted was a great deal of confusion and illfitting policies. The deregulation of the road transport industry by the Thompson Government has caused an enormous increase in heavy road transport in Victoria.
The shire engineer in my electorate of Ballarat pointed out the problems encountered at the work face that are just not fully understood adequately in Canberra. He said:

The maintenance of the exisiting road network asset is falling further behind due to decreasing funds in real terms being made available to Council. Inevitably, the road surfaces will become irreparable, and the costs of total reconstruction will be unable to be funded by Council or the Government.

Once again the unco-ordinated policies of the previous Victorian Government are evident. We have been required to cut down on the amount of time we have for our speeches in this debate, so I will limit what I have to say about that matter.

I think it is certainly a matter of great relief to all Victorians to have a different kind of government and one which will initiate plans to upgrade VicRail. This will help by taking some of the burden off the State's deteriorating road system. It seems almost incomprehensible that a government that had been receiving less and less funding from the Federal Government should have encouraged the growth of heavy transport traffic on Victorian roads. The axle loading of those vehicles is up to over 2,000 times that of a family car. It has been shown by tests undertaken in the United States of America that the effect of increased truck traffic can be catastrophic on roads that were never intended for that purpose. The tests showed that the effect-that is the damage- imposed by heavy loads on the loaded wheel is generally proportional to the fourth power of the load. The import of this fact is simple and dramatic. It really means that there is a much heavier burden placed upon the roads by laden trucks than by the family car. Obviously the Federal Government has failed to give the maintenance of an adequate road system a sufficiently high priority in recent years.

I find the current Minister for Transport a particularly pleasant and congenial man but I believe he has to make far more determined efforts to get the required funding. In fact it was stated, I think by the honourable member for Bradfield ( Mr Connolly), that it was not true that the States were receiving less money for road grants. That is just not so. If he were to refer to page 214 instead of 209 of Budget Paper No. 1 he would realise that the allocation to the States and local government in tied and untied grants was only 8.2 per cent more than last year. This is far less than the rate of inflation. As I indicated, heavy transport places a particularly heavy burden upon the roads. As I have said, I find the current Minister a particularly pleasant person but he must work much harder to ensure that the Government takes him seriously. The demands that have been placed upon our roads have outstripped the capacity of many of the States and local governments to be able to improve the standards, so they have declined .

The increase in the work load on roads has taken place without substantive recognition by the Federal Government in the form of increased funding. The increase in funding necessary for the maintenance and construction of roads, to keep pace with the increased wear and tear expected to be caused by heavier traffic usage, is far in excess of that which has been allocated. Without looking at the increase in the cost of maintenance et cetera as a result of escalating prices, we can easily see that road maintenance costs are now quite prohibitive for State and local governments.

In Victoria we are concerned that in 1980-81 the total revenue of the Country Roads Board increased by approximately 8 per cent over the preceding year while the Board's direct works and salary prices index rose by approximately 15 per cent.

Over the past decade the cost of road construction has increased by about 15 per cent per annum. This means that there is a doubling of road construction costs every year, yet the CRB revenue is expected to increase this year by only 6 per cent. How on earth can we expect to meet the need when there could be at least a 15 per cent increase in maintenance costs and road construction costs? In my electorate of Ballarat there has been a reduction in the number of outdoor staff which has been added to the already higher than average rate of unemployment in the area. The decrease in real terms in the allocation for road funding has another very serious effect.

Both the Federal Government and the previous Liberal Government in Victoria must shoulder a fair proportion of the onerous responsibility of endangering Victorian lives because of the deteriorating state of roads in that State. That this will be so is made quite clear in dramatic terms when it is considered that the funds allocated to the CRB have dropped 22 per cent in real terms in the past decade while there has been an increase of 66 per cent in road traffic in that time. It is an appalling state of affairs. It will be obvious that many of the roads are aging. Without adequate attention the deterioration must actually make them potentially unsafe instruments for people to drive on. I have indicated that I believe the Federal Government and the former State Government must share the blame. I quote from a letter from Mr Robin Nuttall, the city engineer for the city of Ballarat. He says, inter alia:
. . . there were many ways of presenting statistical comparisons of Federal, State and local government spending on roads . . .
But the over-riding fact remained that real expenditure on roads was consistently diminishing.
Road pavements would be rebuilt once in 50 to 100 years when the design life was about 20 years and the real life could be as low as 15 years.

A point Mr Nuttall made demonstrates how farcical is the Federal Government's concern for matters such as road safety. His point supports my earlier contention. He points out that while finance has been reduced in real terms the ousted Victorian Government lifted the restrictions on road freight, lifted the upper limits of axle loads and reduced rail services. I must make a couple of comments in relation to the remarks of an earlier speaker. A few months ago I had the pleasure of paying a short visit to Townsville which is situated in the federal electorate of Herbert. I experienced at first hand the appalling state of the road system leading to and from that beautiful city. It is nothing short of a national scandal that a city such as Townsville which is working with great diligence to increase its industries, including the tourist industry, is treated so shabbily by the Federal Government. The people of the area are as one in condemning the Federal Government for its lack of apparent interest in the problem of inadequate roads in north Queensland. Given that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean) has recently evinced some interest in the problem, I hope that he will demonstrate his concern by voting for this amendment. In what was possibly an exercise in amateur theatrics, he recently appeared in an act with the Minister for Transport, a notorious member of the Queensland Parliament, Mr Hinze, and a number of other folk.

The honourable member for Herbert has indicated his concern even more recently. He is on record in the Townsville Daily Bulletin of 3 April as having said that this legislation will do no more than allow for the provision of moneys already committed by the Commonwealth Government. His performance tonight will be watched very carefully by the people of his electorate. Knowing how the concern for improved roads transcends party divisions and divisions among all sections of the community there, I am sure that the people of Townsville and the surrounding districts will be expecting a sign of genuine interest in their welfare from their local member. Amateur theatrics will not suffice. As I said before, I therefore invite him to vote for the amendment.

The increased allocation of funds to meet the needs of the nation's roads is a matter of real urgency. The funds allocated in this Bill are obviously inadequate. I urge all honourable members, especially those in rural and provincial areas, to support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) and to demonstrate that this great national asset should receive the attention it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Roads Grants Amendment Bill I recognise that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, were responsible for roads throughout Australia in your term as Minister for Transport. I understand that in that time national roads were declared a Commonwealth responsibility following lead-up work by previous parliaments. This responsibility has continued. In that way the Commonwealth had to accept national highways in the state in which they were in 1974. I think it must be recognised that some of the highways throughout the nation then were in fairly good condition. In other States priorities had been given to services other than highway construction. In those instances, the highways were not so great. Mr Deputy Speaker, I make the point that it was in your term of office that Commonwealth responsibility for the national highway system came into being. That was the state of the national highways at that time .

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken of the road situation in Queensland many times in this House in past years. Today I have a further opportunity to press the real needs of my State in that regard. The Bill before us allocates funds for roads throughout Australia in the four years from 1981-82 to 1984-85 with a total indexed amount for the first year at 7 per cent and for the following two years at 6 per cent, amounting to $3,022m. The funds allocated for national highways for those four years amount to $1,336m. The Commonwealth is totally responsible for that category of roads. The balance of the funds to aid the States is for State and local government roads. I believe that the method of allocation is too indefinite. While the Commonwealth allocates funds to assist in the building and maintenance of State and local roads it must then bear the burden of the criticism which follows from all State and local parties that the blame for the deficiency in road building and maintenance in these other categories can be laid at the door of the Commonwealth. While the Commonwealth's percentage of road funding continues to diminish this criticism will appear to gain additional validity.

There is no doubt that the Commonwealth has to bear responsibility for national highways. I have never avoided this responsibility as a member of parliament. Constituents must realise that the States and local government are also responsible for their roads. For this purpose, they have taxing and rating arrangements in addition to grants and tax-sharing arrangements which allow additional funds from the Commonwealth to be used according to the priorities of those involved at those levels of State and local government. The Bill should help in this understanding by making State road funds subject to the same block grant as applies to health and local government grants. Local government bodies should have their allocations washed through the purer waters of the State grants commissions and not through the sullied waters of the State Treasuries. I believe that if we were able to allocate road funds to local councils in the same way as we allocate the 2 per cent share of funds for local government that would be a better way to get money from the Commonwealth to local government.

I firmly believe that before this occurs a formula for distribution of funds to States, including funds for national highways, should be established which takes into account all relevant road construction needs in addition to population. Such a formula should include lengths, developments, industries, weather, costs in the country-all the matters that such a formula should take into account. I take this matter a little further and draw honourable members' attention to the 1979 assessment made by the Bureau of Transport Economics. In particular, I refer to table 6.19 at page 153 of part 1 of that assessment. It does not argue for grants in excess of those given between 1974-75 and 1978-79. It merely shows the distribution among the States of funds available.

It shows that funds available at 1971-72 prices, if appropriated on an economically efficient road expenditure basis, would have given Queensland $213m more of the $2,125m available from 1974-75 to 1978-79. The actual funds given to Queensland were $410 instead of the $623m arrived at in the assessment. All other States benefitted at Queensland's loss. This is evidenced in this table. Many qualifications to the figures shown in this table discount to some extent the recommendations or the findings that were made. But it is important that that assessment places emphasis on needs more than on population. It does not argue for more expenditure; it purely assesses the funds made available and compares how they should have been distributed with how they were distributed- basically, on a per capita basis.

I think the formula, whilst it has been brought forward from the 1974 type of formula, has to be looked at, but I do not think we can argue in the course of this debate for taking money from one State and giving it to the other. What we have to argue for and have faith in is the indication of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) that he is prepared to look at further funding in the context of the Budget so that if extra funds are available they can be used. In regard to this, the previous speaker for the Opposition mentioned what the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean) said about the State of the roads in the electorate of Herbert. Queensland country members have been pressing for additional funds. They have been representing their electorates. The visit through the area was the result of an invitation issued to both Federal and State Ministers so that they could see for themselves the condition of the roads . Members of a committee chaired by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) also went through the area.

As a result of these representations at last we have had an indication that both Ministers are prepared to look at a report which will be presented to both governments suggesting that additional funding for the national highway might be borne on a dollar for dollar basis. I think this is a breakthrough for the State . It is prepared to pick up its responsibilities for a highway not in the same condition as that of the highways in the rest of the nation. The Commonwealth also has good intentions. If funds are available they will be allocated. That is why the amendment that has been moved by the Oppostion cannot be supported by me . Basically the Opposition is trying to pre-empt what might be in the Budget. I think it is just political grandstanding for honourable members on that side of the House to suggest that what they have indicated will be the case.

That the question be now put.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Morris's amendment) stand part of the question.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Medical Costs of Diabetics-Advanced Technology: Telecom Australia-Petitions: Slaughter of Seal Pups-Queensland Police Force-Lithgow Telephone Exchange- Australian Engineering Design

PROCTEXT.PARA: Medical Costs of Diabetics-Advanced Technology: Telecom Australia-Petitions: Slaughter of Seal Pups-Queensland Police Force-Lithgow Telephone Exchange- Australian Engineering Design
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now and again a case is brought to the attention of members which they feel they should mention in this Parliament because it affects people with a medical complaint who are not fully covered, apparently, by our present medical arrangements. I intended to alert the Minister for Health that I would be raising a matter tonight, but of course the Minister for Health is now in another place. A woman wrote to every member of parliament in South Australia and drew attention to her problem. To explain her complaint I shall quote from her letter. She stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I write to seek your help in a problem affecting many thousands of people. As it is my intention to send this letter to all Federal and State Members of Parliament, please excuse this somewhat impersonal presentation.

Although my plea is for diabetics generally, it is more specifically for the sufferers of 'childhood onset diabetes'. These people can be treated only with daily (sometimes multiple) injections of insulin all their lives. The long-term complication of this type of diabetes is vascular disease affecting the eyes, kidneys, heart, limbs and circulation, and inevitably causing neurological disorders. Each condition is sufficiently distressing in itself, but when grouped together, the resultant distress is enormous. Technology has advanced a great deal to help the diabetic cope with these problems, with home monitoring of blood glucose, blood pressure and possibly renal dialysis.

But technology has a price. I will cite my own case as an example of the expenses in which this type of diabetic can become involved. I recently purchased (on my doctor's advice) a blood glucose home-monitoring machine at a cost of $230. The strips needed to work the machine are $3.20 per prescription of 25. I must use the machine four times daily to get the most benefit from it and this means a prescription every 6-7 days, at a total cost of $16 per month.

The needles needed to obtain the blood become blunt very quickly with this continuous use and have to be purchased every couple of weeks at $3.20 for 10. So, the purchase and maintenance of this one item is excessively expensive. Combined with the costs of five prescribed drugs ($3.20 each), insulin (two types-$3.20 each), swabs and syringes (injections 2-3 times daily), urine testing strips (2 types-$3.20 each) regular medical, podiatry and laser ophthalmology treatment, plus contributions to a health fund ($8.50 per week), the outlay gets almost prohibitive. To try and save some money for the future is also very difficult, as life assurance policies are not available to diabetics.

I therefore make this appeal for financial assistance on behalf of myself and fellow sufferers in the sincere hope that something can be done to ease the situation and would be deeply appreciative if you would be good enough to give the matter your serious consideration.

I feel that that case needs attention by the Government. I hope the Minister for Health, whoever he is, will look at the costs that these people have to bear and see whether the Government can do something to alleviate their problems. It is obvious when one works out the costs that they are terribly expensive. To suffer from the affliction of diabetes is bad enough. Some greater assistance should be made available by the Government to these unfortunate people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the great challenges facing the Australian nation today is coping with the impact of advanced technology. It is a fact that prior to modern technology and communications many of the finer things in life- art, matters of intellect, education, et cetera, were limited to a privileged few. Advances in the print media have allowed books to be scattered more widely, and made literacy practicable. Movies, the record player, radio, television and recently the video have enabled many of the world's marvels to be available and even to be understood by even the poorest and disadvantaged in our world community.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the introduction of technology, whilst bringing benefits, often has an unfortunate impact on our communities as well. This can be seen in plans by Telecom Australia to close many of our manual assistance centres throughout Australia and to computerise the services that are presently provided by hundreds of telephonists. In my electorate two such centres at Horsham and Swan Hill are scheduled to close in 1983. If this occurs some 14 women will lose their jobs and communities will lose that personal service for directory assistance, emergency calls and manual bookings that we have received so well and for so long.

Of course, Telecom is an efficient organisation. It is doing its best to offer alternative employment, generous redundancy payments, superannuation and, in many cases, income maintenance payments to these people. Computerisation of such services may also be efficient and effective-I do not know. I do know that in some cases where rationalisation of manual assistance centres has already taken place this has not always proved to be the case. I also know that many job opportunities will be lost in our rural centres and that many of these people will not be able to accept alternative work in Melbourne, simply because they are married and do not wish to leave their home environment. Therefore, I am at this time opposing this decision. I have asked for a thorough review of Telecom' s plans and details of the justification for the introduction of this sophisticated technology.

This issue, however, raises very important questions. Are we facing up to the dynamic changes occuring in our society? Are we preparing ourselves for them and obtaining the skills necessary for employment in a modern world? Society has always been confronted in its development by the two-edged sword of good and evil. New advances in technology have provided mankind with enormous benefits, but not without serious side effects sometimes. Medical advances, vaccines, antibiotics, et cetera, have improved our life expectancy and rid the world of many diseases. But the side effects of last century's discoveries in the medical field have seen an accompanying drop in the death rate, which is placing enormous pressure on earth's resources.

Agriculture in 1800 had to feed 900 million people; today less land has to produce food and fibre for 4,000 million. Fertilisers, insecticides and high energy using chemicals have to be used to boost productivity. The food for survival comes from the farm but at a high cost in energy and machinery to plough, seed, weed and reap. Nuclear energy offers a cheap solution to the world 's energy problems yet it places the earth under threat of destruction. Science has provided enormous benefits but created some serious problems.

There are pressures within our community to return to a simpler, less industrialised, way of life. These thoughts are attractive but of course impossible. We have to move forward with the new advances in technology. We must challenge them, we must conserve our resources and we must find a balance between the good and bad aspects. We are also offered a greater knowledge, greater skills and the opportunity to improve the well-being of the world's people by advanced technology. The important factor is that we equip ourselves well to cope with these changes and use them for progress in our standard of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several weeks ago I advised my electorate, through the local newspapers, that petitions were available at my office for those who had a concern for the harp seals in Canada. I was not surprised by the response. Numbers of people came to the office and took multiple copies of the petition to collect signatures from their friends, neighbours and work mates. I had a call from a teacher at Monash High School to let me know that the students there had also been busy on the same project. I went out to visit the school and found that five 13-year old boys-Gerard Jacobs, Brenton Carey, Paul Merchette, Maurice Madeste and Stephen Walmsley-had indeed been busy. On their own initiative they had collected 1,068 signatures protesting against the way in which the seal cubs were clubbed to death. The boys have demonstrated that social awareness and concern are alive and flourishing among today's youth.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to canvassing their school friends, the five conducted a doorknock of the local area, arranged to have petition forms left in various local shops and even went to the city to collect signatures in the streets. Their concern for the way in which the seal pups are brutally massacred was real and they intended to do all in their power to have it stopped. They presented me with the result of their mammoth task to bring to this Parliament. As honourable members can see, it is quite a number of pages. Difficult though it was, I had to point out to them that the wording they had used on their petition was in a form not acceptable to this Parliament. They were deeply disappointed because they had put a lot of time and energy into their work. However, undaunted by this bureaucratic obstacle, the five boys have taken copies of my petition forms and have started all over again. It is all too seldom that people in our community are prepared to stand up for and work for what they believe in and actually do something about it. Their starting again is proof of their sincerity. They have gone to a tremendous amount of trouble to put their point of view across and they can be proud of themselves. Their teachers, their school and their parents can also take pride in their achievement.

This is not the first petition I have received with incorrect wording. I suggest to the House that perhaps it is time we relaxed the requirement for the rather outdated wording that is necessary at the moment. It would give those people in the community easier access to the House. It is all very well for those of us who are involved in Parliament to know that we have to have each page correctly worded, but the kids do not know, and many people outside do not know and I think it is heartbreaking to have to reject petitions over which people have taken so much time and trouble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -Since this Parliament last sat in late March a scurrilous attack has been made on the police force under parliamentary privilege in the State House in Queensland. The honourable member for Archerfield, Mr Hooper, made an attack on what one might class as a public servant, the Commissioner of Police, and also the Assistant Commissioner. The attack carried no foundation as far as an argument was concerned. What was said on the floor of the House did not substantiate anything said outside by the honourable member. I understand that the attack that was made at that time was not condoned by members of his party within that State House, one of whom publicly disassociated himself from it.
—He is a big bubble of wind.

—He must have been I think. However it is a great pity that men in public office do not have the right of reply to charges made about them. I just want to draw attention to the fact that this is one occasion when the attack was made under circumstances that could not be substantiated. In the meantime the matter was given a tremendous amount of publicity through the Press in that State. The Commissioner of Police, Terry Lewis, has to bear the odium of it.
—What are the charges?

—That is what I would like to know. What are the charges? There were none that could be substantiated. This is a very difficult thing. If one member of his Party was prepared publicly to disagree with him perhaps the statement should have been withdrawn. However, a tribunal has now been set up and that allows this member who, under parliamentary privilege made this attack, to bring forward his charges to the tribunal. He has indicated that he is not prepared to do that. In other words he is not prepared to back up what he says inside the Parliament with statements outside.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the defence of this police commissioner. Terry Lewis is a fine policeman and a very fine commissioner. He is a prominent citizen of Brisbane. He is a great family man, a church man and this is the person who is attacked under parliamentary privilege. I would go so far as to say that although police commissioners and assistants are being challenged in the courts in other States, the whole affair regarding the police is one that is not on a high plane. Other people and other parliamentarians such as a senator from the other place, carried this attack further by making a charge, without any foundation at all, that the police force in Queensland was corrupt. What I would like to say to all parliamentarians is that if they feel they are without sin that they are not in some way tainted with some wrongdoing, then perhaps they have the right to make a charge. But in this case a person who cannot substantiate a charge proves himself to be in that category. What concerns me is that these very blanket charges, made in the Queensland Parliament and by an honourable senator, are made against what I believe is the only thing that can make a democracy work and tick, and that is the police force of any State. If we want a breakdown in the law of this nation all we have to do is do what that State member and the honourable senator did and that is break down the pride that we might have in the police and the police forces throughout Australia. On Sunday I was at an event which probably illustrates this point. During a brawl a policeman intervened to separate two men, and in front of a great crowd of people the two men turned on the policeman. I understand it was a long time before that policeman was rendered any assistance by a member of the public. I congratulate the person who went to the assistance of that policeman, but it proves the point that today there is not sufficient pride and understanding of the role of the police force which is just upholding the rule of law; laws that are made in places such as this Parliament. If we are going to talk about the bad implementation or the bad handling of the law, maybe we should start in legislatures such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to draw the attention of the House to the consequences of the proposed closure of some 16 local telephone exchanges in country centres in New South Wales. This matter was referred to briefly by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) earlier this evening and I would like to support him in what he said about the loss of local jobs. There is no doubt that jobs will go. Some 250 will go in New South Wales. There is no doubt that the effect of this will be devastating for the families concerned. More important is the effect of these closures on the standard of local emergency services. Under the present system a 000 emergency call goes to the local exchange. This local exchange is manned by local people; people who are aware of the location and capacity of local emergency services and who have a good knowledge of local geography.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the new system emergency calls will be switched by computer to wherever spare capacity might exist in the network. A call for help in, say, Lithgow, which is one of the 16 centres facing closure, might be answered in Sydney, Newcastle, Canberra or pretty well anywhere. I am particularly concerned about Lithgow. Although it is not within my electorate it is a city close by to which many of my constituents go to work. They often work in industries that have a high risk of accidents, industries like the local power generation industry, the small arms factory or the many coal mines in the Lithgow district.

I want honourable members to picture the problems that could arise in the case of an accident at any one of these places. A person at the scene of an accident, excited and emotional, simply rings up the local exchange and reports that an accident has happened at, say, Wang, Newcom, Tunnel Hill or the SAF and hangs up . The local operators would know that Wang is a local contraction for Wallerawang. They would know that Newcom is the name of a local colliery. They would know that Tunnel Hill is a well known dangerous site for motor accidents. They would know that SAF is the local contraction for the small arms factory. The local operators know these things. They would be able to follow up any report and get assistance from local emergency services quickly. But an operator in Sydney, Newcastle or somewhere else in the State simply would not know. What is more, that operator would have no way of finding out this information because the local names do not appear in any index.

I am aware that the union affected, the Australian Telephone and Phonogram Officers Association, has mounted a very vigorous campaign on this safety issue. I commend this union for putting in $25,000 of its member's funds to promote publicly what is essentially an issue of public safety. I would also like to place on record the excellent work that has been done on this issue by my friend Mr Mick Clough, the State member for Bathurst, who represents Lithgow in the New South Wales Parliament. Mick has taken hold of this issue and followed it up with his customary enthusiasm and tenacity. I commend him for that.

Tonight I would like to urge Telecom and the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) to re-think these closures; to consult with the union, to consult with the many country people who are upset about these closures and concerned about the risk to public safety. After all, this is quite a simple issue. The closure of these exchanges will mean the loss of vital local knowledge and the loss of this local knowledge could mean loss of lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time I receive a copy of the Australian Consulting Engineer, a journal that is published by the Association of Consulting Engineers, Australia. I assume that other honourable members also receive this publication. I was very interested in a couple of items which appeared in the February edition of this publication. One item refers to a matter which I addressed this House about some years ago, namely the potential for Australian engineering design in the resources development projects taking place or to take place in the near future in Australia. The February edition of the Australian Consulting Engineer makes the point that in a number of recent representations made to the Foreign Investment Review Board concern has been expressed at the continuing trend of allowing foreign engineering firms a virtual monopoly in the resources field. The publication went on to make the claim that at least 70 per cent of every project consists of various elements which fall within the demonstrated capacity of many Australian consulting engineering firms. Examples of these are roads, townships, power stations, railways and water supply projects. In some cases the complete project could be executed entirely with Australian resources.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we have to take adequate steps to ensure that companies that are developing major resources projects look for engineering design expertise within Australia. In many cases it may be easier for them to bring in a large engineering consulting firm from overseas because with one transaction they can ensure that that firm can provide them with all the design capability they need for a project. It may be that in the Australian environment they have to work a little harder to put together the appropriate range of skills needed for a particular project. I am aware that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in examining applications from companies to bring in skilled personnel, examines the availability of appropriate people already in the Australian work force. Similarly, the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, where it engages in training programs in co-operation with State governments and companies, seeks to maximise the potential of the local work force.

I wish to take up the suggestion by the Association of Consulting Engineers of Australia that, within the foreign affairs guidelines, we ought to pay greater attention to the need to ensure that Australian design engineering expertise is used in these projects for which approval is given for overseas capital participation. I do not think it is sufficient just to look at the participation by overseas capital to see whether that is in the interests of the Australian economy. I think we should also look at the skilled manpower implications of such participation and ensure that appropriate guidelines are observed when we give approval for participation by major overseas companies. I am fully in favour of participation by major overseas companies but I think we ought to look a little more closely at the training and manpower implications of some of that participation.

I draw an analogy with the standard provision that we have with respect to defence procurement. We have the Australian industry participation program whereby, if we are purchasing defence equipment from overseas, we require that the companies tendering for that business put forward proposals for Australian industry participation. The bench mark we give is that they involve Australian industry to at least 30 per cent of the value of the particular contract in question. I suggest that if some guideline of that nature regarding Australian manpower participation, or whatever one may call it, were imposed as a condition of the involvement of overseas companies in major resources projects, that would be of advantage to Australia. Indeed, it would be of advantage to the companies participating in this way because they would ensure that their investment was backed up by the best possible involvement of highly trained Australian manpower . I commend this sort of examination to the Treasurer (Mr Howard), the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and to other Ministers who may be involved to ensure that maximum use is made by Australians of projects which have the potential for involvement by Australian skilled engineering personnel.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 10.29 p.m.

(iii) The major proportion of ANL's operating costs, excluding capital servicing costs, are paid to the private sector. Other operating costs not paid to the private sector include port costs, some repairs and statutory charges.
(3) (i) Qantas has no analysis maintained in their accounting system but Qantas Management has no recollection of any capital expenditure, either in Australia or overseas, paid to the public sector.
