The only significant capital expenditure paid to the public sector would be in categories such as sales tax and customs duty. An example would be import duty on aircraft purchases.

(iii) Most ANL capital expenditure is made to the private sector for the purchase of ships, containers, cargo handling and terminal equipment, and buildings. Five ships have been built at the New South Wales Government State Dockyard during the period. They represent 12 per cent of the capital expenditure during the period.

(ii) (a) TAA is of the opinion that the time required to determine the requested value would be prohibitive, and in respect of many items its records would not indicate whether the ultimate source was local or offshore. A major import derived component would be depreciation on aircraft. Fuel is presently running at about 15 per cent imported and 85 per cent local. Aircraft maintenance and overhaul costs might include imported materials and spare parts to about 35 per cent of the total.
(b) Again TAA feels that the time that would be required precludes an exhaustive analysis, and in many cases records would not indicate the ultimate source.

In general though, TAA would be heavily reliant on imports for capital items. To a large extent aircraft and the supporting maintenance tools, test equipment, spare parts, specialised tarmac equipment and flight training simulators are not available locally. Also, computers and related equipment are predominantly imported.
On the other hand, buildings and the construction thereof would represent an area of capital expenditure with a high local content.
(iii) (a) A proportion of ANL's expenses for bunkers, insurance and repairs are payable overseas.

(b) Most of the ships built or purchased by ANL during the period in question were constructed overseas. The five built in Australia would have had a proportion of imported components. Some ANL containers for international trades have been purchased overseas. Other capital expenditure by ANL has been primarily 'domestic'.

In relation to Question 2, 3 and 4, a more accurate assessment of the information contained in the above answers would impose a time consuming task which ANL does not have the resources to undertake without detriment to its commercial accounting requirements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Porta Printer Telephones for Profoundly Deaf Persons: Department of Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister, before the International Year of Disabled Persons ceases , ensure that, at the very least, in each State office of the Minister's Department, and the central Canberra office, a Porta Printer type telephone receiver to communicate with the profoundly deaf is installed.

(2) Does the Minister understand the impediment facing profoundly deaf persons unable to use a standard telephone receiver, who need urgently to contact the Minister's Department on matters of concern, distress, or difficulty.
(3) Will the Minister ensure by this means that the profoundly deaf are not denied telephonic access to the Department which all other sections of the community enjoy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the honourable member to the answer to Question No. 3406 (Hansard, 25 March 1982, page 1494) provided by the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the percentage monetary change and real change in Government expenditure on road safety promotion and research planned for 1981-82 compared to expenditure in 1980-81.
(2) What are the Government's reasons for these changes in expenditure.
(3) Has the Government replaced any major projects concluded in 1980-81 with new major projects; if not, does this represent reduced Government concern with road safety matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Actual expenditure on Road Safety Promotion and Research (Appropriation Code 655/3/11) in 1980-81 was $786,000. In 1981-82 $600,000 has been provided. This represents a monetary decrease of 24 per cent and a real decrease of 30 per cent.
(2) An important factor was the completion in 1980-81 of the pilot testing in Tasmania of a drink-driving campaign, costing in the order of $0.4m.

(3) Major projects being initiated in 1981-82 include an analysis of all fatal road accidents in Australia in 1980, an assessment of hazardous road locations and a film on defensive driving. The government's expenditure on road safety promotion and research is only one part of total Commonwealth road safety efforts. There has been no reduction in concern with road safety matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Using figures for the last available full year, what percentage of recipients of youth employment subsidies complete the period of subsidised employment.

Two levels of subsidy are available, depending on the period of unemployment. The latest available data for Standard SYETP covers the period 30 November 1980 to 31 October 1981. In the case of Extended SYETP which commenced on 1 February 1981 the data relates to the February 1981 commencements only. These figures show that for Standard SYETP (17 weeks of training) 56.2 per cent complete the full period of training. With Extended SYETP (34 weeks of training) 55.15 per cent of trainees have completed the full period of training.

(2) The following tables indicate the percentage frequency and percentage cumulative frequency of trainees discontinuing training for each week of subsidised training. Table 1 relates to Standard SYETP and Table 2 to Extended SYETP.

(3) Statistics on the retention of former SYETP trainees by the training employers are not kept. However, late in 1979 my Department undertook a survey of a sample of employers and young people involved in private sector SYETP placements in April 1979. The results of this survey indicated that 50.7 per cent of trainees were still employed with their SYETP employer some four to five months after the completion of the subsidy period and a further 17.8 per cent were in full-time employment elsewhere.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the claim made at the Victorian Housing Crisis Conference in Melbourne recently that low income earners were being forced into emergency refuges or homelessness because of their inability to afford increasing rents.
(2) Have rents increased as a result of higher property values and escalating inflation rates.
(3) Is it a fact that homelessness is increasing rapidly particularly among single parents and the young.
(4) Was it claimed at the conference that emergency housing in Victoria was already overtaxed, with women's and youth refuges turning away 3 in 4 requests for help.
(5) Is it a fact that Commonwealth Government funding for emergency accommodation has been cut by approximately 70 per cent in real terms since 1974 -75.
(6) Is the emergency accommodation situation in Victoria indicative of the availability of crisis accommodation generally in Australia.
(7) What new initiatives does he propose to deal with this growing crisis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am aware of this Conference organised by the Women's Electoral Lobby in Melbourne last November.

(2) Over the five years to June 1981 rents in Melbourne as measured by the private rent component of the Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased by 36 per cent, compared with an increase of 61 per cent in the CPI.

(3) There is very limited information available on the extent of homelessness in the community. A number of studies has attempted to estimate numbers of homeless youth. A study in Melbourne in 1978 by the Victorian Consultative Committee for Social Development estimated there were 15,000 homeless youth per year in Melbourne and studies in South Australia in 1979 and 1980 indicated that there may be between 6,000 and 9,000 young people each year experiencing severe housing problems in South Australia. However these estimates are based on contacts by young people with welfare agencies and have a number of limitations.
(4) Yes. I am advised that this claim was made by Ms Farrar, Co-ordinator of Shelter Victoria, in a paper presented to the Conference.

(5) Commonwealth assistance for emergency accommodation is provided under a range of programs. These include the Youth Services Scheme, Homeless Persons Assistance Act, and the Family Support Services Scheme which are administered by the Department of Social Security and assistance for women's refuges which was administered by the Department of Health until 1980-81. In addition, some of the accommodation provided under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement is allocated by the States on a priority needs basis.
The following information on expenditure on each program has been provided to me by the Minister for Social Security and the Acting Minister for Health:

(a) Youth Services Scheme: This is a three year pilot scheme designed to provide emergency accommodation and support services for young people up to 18 years. The scheme commenced in 1979-80 and is cost shared on a dollar for dollar basis by the Commonwealth and State Governments. Expenditure is estimated at $1. 15m for 1981-82.

(b) Homeless Persons Assistance Program: Under this program, which commenced in December 1974, the Commonwealth makes grants towards the capital and operating costs of voluntary organisations and local governing bodies which provide accommodation, meals and a welfare service to homeless people. Expenditure under the program to 30 June 1981 was $21.79m, rising from $0.34m in 1974-75 to $7.67m in 1980-81. (This includes additional capital grants totalling $1.9m made in June 1981 and not originally budgeted for). Estimated expenditure in 1981-82 is $6.3m. A $10m three year capital program for homeless persons (with special provisions for homeless young people) commenced on 1 July 1981. Recurrent subsidies which will be generated by this capital investment will be considered in the context of the annual budgetary process.

(c) Family Support Services Scheme: Under this program, introduced on a three year pilot basis in 1978, the Commonwealth funds some voluntary agencies to provide emergency accommodation and support services to families at risk. The Government has provided for an extension of the scheme for a three year period from 1 January 1982 to 31 December 1984. Total allocation to emergency accommodation services for the period is not yet finalised but for 1981-82 it is estimated that approximately $0.4m may be expended on these services.

(d) Women's Refuges: The Commonwealth funding for women's refuges is now included in General Revenue Payments to the States. Up to 30 June 1981, funds for this purpose were provided in the form of specific-purpose grants to the States under the Community Health Program. The General Revenue Payment to each State for 1981-82 includes a component equal to the Commonwealth specific purpose grant to that State for women's refuges in 1980-81 plus 10 per cent. Funding in 1980-81 was $3,789,315 compared with $49,489 in 1974-75.
The Government also funds child care workers in women's refuges, through the Children's Services Program. The cost this financial year is expected to amount to almost $1m.

In addition to the above programs funds are provided to the States and the Northern Territory under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. Under this Agreement, funds are used to provide concessional interest rate loans and grants for home purchase and rental housing assistance.

With these funds and State funds and monies generated from the operation of the programs, States are able to provide housing assistance for those in need. It is a matter for each State to determine eligibility for assistance and the nature of that assistance. While there is no special allocation under the Agreement for emergency accommodation, States provide priority allocation for special cases. They also have provided dwellings to various organisations who in turn provide housing assistance to special groups, i.e., youth, handicapped and women's refuges. Funding under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement in 1974-75 was $ 391.45m. In 1981-82 funding is $262.2m. It should be noted that the proportion of funds provided by way of non-repayable grants rather than loans has increased very substantially from $6.05m in 1974-75 to $116.2m in 1981-82.

(6) On the basis of assistance provided under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act and the Youth Services Scheme, and also the allocations of priority ( emergency) assistance in public rental housing, the situation in Victoria appears broadly similar to that in other States.

(7) As noted in part 5 above the Commonwealth has increased funding for emergency housing under a number of existing programs, for example, the Youth Services Scheme and the Homeless Persons Assistance Program. In addition, the Government has announced the allocation of $2m in the current financial year for the commencement of a new program for crisis accommodation for families in distress. The funds allocated are to be shared by the States and the Northern Territory, and will be used to build up a stock of crisis accommodation for families. This will be done by the construction, purchase or leasing of suitable dwellings. In view of the urgent need of the Aboriginal community for this type of accommodation $100,000 of the money has been allocated to Aboriginal Hostels Ltd.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Perth Airport is particularly susceptible to rapid changes in weather (e.g. rain storms, fog, strong winds) and that senior pilots consider it to be one of the more difficult airports in Australia for landing heavy aircraft.
(2) In the event that a Boeing 747-B, or similar aircraft, was prevented from landing at Perth due to severe weather conditions, what would be the nearest suitable landing strip.
(3) If Learmonth is the nearest alternative to Perth, what effect would a diversion to Learmonth of a heavily laden 747-B have on its fuel reserves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From time to time Perth airport experiences rapid changes in weather. This is taken into account in forecasting the need for the nomination of an alternative aerodrome. My Department has no knowledge of any general opinion among senior pilots that it is one of the more difficult airports in Australia to land heavy aircraft.
(2) The nearest aerodrome to Perth suitable for Boeing 747 aircraft is Learmonth.

(3) A diversion from Perth to Learmonth of a heavily laden Boeing 747-B would require the consumption of approximately 16,000 kilograms of fuel and take about 90 minutes. There would be no dangerous effect on fuel reserves as international aircraft normally carry sufficient fuel to divert to an alternate aerodrome as well as the normal reserves.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did Qantas cease flying to South Africa and what were the published reasons for the cessation of this service.
(2) Which African airlines provide scheduled services to South Africa.
(3) How many flights to Australia each week are provided by South African Airlines.
(4) What is the seat occupancy factor for these SAA flights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Qantas suspended its once weekly service to South Africa through Mauritius in September 1977. In a press release of 20 September 1977 Qantas announced that traffic on the route had steadily declined during 1977 and substantial operating losses were being incurred.

(2) Nine African airlines provide scheduled services to South Africa. They are South African Airways; LAM (Mozambique); Air Zimbabwe; Air Botswana; Zambia Airways; Royal Swazi National Airways Corporation; Lesotho Airways; Air Mauritius; Air Malawi.
(3) South African Airways currently provides two 747-B services per week to Australia.
(4) The average seat occupancy factor on South African Airways services to Australia in 1981 was approximately 80 per cent.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines Ground Staff: Superannuation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Trans Australia Airlines ground staff contributing to the Commonwealth Public Service Superannuation Scheme were recently offered the opportunity to transfer to a separate superannuation scheme through the Australian Mutual Provident Society.
(2) Was this offer extended by the TAA management; if so, what are the reasons for this change.
(3) Is it also a fact that TAA personnel over the age of 60 years were offered the opportunity to change superannuation schemes; if so, who was responsible for this decision.
(4) Was one of the attractions in such a change the provision in the AMP superannuation scheme for a lump sum payment, as opposed to the Commonwealth scheme of partial lump sum and pension payout.

(5) Is it also a fact that the office of the superannuation fund will not release to the AMP fund those funds paid by way of regular contributions by TAA ground staff now over the age of 60 years; if so, for what reason.

(6) Did TAA ground staff over the age of 60 years receive a letter from TAA management confirming their transfer to the AMP scheme; if so, when were they notified in writing by TAA management of the transfer of superannuation funds.
(7) When did the TAA management become aware of the fact that this arrangement was not lawful.
(8) When were those ground staff affected contacted in writing by TAA management.

(9) In this period, did TAA ground staff over 60 years of age contribute to the AMP scheme; if so, will provisions be made for the complete transfer of those contributions to the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund without loss of continuity for the contributor.

(10) Was a mistake made by TAA management in offering the superannuation transfer to staff over 60 years of age, when neither the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund nor AMP could accept the transfer; if so, will an apology be sent by TAA management to each of the TAA ground staff over 60 years of age, who were offered this change of superannuation scheme, for TAA's misadvice, and any inconvenience it may have caused to the contributor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following information is provided in answer to the honourable member 's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The offer was extended by TAA management so that contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme could, if they desired, become members of the TAA Superannuation Plan which offered a lump sum payment in lieu of the pension plus refund of contributions under the Commonwealth Scheme.
(3) TAA personnel over the age of 60 years were initially offered the opportunity to change superannuation schemes. This offer was made in error by TAA.

(4) It is up to the individual contributor as to whether he is attracted to a lump sum payment scheme such as that offered under the TAA plan as opposed to the Commonwealth pension plus a refund of contributions.

(5) The office of the Superannuation Fund will not release to AMP contributions made by employees presently aged over 60 who sought to transfer to the AMP Fund. The decision of the Superannuation Commissioner is based on Clause 1 of the adjusted benefit schedule of the TAA General Superannuation Plan, 'any ground staff employee who is an eligible employee and has not attained the minimum retiring age is eligible to become a member of the Plan . . '. The minimum retiring age for TAA ground staff contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme is 60 years.
(7) September 1981, when the Commissioner for Superannuation advised that applications for transfer had been received from employees over the age of 60.

(8) Ground staff affected by this error were verbally contacted within 2 or 3 days and advised of their ineligibility to transfer. Some of these staff were also advised in writing during the next few weeks as a result of representations made by them seeking clarification on the issue.
(9) No TAA ground staff over 60 years contributed to the AMP Scheme.

(10) A mistake was made in offering the superannuation transfer to staff over 60 years of age when the Superannuation Trust Deed did not permit the transfer from the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme to the TAA Superannuation Plan. TAA management apologised in writing to those who had actually completed transfer applications. Other contributors aged 60 years or more were informed personally.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the ranks and duties of the officials in the Australian High Commission in Cyprus who travel to the part of Cyprus occupied by Turkish armed forces personnel (Hansard, 13 October 1981, page 1943).
(2) Does the Australian Government apply the Migration Agreement between Australia and Turkey to persons who reside in the Turkish-occupied area of Cyprus.
(3) Has the Government decided not to recognise purported passports issued by the Turkish Federated State of Cyprus; if so, when did it so decide.

(4) Does the Government of the Turkish Republic issue a Turkish Cypriot with a Turkish passport which in the space for the passport's number bears a special number commencing with the letters 'TRC' and which leaves blank the space for the holder's nationality; if so, do Australian officials in (a) Turkey and/or (b ) Australia, stamp these special Turkish passports issued to Turkish Cypriots.

(5) Have Australia and Cyprus discussed whether the (a) stamping of the special passports and (b) application of the Migration Agreement, are consistent with the principles of sovereignty, territorial integrity and unity of the Republic of Cyprus for which the Commonwealth Heads of Government have repeatedly declared their support; if so, what have been the date, form and outcome of the discussions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian High Commissioner to Cyprus. The Secretary to the High Commissioner.

(3) The Australian Government does not recognise travel documents issued by the 'Turkish Federated State of Cyprus' (TFSC). This has been the Government's practice since the declaration of the TFSC on 13 February 1975. No specific decision was made by the Government on this issue. The practice is a consequence of the Government's policy of not recognising the TFSC.

(4) The Turkish Government does issue residents of northern Cyprus with Turkish passports. Such passports are accepted as valid travel documents by the Australian Government and are stamped by Australian officials in Turkey and in Australia.

(5) No. The Australian Government has consistently made clear, in multilateral forums such as the Commonwealth as well as bilaterally, its support for the sovereignty, territorial integrity and unity of the Republic of Cyprus.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 February 1982: How many (a) successful and (b) unsuccessful searches were conducted for missing aircraft during (i) each of the years 1978-79, 1979-80 and 1980-81, and (ii) during the period 1 July 1981 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The question is similar to part of Question No. 3511 of 29 October 1981 from the honourable member. At that time I advised that some of the statistical information relating to previous years searches for missing aircraft was not readily available and I was not prepared to authorise the use of scarce resources to answer that part of the question. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the objectives of the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme.
(2) What (a) was the cost of the scheme in each year since its introduction; and (b) is its estimated cost in 1981-82.
(3) Does the scheme differentiate between industrial and household users of subsidised fuel.
(4) What estimates can be provided for the percentage of total subsidy paid to (a) industrial and (b) household users of subsidised fuel for (i) each year of the scheme's existence and (ii) 1981-82.

(5) Does the scheme subsidise industrial users of fuel. If so, (a) what industries are the main beneficiaries; (b) is it a fact that the scheme is, in part, a form of assistance to industry, including mining, in rural areas which is not subject to normal scrutiny procedures for industrial assistance; and (c) what impact does the scheme have upon industry costs in areas eligible for assistance under the scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The purpose of the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme is to ensure that country consumers of eligible petroleum products pay a price which includes no more than 0.44c per litre of the cost of transporting the products to country areas.
(3) and (4) As the Scheme does not differentiate between industrial and household usage no statistics are available as to percentage of subsidy paid to industrial and household users.

(5) (a), (b) and (c) The Scheme subsidises the cost of freighting eligible fuels to country locations where the freight differentials exceed 0.44c per litre. The industries and other users of such fuels in country locations benefit from the fuel freight subsidy. The basis for payment of the subsidy is the relevant legislation and the amount of subsidy itself is directly related to the freight differentials which are subject to scrutiny and justification by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current state of negotiations with the New South Wales Government and Sydney inner city councils concerning the construction of a second airport for Sydney.
(2) What has been the additional cost resulting from the delay in building a second airport for Sydney since the Major Airport Needs of Sydney study recommendations were first released.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The New South Wales Government has not accepted the Prime Minister's invitation to co-operate with the Commonwealth in the development of the close- spaced parallel runway and in determining and securing a contingent site for a future second airport, against the possibility of it being required some time in the next century.

I could understand the State Government's position if it was the result of a considered decision based on detailed information about all relevant factors. But let us be quite clear about this, the State is refusing even to let that detailed information on some very relevant factors be collected and analysed.

The Commonwealth position is clear. A second jet airport must be seen as a long term option only. It could not be counted on to provide any relief until the mid -1990's. An increase in runway capacity at Sydney Airport is essential if ready air access to Sydney is to be maintained in the medium term.
I can only hope that commonsense will prevail and that a co-operative solution will be found which is in the interests of the State, the travelling public and the domestic economy.

(2) The cost estimates adopted in the MANS Study were expressed in constant 1977 prices. A very broad approximation of these cost estimates at current prices can be obtained by increasing those in the MANS Study documents by 50 per cent.

It is important not to underestimate the enormous costs associated with strategies bringing a new international airport into operation. The new airport involves the following estimated capital expenditure by governments-$655m for a single runway plus necessary airport infrastructure, $45m for access roads, $85m for a railway link-a total of some $785m at current prices. Additionally, there is further estimated expenditure of another $370m-$325m on airport infrastructure, $45m on access roads-required to enable Sydney Airport to handle demand growth until the new airport could become operational in the mid-1990's. Total estimated expenditure would amount to $1155m at current prices over next 15 years or so.

It is important also to recognise that the community is already paying dearly for the runway congestion at Sydney Airport. The present cost to the airlines was recently estimated at $10-12m a year and if the time lost by air travellers is included the economic cost to the community could be of the order of $30m a year.

These costs can be expected to increase fairly rapidly in the years ahead. Indeed, the failure of the State Government to co-operate in this matter leaves the community facing the prospect of air services which progressively cost more, are less convenient and less reliable in terms of adhering to schedules.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does the Government allocate quotas in the (a) textile, (b) clothing and (c) footwear industries.
(2) Have there been any significant changes in the allocation of quota over the last 5 years; if so, what are those changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In August 1980 the Government announced a new seven year program of assistance for the Textile Clothing and Footwear Industry.
Bureau of Customs Notices 80/167 to 80/176 and 80/205 outline in some detail the new arrangements for and changes in quota allocation.
From 1 January 1982 and for each of the next seven years quota will be allocated to importers on the basis of previous import performance and through a tender system.

The proportion of quota allocated to importers, on the basis of their previous import performance, is approximately 85 per cent of the import ceiling established for each of the textile, clothing and footwear categories; the ceiling being the quantity of goods imported during the 12 month period ended 30 June 1980.
(2) The more significant changes, which are detailed in the Bureau of Customs Notices referred to in (1) above, include-
a fixed base period, 1 July 1978 to 30 July 1980, in lieu of a moving base, for the purpose of determining an importer's previous import performance
previous import performance, when established by an importer, is transferable for the duration of the seven year program. In the past, with a moving base, this was not possible

some 15 per cent of available quota is to be allocated each year for sale by tender. No sale of quota has previously been undertaken by the Government. Actual quantities to be offered at tender will be increased by both a liberalisation factor and any projected market growth
import licencing controls on footwear and footwear parts have been replaced with tariff quotas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States: Reports on Chemical Weaponry

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of the 19.9 per cent rise on last year's Australian Standard White wheat price will provide for: (a) interest rate rises; (b) increased borrowing; (c) increased farm costs; (d) increased wheat purchases; (e ) increased labour costs, (i) in breadmaking and (ii) elsewhere; (f) increased freight and insurance costs; and (g) other charges.

(2) What will be the (a) effect on bread prices from and (b) probable interest rate on the approximately $2 billion borrowed by the Australian Wheat Board outside the Reserve Bank Rural Credits Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's question are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Home Consumption Price of wheat for human consumption (HCP) was not increased to $187.20 per tonne for the year commencing 1 December 1981 to take account directly of the factors identified in the question, except in respect of shipping costs to Tasmania. Under the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 and the schedule to that Act the HCP is fixed annually in accordance with a formula negotiated with the industry and the States when the current marketing arrangements were decided. This formula takes into account the estimated export price during the season, the previous season's HCP, the relationship between movements in export prices and HCPs over the previous eight seasons and past changes in the Index of Prices Paid by Farmers. The HCP also makes provision for the cost of shipping wheat to Tasmania and this has been set at $3.19 per tonne for 1981-82.
Under the legislation there is a 20 per cent limitation on the annual movement in the HCP and this limitation has applied for each of the 1980-81 and 1981-82 seasons.

(a) The interest rate paid by the Australian Wheat Board on its borrowings does not have a direct effect on the price of bread. It is not included in the formula which is used to calculate the home consumption price of wheat (see answer to question (1)).

(b) The interest rates on particular parcels of bills/notes utilised by the Board to borrow commercially vary over time depending on the timing of drawdowns and maturity of borrowings. However, as an indication, current rates (24 March 1982) for 90 day bank bills are about 20.15 per cent and those for 180 day bank bills are about 20.05 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do any limits exist on the number of awards available in each of the Order of Australia categories; if so, what are the limits.
(2) How many awards have been made in each category since the inception of the scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Constitution of the Order of Australia provides for a maximum number of awards in each calendar year in the General Division and in the Military Division as follows:
General Division: Knight/Dame 2, Companion 20, Officer 50, Member 125, Medal no limit.

Military Division: Not more than one-tenth of one per cent of the average number of persons who were members of the Defence Force on each day of the immediately preceding year. The maximum number of awards available at each level is:
Companion-5 per cent of the total;
Officer-20 per cent of the total;
Member-remainder of the total;
There is no limit imposed on the number of Medals which may be awarded.

(2) Knight/Dame10; Companion: General Division 53, Military Division 3; Officer : General Division 198, Military Division 68; Member: General Division 691, Military Division 226; Medal: General Division 1046, Military Division 121.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Review of Commonwealth Functions: Australian High Commission in London

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice , on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have staff processing visa applications in the Australian High Commission in London been affected by the Review of Commonwealth Functions; if so, what are the specific details.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) 98,000 applications for tourist visas were processed by the High Commission in the year ended 30 June 1981 and (b) 120,000 applications are anticipated in the year ending 30 June 1982.

(3) If so, in view of the expected increase in the number of applications for tourist visas and the delays which are now being experienced in issuing these visas, will he take steps to increase the number of staff employed in the Australian High Commission in London.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Review of Commonwealth Functions decided that staffing levels at the Migration Branch, Australian High Commission, London should be reduced by six Australia based officers and forty locally engaged staff. Action is in progress to meet that requirement.

(2) During 1980-81, 109,802 persons applied at migration offices in Britain for visitor entry to Australia. Of these 89,753 persons applied at the Migration Branch, London with applications from the remaining 20,049 persons being processed at offices in Manchester and Edinburgh. For a time, applications normally handled in Manchester were diverted, because of staffing difficulties, to London, thereby temporarily increasing the work load there. It is anticipated that during 1981-82, some 129,000 persons will apply throughout Britain, with an estimated 81,000 persons applying at London.

(3) Five locally engaged staff have been made available temporarily by the Administration, Australian High Commission, London, to assist in attending to visitor visa applications. Additionally, permanent staff, both Australia-based and locally engaged, have been temporarily redeployed from permanent entry processing (except for immediate family reunion and employment nomination cases) to meet the sudden escalation in workloads arising from the recent introduction of cheap air fares between London and Australia.
The situation in Britain is currently under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many general aviation aircraft in Australia were equipped with emergency location beacons at the date of preparation of the answer to this question?
(2) What information is he able to provide on the (a) structure, (b) durability and (c) location of the emergency location beacon unit as fitted to general aviation aircraft?

(3) Will he initiate action to ensure that emergency location beacons are constructed of material designed to withstand the impact of an aircraft crash and are located at a position in the aircraft that will maximise the possibility of the emergency location beacon being activated and operative in the event of the aircraft being involved in a crash?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department does not and cannot maintain precise records of emergency locator beacons (ELB's) in Australian aircraft. It is estimated that between 30 per cent and 50 per cent of general aviation aircraft are equipped with permanently installed ELB's and some others are equipped with survival beacons on a temporary basis for flights over designated remote areas.
(2) Equipment standards for the design and performance of various types of emergency locator beacons are contained in Air Navigation Orders.
Survival beacons are designed to be stowed in life-rafts, attached to life- jackets, or otherwise carried so that they are available to survivors in the event of a crash or emergency landing.

Crash locator beacons and emergency locator transmitters are designed to be permanently installed in the rear of aircraft for best chance of survival in a crash, to operate automatically and also to be accessible to survivors of an emergency landing on land.

Requirements for carriage of survival beacons and installation of crash locator beacons and emergency locator transmitters, including location of the latter in the rear of the aircraft, are also specified in Air Navigation Orders.
(3) Such requirements have been in effect for several years. Accident studies have shown that the rear section of an aircraft is most likely to survive a crash.
Crash forces are unpredictable and it is not practicable to design a beacon sturdy enough to survive all crashes yet be light enough to install far aft in light aircraft.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: South African Airways: Services between Johannesburg and Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many passengers were carried by South African Airways to and from Australia in 1981.
(2) What was the average load factor of South African Airways on services between Johannesburg and Australia in 1981.
(3) Has Qantas Airways Ltd applied for the resumption of rights for services to and from South Africa.
(4) Has this application been rejected, if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A total of 59,985 revenue passengers were carried by South African Airways to and from Australia in 1981.
(2) The average load factor on South African Airways services to Australia in 1981 was approximately 80 per cent.
(3) Qantas sought the Government's approval in May 1980 to resume services to and from South Africa.

(4) The Government considers that it would not be appropriate for Qantas to resume services to South Africa and has indicated that it could not agree to the airline's proposal. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the retention rate of the Defence Force reserves.
(2) How many people have enlisted in the reserves since the campaign to increase the strength to 30,000 was launched.
(3) How many have ceased to be members of the reserves in the same period and for what reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the 1980-81 wastage expressed as a percentage of monthly average strength was 24.6 per cent. On this basis retention may be said to have been 75. 4 per cent. For the seven months July 1981-January 1982, wastage expressed on a pro-rata basis is running at 27.0 per cent per annum. Thus, retention for this period may be said to be 73 per cent.
(2) 18,918 people enlisted in the reserves between 1 July 1980 and 31 January 1982.

(3) Between 1 July 1980 and 31 January 1982 wastage from the reserves was 11, 111. Statistics concerning the reasons for wastage are not readily available for all of this period but category expressed as a percentage of total discharges for the period January 1981 to June 1981 was:
At own request 54.3 To enlist in ARA 7.6 Unable to meet training requirements 27.8 Miscellaneous 7.3 Death, medical, retirement 3.0

Earlier studies of discharges from the reserve have indicated that a change in job, increased job demands, insufficient time available and family commitments are the main factors influencing the decision to separate from the reserves.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do Department of Defence contracts for equipment (a) construction and (b) supply have the same provisions for insurance and responsibility for damage to the equipment prior to delivery to the Department; if so what are these provisions.
(2) Do provisions for insurance and responsibility for equipment before delivery vary; if so, when, why and in what way do they vary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The insurance provisions of contracts for construction of major equipment such as ships and the supply of stores and equipment 'off the shelf' are different. Defence contracts for the supply of stores/equipment normally place the onus for insurance and damage responsibility on the contractor until such time as the equipment passes into effective Commonwealth control. For major equipment being constructed to a specific Defence design, the Commonwealth to the greatest extent possible accepts the insurance risks from the time the initial payment is made against the contract. The principal reason for the Commonwealth carrying its own risk is that the cost of premiums which would otherwise be payable out of Commonwealth funds are avoided. However, the extent to which the Commonwealth actually bears the costs of loss or damage is dependent on the particular circumstances of each case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 February 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that no legislation presently exists that empowers the Government to remove sub-standard foreign ships from Australian ports.

(2) If controls do exist in respect of part (1) (a) do these give Australian authorities powers of inspection of suspected sub-standard foreign ships and (b) has the Anro-Asia at any time been the subject of such an inspection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Investigations carried out by the Marine and Ports Council of Australia ( MPCA) indicate that the legislation of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory confers limited power to remove ships from Australian ports although it is not specifically related to sub-standard ships. At the 10th MPCA meeting in November 1981, Ministers agreed to legislate to confer power to refuse entry to and to authorise the removal of sub-standard ships from Australian ports.

(2) The Commonwealth has power to inspect ships in port to detain sub-standard ships. This is and will remain the principal method of control. The Anro-Asia has been regularly visited by Department of Transport marine surveyors for the purpose of inspections required by the Navigation (Cargo-Hazards Prevention) Regulations. During these inspections, there was nothing in general appearance of the ship to suggest that it was below standard in any way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 February 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that light aircraft are not compelled to carry third party insurance to cover either property or personal risk.
(2) Has he considered making third party insurance cover compulsory for all light aircraft flying in Australian airspace.
(3) Has there ever been a light aircraft crash in which there was a resultant loss of property and/or life in which the aircraft involved was not insured for third party; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The question of compulsory insurance for passengers is currently being considered jointly by the Commonwealth and State Government. However, the question of an even broader third party compulsory insurance scheme is a much more complex issue as treatment of cases varies from State to State and Territory. Some States have effected no fault/no limit liability while others leave it to common law actions. Commonwealth legislation at present only applies to international carriage. The Government is aware of the increasing need for this situation to be reviewed and action is being taken in Commonwealth/State Government forums.
(3) This information is not readily available. As there is no Commonwealth requirement for operators to carry insurance, particulars of such insurance cover are not maintained by my Department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transport of Lectern for Use by Prime Minister

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that for some years he has frequently used the same lectern when making speeches in various parts of Australia; if so, has the lectern travelled to every mainland capital city; if not, which ones has it travelled to .

(2) Is this the same lectern which appears in a photograph on page 559 of the November 1981 issue of Australian Foreign Affairs Record published by the Department of Foreign Affairs relating to the official opening by the Prime Minister of a meeting of the International Bauxite Association on 6 November 1981.
(3) Who purchased the lectern.
(4) What was the purchase price.
(5) What has been the cost of the elaborate transport arrangements necessary for the movement of the lectern around Australia.

(6) Who is responsible for attending to arrangements for the movement of the lectern and to what extent have Commonwealth officers, vehicles and aircraft or services contracted by the Commonwealth, been involved.

(7) In view of his frequent remarks about wasteful expenditure will he immediately end his requirement for, and the unnecessary expenditure associated with, the movement of this lectern and instead use one of his hands to hold his speech notes like thousands of other speakers around Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (7) The lectern to which the honourable member refers is privately owned and is made available for my use without charge. It is not possible to isolate the costs of transporting it from the total costs of transporting other equipment which is essential for my responsibilities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Defence: Equal Opportunities Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department have an equal employment opportunities program; if so,
(a) how long has the program been in existence,
(b) what are the aims of the program,
(c) what is the Department's assessment of the success of the program in achieving its aims,
(d) how have, or are, the aims of the program been, or being, met,
(e) is the program aimed at covering the whole Department, or merely a section of it,
(f) what are the procedures for union consultation and involvement in the program,
(g) what involvement does the Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau of the Public Service Board have in the program and
(h) has the program changed in its priority rating within the Department since its introduction.
(2) If there is no program, on what basis was this decision reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes-

(a) the concept of equal employment opportunity (EEO) in the Australian Public Service gained momentum in 1977 following the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. In line with Government policy, the Public Service Board has, over recent years, introduced a number of initiatives designed to achieve equal employment opportunities for women and members of minority groups. My Department has progressively implemented and maintained these initiatives, which have concentrated on people in the following categories:
Women
Aboriginals
Ethnic groups and
the Disabled,
(b) broadly speaking the aims of our over-all program follow Government policy, which states that there is to be no discrimination in employment on the grounds of:
gender
ethnic background
physical disability
sexual preference
religious or philosophical beliefs,

(c) my Department is satisfied with the success achieved to date in promoting EEO within the Department of Defence, particularly concerning women, aboriginals and the disabled. The ongoing program is subject to continual assessment by senior management of the Department,

(d) the aims of the program have been enunciated in a number of instructions which have been distributed widely throughout the Department. These aims have been and are being facilitated in the following ways:

the Department has recently appointed a permanent EEO officer, whose broad role is to provide a focal point for achieving non-discrimination in employment matters and generally heighten EEO awareness in the Department,
special emphasis is given to EEO principles in the content of appropriate training courses conducted by the Department, e.g. selection interviewing, and supervision,
in order to strengthen public awareness of EEO considerations, my Department has produced two video programs on the following subjects:
employment of aboriginal people and their involvement in the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals Scheme in the Department,
employment of disabled people in the Department,
these videos have facilitated the Department's continued success in the employment of the disabled and active participation in the NESA Scheme,

close attention is given to the selection of women for development opportunities, especially supervision and management courses. In this regard the first female civilian participant is currently attending the Joint Services Staff College, for which civilian attendance is keenly contested by a number of Commonwealth Departments.
(e) the EEO program is aimed at the whole Department,
(f) broad policy guidelines on EEO matters are issued by the EEO Bureau of the Public Service Board. On EEO issues, the need for, and conduct of consultation with unions is undertaken by the Board,

(g) the EEO Bureau is the focal point for EEO initiatives and programs in Commonwealth Departments. My Department maintains close liaison with the Public Service Board on all EEO matters affecting it, including EEO measures being adopted in the Department,
(h) no,
(2) not applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Science and Technology: Equal Opportunities Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department have an equal employment opportunities program; if so (a) how long has the program been in existence, (b) what are the aims of the program, (c) what is the Department's assessment of the success of the program in achieving its aims, (d) how have, or are, the aims of the program been, or being, met, (e) is the program aimed at covering the whole Department, or merely a section of it, (f) what are the procedures for union consultation and involvement in the program, (g) what involvement does the Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau of the Public Service Board have in the program and (h) has the program changed in its priority rating within the Department since its introduction.
(2) If there is no program, on what basis was this decision reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This Department has a policy of facilitating equal employment opportunities of all categories covered by the Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau of the Public Service Board.
(a) Policies relevant to equality of employment within this Department have been in existence since its creation in 1972.
(b) The aims of the program within this Department are those which are in keeping with the Government's endorsed policy implemented by the Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau.

(c) The aims of the program have been met through ensuring equal access to employment and other aspects of departmental opportunities available to all staff. Arrangements are continuing for the inclusion of relevant information in appropriate departmental documents, as they are amended and revised. In this regard the program has been successful.
(d) This Department has not had the opportunity of reviewing the overall program, but indications from statistics gathered by the Public Service Board are favourable.
(e) The overall program is aimed at covering the whole of the Department wherever possible.
(f) The staff associations have regular and comprehensive meetings with senior management of the Department at which opportunities are provided to discuss any matters affecting departmental staff.
(g) The Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau has overall responsibilities for the service-wide program and is consulted and advised by this Department as appropriate on each segment of the program.

(h) The program has been continually developing as the opportunity arises since its introduction and through this, greater understanding of the range of opportunities presenting themselves has been gained. This has facilitated the general growth and broadening of the program within the Department.
(2) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have current operational airspace regulations, challenged by a landowner in Nowra, as referred to in his answer to my question No. 3187 (Hansard, 18 November 1981, page 3144), been found wanting.
(2) Has he taken action to gazette new Defence (Areas Control) Regulations in view of the recommendations of the Ombudsman on page 175 of his 3rd annual report.
(3) If so, (a) is provision made for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and (b) do the new regulations cover the recommendations of the Ombudsman.

(4) If not, (a) what is the status of ownership and rights, relating to land usage, etc., of people owning properties adjacent to military airfields and bases in what are considered danger areas, (b) what is the reason for the delay, and (c) when will the present situation be corrected.
(5) Has (a) the matter of new Defence (Areas Control) Regulations been discussed with the Ombudsman or (b) the Ombudsman been notified of any ministerial decision relating to new regulations.

(6) Do existing regulations and defence legislation provide (a) adequate authority for defence usage of military airfields, (b) for the regulation of adjacent airspace and (c) for the protection of runways, etc., against the incursion into flight areas or adjacent private property of hazards, either natural or man made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This part of the question raises matters at issue in the legal proceedings referred to in my answer to question No. 3187 (Hansard, 18 November, 1981, page 3144). It is therefore not appropriate for me to comment on such matters.
(2) I have approved the development of new Defence (Areas Control) Regulations. A draft of the proposed Regulations is under examination in my Department.

The Regulations will provide a basis for controlling the heights of buildings and other natural and artificial objects in the vicinity of Defence airfields, where these are hazardous to aircraft or related activities.
(3) and (4) (a) It is proposed that the Regulations will make provision for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal relating to various classes of decisions under the Regulations.
(b) The aim in drafting the Regulations, has been to cover all of the Ombudsman 's recommendations concerning the control of building heights.
(5) (a) and (b) The Ombudsman's Office has, in accordance with his recommendations, been kept informed of progress with the development of the Defence (Areas Control) Regulations.
(6) See my answer to (1) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Royal Navy anti-submarine cruiser H.M.S. Invincible possess an action data automation weapon system built by Ferranti and Plessey, known as ADAWS6.

(2) Is the ship equipped with sensors including type 1022 long-range surveillance radar, IFF/SIF, Type 992Q search and target indication radar, 2 Type 909 radars for the Sea Dart system and Type 1006 navigation radar.
(3) Are the ADAWS6 and all or part of the sensors compatible with other Royal Navy ships.
(4) Is there commonality in both armaments and sensors with Royal Australian Navy and United States of America ships.

(5) Will the same weapon systems and sensors be retained once the Invincible is part of the R.A.N.; if so, will spares be held in the United Kingdom or in Australia and what will be the cost of the desired stock level.

(6) If the same weapons systems and sensors are not to be retained, which ones will be stripped out and what will the cost of the operation necessary to make the Invincible's systems and sensors compatible with Australian requirements.
(7) Are the communications systems compatible with those of the R.A.N.; if not, will it be required for the Invincible's systems to be changed and what will be the cost of this operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) The sensors, weapons and data system hardware of Invincible are common to many Royal Navy ships.

(4) H.M.S. Invincible has almost no commonality of sensors or weapons with United States Navy or R.A.N. ships. However the ship has a data link system ( Link 11) which gives her full operational compatibility with similarly equipped units of United States and Australian defence forces including our DDGs, PC3 aircraft and in due course FFGs.

(5) The ADAWS6 combat system of Invincible will be retained largely intact with the exceptions listed in paragraph 6 below. Since Invincible is one of a class of three ships and since much of her equipment is common to other Royal Navy ships we are looking for any advantages to be gained through co-operative logistic arrangements. The United Kingdom Ministry of Defence and the Royal Navy have indicated their willingness to co-operate wherever practicable along these lines. A project team is in the United Kingdom investigating such arrangements. Details of support arrangements and costs are yet to be finalised.
(6) An upper limit of $5m has been provided for R.A.N. modifications to Invincible. With respect to the combat system, planned alterations or additions are:
(a) Type 184 sonar to be removed.
(b) IFF/SIF equipment will be transferred from H.M.A.S. Melbourne to Invincible .

(c) Sea Dart missle system-as I covered in my statement to Parliament on 25 February 1982 the question of whether or not to retain this system is the subject of a special study which is now in progress.

(7) There are minor communication changes to be implemented before Invincible is fully compatible with the R.A.N. communications system. These include the installation of special security communications equipment to be removed from H.M .A.S. Melbourne. The cost of these changes is included in the aforementioned $5m estimate.
